Reserves and Academy|Manchester City]] |years1 = 2005–2009 |clubs1 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] |caps1 = 8 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2006 |clubs2 = → [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] (loan) |caps2 = 4 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2006 |clubs3 = → [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] (loan) |caps3 = 29 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2007 |clubs4 = → [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] (loan) |caps4 = 15 |goals4 = 0 |years5 = 2007–2008 |clubs5 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan) |caps5 = 14 |goals5 = 0 |years6 = 2008 |clubs6 = → [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] (loan) |caps6 = 9 |goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2009–2010 |clubs7 = [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] |caps7 = 43 |goals7 = 0 |years8 = 2010–2011 |clubs8 = [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] |caps8 = 37 |goals8 = 0 |years9 = 2011– |clubs9 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps9 = 294 |goals9 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2004–2005 |nationalteam1 = [[Denmark national under-19 football team|Denmark U19]] |nationalcaps1 = 8 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2006 |nationalteam2 = [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U20]] |nationalcaps2 = 1 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 2007–2008 |nationalteam3 = [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U21]] |nationalcaps3 = 17 |nationalgoals3 = 0 |nationalyears4 = 2013– |nationalteam4 = [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] |nationalcaps4 = 44 |nationalgoals4 = 0 |club-update = 07:57, 17 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = 23:28, 21 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Kasper Peter Schmeichel''' ({{IPA-da|kasbɐ ˈsmɑjˀɡl̩}}; born 5 November 1986) is a Danish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|LeicestC}} club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[Denmark national football team|Denmark national team]]. He is the son of former [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and Danish international goalkeeper [[Peter Schmeichel]].
Schmeichel began his career with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], but he had loan spells with [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]], [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] and [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] before he made his Manchester City debut. Although Schmeichel appeared to have made the City number 1 jersey his own at the start of the 2007–08 season, the emergence of [[Joe Hart]] resulted in Schmeichel being loaned to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. The signing of Republic of Ireland international [[Shay Given]] in January 2009 meant that Schmeichel fell even further down the pecking order at City, and in August 2009, he was allowed to link up with former manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] at [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]]. He spent only one season with the Magpies as, while it was a very successful one for the club and the player himself, changes to the club's financial position made his departure necessary and his contract was terminated by mutual consent. He joined [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in May 2010, but again, his tenure at the club would only last one season before he was the subject of a transfer to Leicester City, where he would again work under Eriksson. Schmeichel has gone on to play over 300 competitive games for Leicester, winning the Championship in the 2013–14 season and the Premier League in 2015–16.
He played 17 games for the [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark national under-21 team]]. Schmeichel was called up to the Denmark national team for the first time against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] on 13 May 2011,<ref name="translate.google.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.bt.dk/fodbold/olsen-overrasker-udtager-schmeichel |title=Olsen overrasker: Udtager Schmeichel |newspaper=BT |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=25 November 2013 |language=Danish}}</ref> and was part of their squad at [[UEFA Euro 2012]], but did not make his senior debut until 2013.
==Club career== ===Manchester City=== Born in [[Copenhagen]],<ref name=Hugman1011/> Schmeichel joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in September 2002 on a long-term contract, which covered schoolboy, scholar and professional terms.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel's son joins Man City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/2241867.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 September 2002 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> He joined [[Football League Two|League Two]] side [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] on a loan deal in January 2006,<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel joins Quakers on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/darlington/4610178.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 January 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> where he made his professional first team debut against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] at the [[96.6 TFM Arena]] on 14 January 2006. Darlington won the game 2–1, with Schmeichel conceding a goal to Peterborough striker [[James Quinn (footballer)|James Quinn]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Darlington 2–1 Peterborough |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/4590336.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 January 2006 |accessdate=20 June 2007}}</ref> He gained his first [[clean sheet]] three days later against [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]]. He made two further appearances before returning to Manchester City.
One month after returning to Manchester City he was loaned out again, this time to [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] in February,<ref>{{cite news |title=Bury sign Man City's Schmeichel |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bury/4736578.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 February 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> where he made 15 appearances in a three-month loan spell. He returned to Bury for a further three months the following season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel returns to Gigg Lane |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bury/5279498.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2006 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref>
Schmeichel joined [[Scottish Premier League]] side [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] on loan from January 2007 until the end of the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel gets Falkirk loan move |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/falkirk/6251405.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 January 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> He was named [[man of the match]] against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] on 18 February 2007. He also saved a [[Craig Beattie]] penalty in a 1–0 win over [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] on 18 March 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/6456637.stm |title=Falkirk 1–0 Celtic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 March 2007 |accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> He revealed in May he would have liked his loan at Falkirk extended, and the club expressed an interest in signing him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel keen on Falkirk stay |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/falkirk/6574929.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Falkirk target Schmeichel switch |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/falkirk/6224204.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 June 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref>
[[File:Kasper Schmeichel 2.JPG|thumb|left|150px|Schmeichel playing for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2007]]
Schmeichel made his Manchester City debut against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in August 2007.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=West Ham 0–2 Man City |url=http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6931065.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> He played against City's rivals and his boyhood team [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 19 August 2007 and kept a clean sheet in City's 1–0 home win.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Man City 1–0 Man Utd |url=http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6941879.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 August 2007 |accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> Schmeichel saved a penalty from [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal's]] [[Robin van Persie]] on 25 August 2007 at the [[Emirates Stadium]]. Despite City losing 1–0 to Arsenal he was named man of the match. He played the first seven of Manchester City's games in the [[2007–08 Premier League]], keeping clean sheets against Manchester United, West Ham, [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], conceding only five goals.<ref>{{Soccerbase season|37210|2007|name=Kasper Schmeichel|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> [[File:Kasper Schmeichel 2006.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Schmeichel making a save during training while on loan at [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] on 23 September 2006]] He signed a new four-year deal with City in September 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel pens new Man City deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/7009246.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 September 2007 |accessdate=23 September 2007}}</ref> This was then followed up with an agreement to go on a one-month loan with [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 25 October 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff seal Schmeichel loan deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/7062022.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2007 |accessdate=25 October 2007}}</ref> He made his debut for Cardiff on 27 October 2007 in a 1–1 draw with [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff 1–1 Scunthorpe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7054123.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2007 |accessdate=28 October 2007}}</ref> He was named 2007 [[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish Under-21 Talent of the Year]].<ref name="arla">{{cite news |title=Schmeichel årets Arla-talent |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=242463 |publisher=Danish Football Association |language=Danish |date=6 November 2007 |accessdate=23 November 2007}}</ref>
Towards the end of the loan spell, Schmeichel requested that he would be allowed to stay on at Cardiff for a longer period and on 22 November, the loan spell was extended until the new year, with manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] stating that he could possibly stay at the club for the rest of the season providing Manchester City do not suffer an injury crisis.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kasper can stay at Ninian into the new year |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/kasper-can-stay-ninian-new-2219786 |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=22 November 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> After Eriksson named [[Joe Hart]] as the number one goalkeeper at Manchester City, however, [[Andreas Isaksson]] requested a transfer. This meant that Eriksson would not allow Cardiff to keep Schmeichel after his initial loan period ended on 2 January.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kasper ready to ghost away from Ninian following Sven's summons |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/kasper-ready-ghost-away-ninian-2213019 |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> On 31 December, Eriksson threw Cardiff a lifeline by opening talks for Schmeichel to stay at [[Ninian Park]]. Schmeichel would be allowed to stay for two more matches should Isaksson not move until late in the January transfer window. Schmeichel had stated he would like to play for Cardiff again in the future.<ref>{{cite news |first=Terry |last=Phillips |title=Sven's new year gift to Cardiff City |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/svens-new-year-gift-cardiff-2214180 |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=31 December 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Tucker |title=Schmeichel content to extend Cardiff stay |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/schmeichel-content-extend-cardiff-stay-2199716 |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=1 January 2008 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> Schmeichel, however, returned to [[City of Manchester Stadium|Eastlands]] the day after his initial loan expired.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~1205866,00.html |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120526210350/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1205866%2C00.html |archivedate=26 May 2012 |title=Kasper returns to Manchester City |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=3 January 2008 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>
He joined [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on loan until the end of the season on 13 March.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10269~1264260,00.html |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120526210351/http://www.ccfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10269~1264260%2C00.html |archivedate=26 May 2012 |title=Sky Blues agree Schmeichel deal |publisher=Coventry City F.C. |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> Towards the end of the season, his father, [[Peter Schmeichel]], commented during a TV interview that his son was not happy at Manchester City and was set to leave following the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel set for Man City exit |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/7351151.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=13 August 2008}}</ref>
Despite wanting to leave, Schmeichel returned to the City of Manchester Stadium at the end of the season and changed to the number 16 shirt. He repeatedly stated that he wanted to leave City and regretted signing a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |title=Schmeichel wants City exit |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_3974080,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |date=13 August 2008 |accessdate=13 August 2008}}</ref>
[[File:Kasper Schmeichel (1240546579).jpg|thumb|left|230px|Schmeichel during a match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 2007]]
On 16 November, Schmeichel entered a game as a substitute after Joe Hart injured his ankle in the 14th minute. City went on to a 2–2 result with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Fletcher |title=Hull 2–2 Man City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7715659.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=15 August 2009}}</ref> In December 2008, Schmeichel played his last game for Manchester City in a [[UEFA Cup]] match against [[Racing de Santander]].<ref name="thisisnottingham.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Brave-Schmeichel-deserves-World-Cup-place-says-Backe/story-12207172-detail/story.html |title=Notts County manager Hans Backe believes Kasper Schmeichel has a bright future ahead of him |newspaper=Nottingham Post |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208002928/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Brave-Schmeichel-deserves-World-Cup-place-says-Backe/story-12207172-detail/story.html |archivedate=8 December 2013}}</ref> On 4 January 2009, he stated in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' that he was ready to quit the club after falling down the pecking order at Eastlands.<ref>{{cite news |title=Monday's gossip column |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/gossip_and_transfers/7811007.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 January 2009 |accessdate=8 February 2009}}</ref>
===Notts County=== On 14 August 2009, Schmeichel signed for League Two side [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] in a deal that is believed to have broken the club's previous transfer record. The transfer reunited Schmeichel with his former Manchester City manager, Sven-Göran Eriksson, who had recently been appointed director of football for Notts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Magpies snap up keeper Schmeichel |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/notts_county/8201444.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=15 August 2009}}</ref> He was the highest paid player at the club, earning £1 million annually.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saving Notts County |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/simonaustin/2010/03/saving_notts_county.html |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> He made his debut on 22 August and kept a clean sheet in the side's 3–0 win against [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]]. In September 2009, Schmeichel almost scored with an audacious overhead kick against [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] when he came up from a corner late on in the game.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oreKpLxqp60 |title=YouTube |via=YouTube |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
A fine string of performances in October earned Schmeichel the Player of the Month award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10426~1875493,00.html |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120526210353/http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10426~1875493%2C00.html |archivedate=26 May 2012 |title=Kasper delighted with award |publisher=Notts County F.C. |date=14 November 2009 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> During Schmeichel's stay at The Magpies, the club conceded only 0.67 goals per League 2 match (29 goals conceded in 43 league appearances). Schmeichel's clean-sheets-to-game-ratio at Notts County was an impressive 55.8 percent (24 out of 43 league appearances).<ref>{{Soccerbase season|37210|2009|name=Soccerbase}}</ref> On 27 April, Schmeichel and Notts County secured the [[2009–10 Football League Two|2009–10 League Two]] trophy and promotion for the [[Football League One]] with a 5–0 win against already relegated [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]].<ref name="l2-1">{{cite web |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/27042010/58/league-notts-county-clinch-title.html |title=League Two – Notts County clinch title – Yahoo! Eurosport |publisher=Yahoo! |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="l2-2">{{cite news |url=http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10426~47395,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318071739/http://www.nottscountyfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10426~47395%2C00.html |archivedate=18 March 2012 |title=Darlington 0–5 Notts County |publisher=Notts County F.C. |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> Shortly before the game, it was announced that Notts County agreed to release Schmeichel at the end of the season despite having four years left on his contract. The reasoning behind this was financial: Schmeichel earned a reported £15,000 per week, having been signed during the brief ownership period of high-spending [[Qadbak Investments|Munto Finance]] in the summer 2009. Schmeichel agreed to forgo all his future wages, something which chairman [[Ray Trew]] described as "a huge concession by such a young man".<ref name="Notts County to tear up Kasper Schmeichel deal">{{cite news |title=Notts County to tear up Kasper Schmeichel deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/notts_county/8647725.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref>
===Leeds United=== [[File:Schmeichel Leeds.jpg|thumb|left|230px|Schmeichel at [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] as he sees the ball crossed in a match against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]]]
On 27 May 2010, having been linked with both [[Premier League]] and [[Bundesliga]] clubs, Schmeichel signed a two-year contract with [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], joining the club on 1 July 2010.<ref name="Kasper becomes first summer recruit">{{cite news |title=Kasper becomes first summer recruit |url=http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100527/kasper-becomes-first-summer-recruit_2247585_2060450 |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |date=27 May 2010 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207222741/http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100527/kasper-becomes-first-summer-recruit_2247585_2060450 |archivedate=7 December 2013 }}</ref> In the 2010–11 season squad number announcement, Schmeichel was given the number 1 shirt at Leeds. After much speculation during the pre-season over who would be Leeds' first choice goalkeeper for the forthcoming season, it was Schmeichel who was given the nod ahead of [[Shane Higgs]]. He made his debut for the club on Saturday 7 August 2010 in Leeds' opening Football League Championship match against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]. Despite Leeds losing 2–1, Schmeichel put in an impressive performance, making several crucial saves during the match.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/leeds-united/7931894/Leeds-United-1-Derby-County-2-match-report.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |title=Leeds United 1 Derby County 2: match report |date=7 August 2010 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |location=London |first=Duncan |last=White}}</ref> After a string of impressive games for Leeds, Schmeichel was nominated for the August Championship Player of the Month award, but lost out to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] winger [[Adel Taarabt]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8984819.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Warnock and Taarabt scoop awards |date=9 September 2010}}</ref> Schmeichel, however, did win [[Sky Sports]] Championship Player of the Month award for August.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11715_6354496,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Best of the month |date=6 September 2010}}</ref>
After picking up a tendon injury in his foot, Schmeichel missed the game against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and was ruled out of Leeds' next few games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/1fsb8k9l1yn5d1ovz8b46d95t6/title/kasper-out-as-brown-joins-on-loan |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> While out injured, Schmeichel appeared on ''[[Soccer AM]]'' as one of the guests on the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100921/kaspers-interview-soccer-am_2247585_2160628 |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207222747/http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100921/kaspers-interview-soccer-am_2247585_2160628 |archivedate=7 December 2013}}</ref> After just under two months out, Schmeichel returned to the Leeds starting line-up against Cardiff City. He was set to play against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on 6 November, but due to the birth of his first child the night before, he missed the game.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/match-report/match/945129 |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
On 8 January 2011, Schmeichel helped Leeds earn a 1–1 draw against Arsenal in the [[FA Cup]] Third Round match at the Emirates Stadium.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/match-report/match/1052631 |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> After the match, Arsenal captain [[Cesc Fàbregas]] commented that Schmeichel should have received the match ball for his performance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Fabregas-Schmeichel-var-fantastisk |title=Fabregas: Schmeichel var fantastisk |website=bold.dk |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> Although Leeds lost the replay 3–1, Schmeichel produced another impressive display (nearly scoring himself via a header) and he was subsequently named player of the FA Cup Third Round.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20110124/kasper-bags-fa-cup-award_2247585_2275135 |title=Kasper bags FA Cup award |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207222737/http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20110124/kasper-bags-fa-cup-award_2247585_2275135 |archivedate=7 December 2013}}</ref>
On 20 June 2011, Leeds announced they had accepted an undisclosed bid for him from [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2005993/Leicester-close-Kasper-Schmeichel-fail-3m-bid-Nicky-Maynard.html |title=Leicester close in on Kasper Schmeichel but fail in £3m bid for Nicky Maynard |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=21 June 2011}}</ref> With Schmeichel wanting to stay at Leeds for the remainder of his contract, he admitted that the decision to sell him was a real shock.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/leeds_united_schmeichel_news_was_a_real_shock_ormsby_1_3514880 |title=Leeds United: Schmeichel news was a real shock – Ormsby |newspaper=Yorkshire Evening Post |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> Leeds claimed that they felt they wanted to strengthen the goalkeeping position to replace Schmeichel due to the poor goals against ratio.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20110627/schmeichel-completes-foxes-switch_2247585_2382546 |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207221229/http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20110627/schmeichel-completes-foxes-switch_2247585_2382546 |archivedate=7 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/929298/kasper-schmeichel-shock-over-possible-leicester-move?campaign=rss&source=soccernet&cc=5739 |title=Kasper Schmeichel shock over possible Leicester move |website=ESPN FC |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== ====2011–12 season==== [[File:Schmeichel vs Chelsea.jpg|thumb|200px|Schmeichel playing for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 2012]] On 27 June 2011, Schmeichel was officially confirmed as a Leicester player, signing a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee that reunited him for a second time with his former Manchester City and Notts County manager, Sven-Göran Eriksson.
In the first month of the season, Schmeichel was shown a seemingly needless red card in the 79th minute of Leicester's away game to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 20 August 2011 after receiving two yellow cards for "unsporting conduct". He received the first card for moving the ball from the penalty spot as Forest's [[Lewis McGugan]] was about to take a kick, then received his second for throwing the ball away after the spot kick was successfully converted. After the match, Schmeichel apologized, claiming his back was turned to the referee so did not know he had received the first of the yellow cards. "I didn't know I had been booked as I had my back to the ref otherwise I would never have done that," he said on his personal [[Twitter]] page.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/14514759.stm Nottingham Forest v Leicester City match report.] BBC Sport. Retrieved 20 August 2011.</ref><ref>[http://socqer.com/questions/887/why-was-kasper-schmeichel-sent-off-playing-for-leicester-city-against-nottingham-forest-in-august-2011/ Why was Kasper Schmeichel sent off playing for Leicester City against Nottingham Forest in August 2011?] Socqer.com. Retrieved 20 August 2011.</ref> Despite this, Schmeichel's performances for Leicester quickly began earning him plaudits, with his then manager Sven-Göran Eriksson comparing him with [[England national football team|England]] number 1 goalkeeper Joe Hart,<ref name="Kasper Schmeichel as good as Hart - Sven-Goran Eriksson">{{cite news |title=Kasper Schmeichel as good as Hart – Sven-Goran Eriksson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15006682.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2011 |accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> and teammate and former England international [[Paul Konchesky]] describing him as "one of the best [goalkeepers] he has ever played with".<ref>{{cite news |title=Konchesky hails in-form Leicester City goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Konchesky-hails-form-Leicester-City-goalkeeper/story-14019188-detail/story.html |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210214914/https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Konchesky-hails-form-Leicester-City-goalkeeper/story-14019188-detail/story.html |archivedate=10 December 2013}}</ref> A short-distant reaction save against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in November 2011, in particular, earnt Schmeichel praise and was described by Portsmouth manager [[Michael Appleton]] as "one of the best saves I have seen in a very long time".<ref>{{cite news |title=Portsmouth 1–1 Leicester: Sunday Mirror match report |url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Portsmouth-1-1-Leicester-City-David-Nugent-haunts-old-club-as-he-grabs-the-equaliser-article835365.html |newspaper=Daily Mirror |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> and by Leicester manager [[Nigel Pearson]] as "a world-class, outstanding save and was very important at that point of the game".<ref>{{cite news |title=We must do better, says Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/better-says-Leicester-City-boss-Nigel-Pearson/story-13978179-detail/story.html |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210215733/https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/better-says-Leicester-City-boss-Nigel-Pearson/story-13978179-detail/story.html |archivedate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
Schmeichel played a total of 52 games overall, making 17 clean sheets and saving four penalties. His performances in the [[2011–12 Leicester City F.C. season|2011–12 season]] earned him the club's Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year awards on 30 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2755427,00.html |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805050551/https://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2755427%2C00.html |archivedate=5 August 2012 |title=Schmeichel Crowned Player of the Year |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=30 April 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== Schmeichel's form in the first half of the [[2012–13 Leicester City F.C. season|2012–13 season]] surpassed that of the previous season, keeping 12 clean sheets in 28 games, the most in the league as the Foxes sat second in the table, such performances earning him links with [[La Liga]] giants [[Real Madrid C.F|Real Madrid]] and also leading to his first senior [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] cap. A particular highlight was a spectacular save against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in February. On 16 April 2013, he made his 100th Leicester appearance in a 3–2 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]]. Schmeichel's performances earned him a place in the 2012–13 Championship PFA Team of the Year, alongside club captain [[Wes Morgan]].
====2013–14 season==== During the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14 season]], Schmeichel kept nine clean sheets during a 19-game unbeaten run spanning from December to April to help guarantee Leicester promotion from the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] with six games to spare. Schmeichel's high quality performances once again lead to him being courted by some of world football's giants, with both Manchester United and [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] being linked with moves for the Danish international during the January transfer window.
In March, TV footage<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.101greatgoals.com/blog/leicester-keeper-kasper-schmeichel-should-have-been-awarded-injury-time-goal-v-yeovil-header-crossed-the-line-vine/ |date=25 March 2014 |title=Leicester keeper Kasper Schmeichel scores injury time header Yeovil! [Vine]}}</ref> appeared to support Schmeichel's claim that he had scored what would have been the first goal of his career, when Leicester equalised, in injury time, against [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]]. However, the match officials ruled that his header had not crossed the line and the goal was officially credited<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/294725.html |date=26 March 2014 |title=Spoilsports! League deny Schmeichel goal}}</ref> to [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]], who followed up to put the ball in the net.
At the end of the [[2013–14 Leicester City F.C. season|2013–14 season]], it was announced that Schmeichel had signed a four-year contract extension until the summer of 2018 with Leicester.<ref name="contract">{{cite web |title=Schmeichel Signs New Leicester City Deal |url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/article/040614-schmeichel-signs-new-leicester-city-deal-1602227.aspx |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== Schmeichel remained the first choice goalkeeper for Leicester's return to the Premier League, including playing the full 90 minutes in the 5–3 victory against Manchester United on 21 September 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester 5:3 Man Utd |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29196081 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> In December 2014, Schmeichel suffered a broken [[metatarsal]] in training, ruling the Dane out for at least a month.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kasper Schmeichel OUT for at least a month after Leicester City goalkeeper suffers broken metatarsal in training |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2870219/Kasper-Schmeichel-month-Leicester-City-goalkeeper-suffers-broken-metatarsal-training.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> While he was out, Leicester signed goalkeeper [[Mark Schwarzer]] as a replacement. Schmeichel eventually returned from injury on 21 March 2015, and beat Schwarzer to play in the 4–3 defeat to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Tottenham Hotspur 4–3 Leicester City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31883462 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> Clean sheets against Swansea City and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] as Leicester won four out of five games in April earned Schmeichel a nomination for the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] award.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City's Jamie Vardy and Kasper Schmeichel nominated for Premier League player of the month |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-s-Jamie-Vardy-Kasper-Schmeichel/story-26457220-detail/story.html |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |accessdate=10 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518093041/https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-s-Jamie-Vardy-Kasper-Schmeichel/story-26457220-detail/story.html |archivedate=18 May 2015}}</ref> After securing Premier League safety following a goalless draw with [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 16 May, Schmeichel stated his belief that manager Nigel Pearson should win [[Premier League Manager of the Season|Manager of the Season]] and that Pearson is the best manager Schmeichel has played for.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester's Nigel Pearson should be manager of year, says Schmeichel |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/may/17/sunderland-leicester-city-nigel-pearson-premier-league-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> Pearson, however, was sacked in the off-season.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33338638 |title=Nigel Pearson: Leicester City sack manager |date=30 June 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:Kasper Schmeichel 2016.jpg|thumb|Schmeichel in a league match against Chelsea at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] on 15 May 2016]]
Under Pearson's replacement, [[Claudio Ranieri]], Leicester sat top of the table on Christmas Day.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/english-soccer/jamie-vardy-claims-10th-goal-of-season-as-leicester-s-fine-start-rolls-on-1.2405100 |title=Jamie Vardy claims 10th goal of season as Leicester's fine start rolls on |date=24 October 2015 |newspaper=The Irish Times |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> Despite their great start, the team did not keep a clean sheet in their first nine games, prompting Ranieri to offer to buy the squad pizza for their first.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9994945/leicester-boss-claudio-ranieri-offers-players-pizza-for-a-clean-sheet |title=Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri offers players pizza for a clean sheet |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> The team finally managed their first clean sheet of the season in their tenth game, against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=37210 |title=Kasper Schmeichel – Football Stats – Leicester City – Age 29 – Soccer Base |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> The team improved defensively, and Schmeichel kept his 12th clean sheet of the season in the reverse fixture against Palace on 19 March.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35792249 |title=Crystal Palace 0–1 Leicester City |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> On 2 May 2016, he won the Premier League title at 29 years of age, the same age and same calendar day when his father won Manchester United's first such title in 1993. On both occasions, the respective teams ([[1992–93 Manchester United F.C. season|Manchester United]] and [[2015–16 Leicester City F.C. season|Leicester City]]) clinched the titles by nearest rivals (Aston Villa and Tottenham Hotspur) not winning.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/veitchyonsport/photos/a.209680292402024.47624.203262656377121/1034246246612087/?type=3&theater&notif_t=notify_me_page&notif_id=1462233279363009 |title=Like father, like son.. Another wee factoid to add to the Foxes story. – Veitchy on Sport {{!}} Facebook, as cited from Peter Schmeichel's Twitter account.|website=www.facebook.com|accessdate=3 May 2016}}{{Primary source inline|date=January 2018}}</ref> The Schmeichels became the only biological father and son to win the Premier League, as well as being in the same position to do so.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City: The ridiculous statistics |url=http://www.football365.com/news/leicester-city-the-ridiculous-statistics |accessdate=3 May 2016 |publisher=Football 365 |date=3 May 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== Despite rumors of a move away after playing a crucial role in Leicester City's title in the 2015–16 season, on 6 August 2016, Schmeichel signed a new five-year contract until 2021.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/article/2016-17/new-leicester-city-deal-for-kasper-schmeichel-3228343.aspx |title=New Leicester City Deal For Kasper Schmeichel |date=6 August 2016}}</ref> Schmeichel made his first appearance of the season in [[FA Community Shield]] against FA Cup winners, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], the match ended in a 2–1 defeat for the reigning champions.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36934956 |title=Jose Mourinho began his reign as Manchester United manager with a trophy |date=7 August 2016}}</ref> On the opening of the Premier League, Schmeichel continue his role in the goal ahead of new signing, [[Ron-Robert Zieler]] against newly promoted [[Hull City F.C.|Hull City]]. Schmeichel was beaten twice as Hull City went on to beat the champions 2–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36994520 |title=Hull City 2–1 Leicester City: Champions starts the season was a loss |date=14 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> After missing three games in September, including a midweek [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], with a minor groin injury,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/1865483/leicester-vs-porto-kasper-schmeichel-returns-in-goal-as-jamie-vardy-partners-islam-slimani-in-attack/ |title=Kasper Schmeichel returns in goal as Jamie Vardy partners Islam Slimani in attack |newspaper=The Sun |first=Richard |last=Forrester |date=27 September 2016}}</ref> Schmeichel sustained a hand fracture in the first half of a [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] match at [[F.C. Copenhagen]] on 2 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/03/kasper-schmeichel-fractured-hand-out-month |title=Leicester's Kasper Schmeichel set for a month out with fractured hand |newspaper=The Guardian |first=Stuart |last=James |date=3 November 2016}}</ref> Despite the injury, Schmeichel finished the game, seeing out a 0–0 draw by making a late save of [[Andreas Cornelius]] for his fourth Champions League clean sheet in four matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/02/fc-copenhagen-leicester-city-champions-league-match-report |title=Leicester City step closer to qualification with draw in Copenhagen |newspaper=The Guardian |first=Stuart |last=James |date=2 November 2016}}</ref> After undergoing surgery two days later, Schmeichel was expected to miss six weeks of action, with Zieler taking his place in goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10644223/leicester-keeper-kasper-schmeichel-undergoes-surgery |title=Leicester keeper Kasper Schmeichel undergoes surgery on fractured hand |publisher=Sky Sports |first=Peter |last=Gilbert |date=4 November 2016}}</ref>
On 24 February 2017, reports emerged alleging that Schmeichel was among several teammates who met with chairman [[Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha]] following their 2–1 Champions League defeat at Sevilla on 22 February,<ref name="Sevilla 2-1 Leicester">{{cite news |title = Sevilla 2–1 Leicester|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39043648|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Phil Dawkes|date = 22 February 2017|accessdate = 21 October 2017}}</ref> which led to manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] being sacked. Schmeichel denied the claims, describing them as "very hurtful".<ref name="I have no problem with Ranieri - Schmeichel">{{cite news |title = I have no problem with Ranieri – Schmeichel|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39090834|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 25 February 2017|accessdate = 21 October 2017}}</ref>
In Leicester's [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|first Champions League campaign]], Schmeichel saved a penalty in each leg of the last 16 tie with [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] – from [[Joaquín Correa]] and [[Steven Nzonzi]] respectively – as the Foxes advanced 3–2 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ronay |first1=Barney |title=Kasper Schmeichel's Champions League brilliance confirms his rise to the elite |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/mar/15/kasper-schmeichel-champions-league-leicester-steven-nzonzi |accessdate=15 March 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=15 March 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== On 26 August 2017, Schmeichel saved a [[Romelu Lukaku]] penalty away at Manchester United in the 53rd minute, with the score at 0–0. Leicester would go onto lose the game 2–0.<ref>{{cite web |title=Manchester United vs. Leicester City 2–0 |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2017/08/26/england/premier-league/manchester-united-fc/leicester-city-fc/2462819/ |accessdate=28 October 2018 |website=Soccerway}}</ref> On 31 March 2018, Schmeichel saved a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]] in a 2–0 away win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]], the same number his father saved during his time in the competition (three out of 21 Premier League penalties saved).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43524302 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 0–2 Leicester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2018}}</ref> On 14 April 2018, Schmeichel suffered an ankle injury in the 86th minute in a 2–1 home loss against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], resulting in Schmeichel missing Leicester's final five games of the [[2017–18 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/kasper-schmeichel-huge-doubt-southampton-1468218 |title=Kasper Schmeichel a huge doubt for Southampton clash |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=17 April 2018 |accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== Schmeichel witnessed the [[2018 Leicester City F.C. helicopter crash|helicopter crash]] on 27 October 2018 that killed five people including Leicester owner [[Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mannion |first1=Damian |title=Kasper Schmeichel ‘saw some terrible things’ Leicester manager Claude Puel says in emotional press conference |url=https://talksport.com/football/440877/leicester-helicopter-crash-schmeichel-police/ |publisher=Talksport |date=2 November 2018 |accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== While at Manchester City, Schmeichel was called up for the [[Denmark national under-19 football team|Denmark national under-19 team]] in August 2004,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=24311 |title=Schmeichel på U/19-landsholdet |publisher=Danish Football Association |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> and made his international debut in a 0–0 draw with [[Northern Ireland national under-19 football team|Northern Ireland]] on 2 September 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=24780 |title=God debut til Schmeichel |publisher=Danish Football Association |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> He went on to play eight under-19 internationals until March 2005, competing with [[Kenneth Stenild]] and [[Michael Tørnes]] for the goalkeeping spot. He was called up for the [[Denmark national under-20 football team|under-20]] team in October 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=38719 |title=Schmeichel på U/20 –landsholdet |publisher=Danish Football Association |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> but did not play for the team until October 2006, during his time at Bury.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=234918 |title=Unødvendigt nederlag mod Norge |publisher=Danish Football Association |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> The day after his under-20 debut, Schmeichel was asked to train with the senior [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] team and was called up as a replacement for injured [[Theis Rasmussen]] in the [[Denmark national under-21 football team|under-21]] squad.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=234938 |title=Rommedahl ude, Krohn-Dehli inde |publisher=Danish Football Association |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
Schmeichel was one of the leading players in the team, and was named [[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish under-21 Talent of the Year]] in November 2007, following three clean sheets in the previous four under-21 games.<ref name="arla"/> He played a total 17 under-21 internationals in a row from March 2007 to October 2008, racking up seven clean sheets.
===Senior=== Following his strong showings for Manchester City in the early [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]], it was reported on 23 August 2007 that [[The Football Association]] (FA) were investigating Schmeichel's international status, to see if there was any chance of him foregoing his Danish international status in order to play for [[England national football team|England]].<ref>{{cite news |title=FA woo Kasper |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/fa-woo-kasper-714795 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |date=23 August 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> Schmeichel, however, stated that he would only ever play for Denmark.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nikolaj |last=Worm |title=England kan glemme alt om Schmeichel |url=http://jyllands-posten.dk/sport/fodbold/article1055767.ece |newspaper=Jyllands-Posten |date=23 August 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
Schmeichel was called up to the Danish senior team on 13 May 2011 for the first time for the match against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]], but remained an unused substitute.<ref name="translate.google.co.uk"/> On 29 May 2012, he was called up for [[UEFA Euro 2012]] as a third goalkeeper after it became clear that [[Thomas Sørensen]] would miss the tournament due to an injury sustained against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Thomas-Soerensen-ude-af-EM |title=Thomas Sørensen ude af EM |website=bold.dk |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> Schmeichel made his senior debut in a 3–0 friendly match defeat to [[Macedonia national football team|Macedonia]] at the [[Philip II Arena]] on 6 February 2013.<ref name="Macedonia 3 - 0 Denmark">{{citation |title=Macedonia 3 – 0 Denmark |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/international-friendlies/2013/macedonia-denmark-587659.html |publisher=Yahoo Eurosport UK |date=6 February 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref>
On 15 October 2013, Schmeichel had his first ever senior level game in his native Denmark, when he held an easy clean sheet in Denmark's 6–0 win against [[Malta national football team|Malta]] in the last [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group B|2014 FIFA World Cup qualifier]]. Denmark were eventually runners-up in the group, finishing six points behind [[Italy national football team|Italy]], but they did not progress to the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Second Round|play-offs]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|finals]] as they were the lowest-ranked team of the nine runners-up.<ref>{{cite news |title=Young Denmark put six past Malta |url=http://www.uefa.com/worldcup/season=2014/matches/round=2000294/match=2008563/index.html |publisher=UEFA |date=15 October 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref>
On 5 March 2014, Schmeichel received his third cap for Denmark in their 1–0 friendly defeat against England at [[Wembley Stadium]]. Despite defeat, Schmeichel pulled off a string of impressive saves earning plaudits from the media as well as England manager [[Roy Hodgson]].
Schmeichel was selected for the Danish squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], where he started in three group stage matches. His clean sheet in the opening match contributed to a [[Player of the match|Man of the Match]] award and helped Schmeichel set a new record for minutes without conceding a goal for Denmark, surpassing his father's record.<ref>{{cite news |last=Kelner |first=Martha |date=20 June 2018 |title=Kasper Schmeichel breaks dad’s Denmark record but puts wins first |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/20/kasper-schmeichel-denmark-australia |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Martel |first=Brett |date=16 June 2018 |title=Schmeichel, Poulsen lift Denmark past Peru 1–0 |url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/worldcup/2018/06/16/schmeichel-poulsen-lift-denmark-past-peru-1-0.html |newspaper=The Star |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> During the [[2018 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Denmark vs Croatia|Round of 16]] match against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], Schmeichel was named Man of the Match after saving a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty-kick]] taken by [[Luka Modrić]] in [[Overtime (sports)|extra-time]] and two penalties during the subsequent [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|shootout]], although his opposing counterpart [[Danijel Subašić]] saved three penalties in that shootout to eliminate Denmark.<ref>{{cite news |date=1 July 2018 |title=Croatia 1–1 Denmark |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/jul/01/croatia-v-denmark-world-cup-2018-live?page=with:block-5b393c94e4b0c089ab2b8901#block-5b393c94e4b0c089ab2b8901 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/schmeichel-s-hat-trick-not-enough |title=Schmeichel's hat-trick not enough |publisher=FIFA |access-date=1 July 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Schmeichel is the son of former Denmark international goalkeeper [[Peter Schmeichel]]. Having spent most of his childhood living in England due to his father's playing career, Kasper is a [[first language|native speaker]] of both Danish and English, the latter of which he speaks with a [[English language in Northern England|Northern-English]] accent. He attended [[Hulme Hall Grammar School]] in Cheadle Hulme, Stockport, Greater Manchester, and he also attended [[Saint Julian's School]] in Portugal while his father played for [[Sporting CP]] in [[Lisbon]]. When [[Alex Bruce (footballer, born 1984)|Alex Bruce]], son of Kasper's father's former Manchester United teammate [[Steve Bruce]], joined Kasper at Leeds United, the move saw the two players re-unite after both had previously played football together on the streets as children after school.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-475821/EXCLUSIVE-Peters-proud-son-Kasper-keeping-family-tradition-alive.html |location=London |newspaper=Daily Mail |title=EXCLUSIVE: Peter's so proud son Kasper is keeping family tradition alive |date=17 August 2007}}</ref>
Schmeichel has two children: a son, Max (born 2010) and a daughter, Isabella (born 2012).<ref>{{Cite news |title=A great 2012, but this year could be even better for Leicester City goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/great-2012-year-better-Leicester-City-goalkeeper/story-17767985-detail/story.html |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=17 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217231803/https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/great-2012-year-better-Leicester-City-goalkeeper/story-17767985-detail/story.html |archivedate=17 December 2013 }}</ref>
Schmeichel signed an ambassadorial deal with Precision Goalkeeping on 17 August 2010 which will include the release of the "Schmeichology" Goalkeeping Range.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100816/kasper-launches-precision-range_2247585_2125194 |title=News | Leeds |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211201640/http://origin-www.leedsunited.com/news/20100816/kasper-launches-precision-range_2247585_2125194 |archivedate=11 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>

club-update = 21:33, 16 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Daniel Peter Simpson''' (born 4 January 1987) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[right back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].
A product of the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] academy, during his development Simpson played on loan for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in England, and [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]] in Belgium. He was on loan at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for six months before signing for them on a permanent basis in January 2010, and after four years joined [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on a free transfer in June 2013 for a year, before joining Leicester City the following season.
==Career== ===Manchester United=== Simpson was born in [[Eccles, Greater Manchester|Eccles]], [[Greater Manchester]],<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> to a Jamaican father and English mother.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sport/JFF-nets-eight---Beckford--McAnuff-among-recruits-from-UK-trip_13066699 |title=JFF nets eight – Beckford, McAnuff among recruits from UK trip |first=Jamaica Observer |last=Limited |website=Jamaica Observer}}</ref> Simpson played for Parkwyddn JFC in [[Eccles, Greater Manchester|Eccles]] as a youth before being picked up by [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. He is a product of the [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester United youth system]], having come up through the ranks into the reserve squad in 2005.
Simpson made his debut against South African team [[Kaizer Chiefs FC|Kaizer Chiefs]] on 18 July 2006, which the Reds won 1–0.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kaizer Chiefs 0–1 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_utd/5193126.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> Manager Alex Ferguson claimed that Simpson looked "anything but a player making his first start for Manchester United".{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
====Royal Antwerp (loan)==== In early January 2006, he was sent on loan, along with three other United youths, to the [[Belgian Second Division]] club [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]] for the remainder of the season, to gain match experience.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=Another United loanee |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11667_2362508,00.html |work=Sky Sports |publisher=BSkyB |date=7 January 2006 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> Simpson also spent the first half of the 2006–07 season at Antwerp before returning to United in January 2007.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Youngsters join Antwerp |url=http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid={B4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70}&newsid=355888 |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=18 August 2006 |accessdate=10 November 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918045750/http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid=%7BB4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70%7D&newsid=355888 |archive-date=18 September 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Sunderland (loan)==== On 25 January 2007, he joined [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on loan for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sunderland sign Simpson on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/6300117.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 January 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> The loan move saw him link up with fellow Manchester United player [[Jonny Evans]]. He won the Championship title with Sunderland that season.
====Return to Manchester United==== Simpson returned to United at the start of the [[2007–08 Manchester United F.C. season|2007–08 season]] and signed a new contract in September 2007 that would keep him at the club until 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd hand new deal to Simpson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_utd/6979964.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 September 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> He made his first competitive appearance for United on 26 September 2007 in the 2–0 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] loss to [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd 0–2 Coventry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7008020.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> and soon after made his [[Premier League]] debut on 6 October 2007 against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at [[Old Trafford]], coming on as a 30th-minute [[substitute (football)|substitute]] for the injured [[John O'Shea]]. He set up the fourth goal with a well flighted cross for [[Wayne Rooney]]. The match ended with a 4–0 win to United.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Sinnott |title=Man Utd 4–0 Wigan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7019619.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 October 2007 |accessdate=6 October 2007}}</ref> His European debut came on 23 October 2007, when he came on as an 80th-minute substitute for [[Ryan Giggs]] against [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |title=Dynamo Kiev 2–4 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7054215.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 October 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> His first European start was in the reverse fixture against Dynamo Kyiv on 7 November 2007; United won the game 4–0.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Man Utd 4–0 Dynamo Kiev |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7076590.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 November 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref>
====Ipswich Town (loan)==== On 21 March 2008, Simpson signed a loan deal with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. With [[Gary Neville]] on the verge of returning to the Manchester United first team, United manager [[Alex Ferguson]] decided it was best for Simpson to get as much first team football as possible, something that would be quite hard to come by at Old Trafford with both Gary Neville and [[Wes Brown]] ahead of Simpson in the pecking order.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Bostock |title=Simpson out as Nev nears return |url=http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid={B4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70}&newsid=543149 |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=21 March 2008 |accessdate=21 March 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080324124052/http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid=%7BB4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70%7D&newsid=543149 |archive-date=24 March 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Blackburn Rovers (loan)==== On 4 August 2008, Simpson signed for [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on a season-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Simmo joins Rovers on loan |url=http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid={B4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70}&newsid=6615332 |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=4 September 2008 |accessdate=4 September 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014201455/http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid=%7BB4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70%7D&newsid=6615332 |archive-date=14 October 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn sign Man Utd's Simpson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/blackburn_rovers/7541677.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 August 2008 |accessdate=4 August 2008}}</ref> Simpson made his Blackburn debut on 27 August 2008, playing in Rovers' 4–1 win over [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] Second Round.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn 4–1 Grimsby |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7576508.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 August 2008 |accessdate=28 August 2008}}</ref> His Premier League debut for Blackburn Rovers came almost three weeks later, on 13 September 2008, in a 4–0 defeat at home to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Lyon |title=Blackburn 0–4 Arsenal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7601879.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2008 |accessdate=13 September 2008}}</ref> With the exception of Blackburn's League Cup Fifth Round defeat by Manchester United, which he was forced to miss because of a clause in his loan agreement, Simpson was ever-present for Blackburn during their League Cup and FA Cup campaigns. He also played in 11 out of the 14 league matches for which he was eligible prior to Christmas 2008, although he was named on the bench for the other three. After Christmas, Simpson only played in one further league match, another 4–0 defeat to Arsenal,<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Hughes |title=Arsenal 4–0 Blackburn |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7944245.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 March 2009 |accessdate=28 April 2009}}</ref> and in early May 2009, with his first team opportunities limited at Blackburn, the loan agreement was terminated early and he returned to train with Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Burton |title=Home form gives Sam hope |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_5299066,00.html |work=Sky Sports |publisher=BSkyB |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2009}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== [[File:Danny Simpson - 2009.jpg|thumb|upright|Simpson playing for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 2009]]
On 14 August 2009, Simpson joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on loan until January 2010,<ref>{{cite news |title=Simpson makes Magpies loan switch |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/8201408.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2009}}</ref> making his debut in a 1–0 victory over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] at St. James' Park. He scored his first goal for Newcastle against Peterborough United on 7 November 2009.
Following the completion of the loan deal, Newcastle made a bid to keep Simpson on a permanent basis. An undisclosed fee, reported as being in the region of £750,000,<ref>{{cite news |title=Everton keen on loan move for Arsenal's Philippe Senderos |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/article6995850.ece |work=The Times |date=21 January 2010 |accessdate=21 January 2010 |location=London |first1=Gary |last1=Jacob |first2=Tony |last2=Barrett |first3=George |last3=Caulkin}}</ref> was agreed between Newcastle and Manchester United and Simpson signed a three-and-a-half-year contract on 20 January 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Newcastle sign Manchester United defender Danny Simpson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/8469941.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=21 January 2010}}</ref>
He played a solid part in Newcastle's promotion to the Premier League, winning his second Championship title in the process, while forming a right flank partnership with January signing [[Wayne Routledge]]. Towards the end of the season, he "played through the pain" with what he considered a small ankle injury. He only realised the full extent of the ankle injury at the end of the season, and he had an operation to correct it. He was out for three months, including the first month or so of Newcastle's season.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mark Douglas |url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/danny-simpson-reveals-full-injury-1416407 |title=Danny Simpson reveals his full injury blow |publisher=Chronicle Live |date=24 June 2010 |accessdate=23 June 2013}}</ref> Simpson returned to action from his injury lay off, playing two reserve games in October. He made his first start of the new season in Newcastle's 2–1 victory over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], replacing [[James Perch]] at right back. Simpson kept his right-back spot with consistently strong performances, forming a strong partnership with [[Joey Barton]] on the right flank.
On 20 September 2011, Simpson scored a curler in Newcastle's 4–3 win over [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the third round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].
On 10 December 2011, Simpson started alongside [[James Perch]] at center back in place of the injured [[Steven Taylor (footballer)|Steven Taylor]] and [[Fabricio Coloccini]] for Newcastle's 4–2 defeat at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]. He had played at right back for the beginning of the season.
On 4 January 2012, Simpson started for Newcastle during their 3–0 win against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], and produced a fantastic saving clearance off the line against his old club on his 25th birthday.
===Queens Park Rangers=== After his contract with Newcastle expired at the end of the 2012–13 season, Simpson signed a three-year deal with Championship club [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 27 June 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Exclusive: Simpson Signs |url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/news/article/270613-exclusive-simpson-signs-882907.aspx |publisher=Queens Park Rangers F.C. |accessdate=28 June 2013 |date=27 June 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for QPR in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on 6 August 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Exeter 0–2 QPR |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23499499 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 August 2013 |accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> He made 36 Championship appearances for QPR as they earned promotion via [[2015 Football League play-offs|the play-offs]].{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
===Leicester City=== [[File:Danny Simpson LCFC.jpg|thumb|Simpson and his daughter celebrating Leicester's title win on 7 May 2016]] On 30 August 2014 signed a three-year contract for fellow promoted team [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for an undisclosed fee.<ref name="simpson_leicester">{{cite news |title=Danny Simpson joins Leicester City from QPR on three-year deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28998920 |accessdate=21 May 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 August 2014}}</ref> Simpson made his Leicester debut in a 2–0 defeat against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] off the bench on 27 September 2014. However, he didn't make his second appearance for the club until 7 December against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], as he often struggled to get into the side ahead of regular right back [[Ritchie De Laet]]. Simpson made 14 appearances overall for Leicester in the 2014–15 season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Danny Simpson |url=http://www.foxestalk.co.uk/forums/history/players?pid=1541 |website=FoxesTalk – History |accessdate=12 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024090438/http://www.foxestalk.co.uk/forums/history/players?pid=1541 |archivedate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
In the 2015–16 season, under the new management of [[Claudio Ranieri]], De Laet was again preferred ahead of Simpson to begin with. However, following a 5–2 defeat by [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], Ranieri changed his full backs bringing Simpson in for De Laet helping to shore up Leicester's defence, as Simpson was considered a much more defensive full-back than De Laet and "rarely ventured forward".<ref>{{cite web |title=How Claudio Ranieri's tactics put his rivals to shame at Leicester City |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/04/30/how-claudio-ranieris-tactics-put-his-rivals-to-shame-at-leiceste/ |last=Gill |first=JJ |date=30 April 2016 |website=The Telegraph |accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref> Simpson became a regular for the rest of the season, though was sent-off in the return fixture against Arsenal as Leicester went down to a late 2–1 defeat,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515144 |title=Arsenal 2–1 Leicester |date=14 February 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> but the Foxes held on to win their first ever Premier League title.
==Personal life== Simpson has a daughter, who was born six weeks prematurely in mid-2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/danny-simpson-reaching-skye-after-1402352 |location=Newcastle |work=Evening Chronicle |first=Lee |last=Ryder |title=Danny Simpson reaching for Skye after birth |date=3 August 2011}}</ref>
On 20 May 2015, Simpson was found guilty of assaulting his then-girlfriend and mother of his child Stephanie Ward on 28 December 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title=Danny Simpson convicted of assaulting ex-girlfriend |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32820683 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 May 2015 |accessdate=20 May 2015}}</ref> He was sentenced to 300 hours of community service.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33154782 |title=Danny Simpson to face Leicester hearing after assault sentence |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 June 2015 |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> On 12 May 2016, his sentence was reviewed in light of press-intrusion into his community service, and replaced with a 22:00 to 06:00 curfew for 21 days.<ref name=BBC36276824>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-36276824 |title=Leicester City's Danny Simpson spared community service due to press intrusion |date=12 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
