Reserves and Academy|Manchester City]] | youthyears3 = 2014–2015 | years1 = 2015–2017 | clubs1 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | caps1 = 46 | goals1 = 12 | years2 = 2017– | clubs2 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps2 = 44 | goals2 = 4 | nationalyears1 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[Nigeria national under-17 football team|Nigeria U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 8 | nationalyears2 = 2015–2017 | nationalteam2 = [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria U20]] | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2015– | nationalteam3 = [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] | nationalcaps3 = 23 | nationalgoals3 = 8 | club-update = 19:31, 23 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:21, 20 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Kelechi Promise Iheanacho''' ({{IPA-ig|ɪ̙ɦeanãtʃɔ̙|lang}};{{Fix|text=needs tone}} born 3 October 1996) is a Nigerian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for {{English football updater|LeicestC}} club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria national team]]. He has made appearances for Manchester City,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/4110/nigerians-abroad/2015/05/23/12011122/kelechi-iheanacho-scores-brace-in-manchester-united-u21 |title=Kelechi Iheanacho scores brace in Manchester United U21 defeat |work=Goal.com}}</ref> as well as the Nigeria squad that won the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] and the [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria U-20]] team at the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://leadership.ng/sports/436808/u-20-world-cup-beginning-of-great-things-for-iheanacho-father |title=U-20 World Cup Beginning of Great Things For Iheanacho – Father |author=Leadership Newspaper |date=29 May 2015 |work=Nigerian News from Leadership News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618064247/http://leadership.ng/sports/436808/u-20-world-cup-beginning-of-great-things-for-iheanacho-father |archivedate=18 June 2015 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/11242/nigeria-u20/2015/05/26/12100202/kelechi-iheanacho-arrives-new-zealand-for-u20-world-cup |title=Kelechi Iheanacho arrive in New Zealand for U20 World Cup |work=Goal.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529063102/http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/11242/nigeria-u20/2015/05/26/12100202/kelechi-iheanacho-arrives-new-zealand-for-u20-world-cup |archivedate=29 May 2015 |df=}}</ref> Iheanacho was called up to the Manchester City senior squad for the [[2015–16 Manchester City F.C. season|2015–16 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.starafrica.com/football/iheanacho-in-citys-first-team-squad-next-season.html |title=Iheanacho in City's first team squad next season |work=Football |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618052508/http://en.starafrica.com/football/iheanacho-in-citys-first-team-squad-next-season.html |archivedate=18 June 2015 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2488104-why-kelechi-iheanacho-will-be-the-next-star-to-come-through-man-citys-academy |title=Why Kelechi Iheanacho Will Be the Next Star to Come Through Man City's Academy |author=Rob Pollard |work=Bleacher Report}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Manchester City=== ====Early career==== Iheanacho was born in the state of [[Imo State|Imo]].<ref name=BDFutbol/> As a youth, he represented Taye Academy in [[Owerri]], the capital city of Imo. His performances for Nigeria in the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] led to interest from clubs in Europe; teams following his progress included [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/arsenal-iheanacho-nigeria-world-cup-wenger-rowley-521299 |title=Nigeria win Under-17 World Cup |work=International Business Times |author=Adrian Back |date=11 November 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]] and [[FC Porto|Porto]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://talksport.com/football/man-city-set-miss-out-nigerian-wonderkid-13123173775 |title=Man City set to miss out on Nigerian wonderkid |work=Talksport |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> In December 2012, Iheanacho travelled to England to discuss a move to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. He signed a pre-contract agreement with the club, stating his intent to formally sign for City on his 18th birthday in October 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11679/9109769/transfer-news-manchester-city-deal-for-kelechi-iheanacho-claimed |title=Transfer news: Manchester City deal for Kelechi Iheanacho claimed |work=Sky Sports |date=10 January 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> In the interim, he returned to Nigeria. As the year drew to a close, the [[Confederation of African Football]] (CAF) named him the Most Promising Talent of the Year for 2013 at the [[CAF Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cafonline.com/en-US/NewsCenter/News/NewsDetails?id=%2FR3WaZKROVJ6wGZ8srjnDQ%3D%3D |title=Iheanacho named most promising talent |work=Confederation of African Football |date=9 January 2014 |accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
Iheanacho joined [[Manchester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester City's Academy]] on 10 January 2014. Before the [[2014–15 Manchester City F.C. season|2014–15 season]], City visited the United States on a pre-season tour, and although still not formally a City player, he joined up with the squad. He played and scored in the first match of the tour, a 4–1 win against [[Sporting Kansas City]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/manchester-city-profile-kelechi-iheanacho-7510799 |title=City profile: Kelechi Iheanacho |work=Manchester Evening News |author=Paul Handler |date=26 July 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> and scored again against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] in a 5–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/jovetic-strikes-twice-nigerias-kelechi-iheanacho-nets-and-man-city-thump-ac-milan |title=Jovetic strikes twice, Nigeria's Kelechi Iheanacho nets and Man City thump AC Milan |work=The National |date=28 July 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> After the conclusion of the tour, Manchester City arranged for Iheanacho to train with the [[Columbus Crew]] until mid-October.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/blogs/covering-the-crew/2014/09/man-city.html |title=Young Manchester City Striker Kelechi Iheanacho Training With Crew |work=Columbus Dispatch |author=Adam Jardy |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref>
Delays in obtaining a work permit meant Iheanacho was unable to play in England until February 2015. He made his debut at under-19 level in a [[UEFA Youth League]] match against [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]], but sustained an injury after only 11 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sl10.ng/news/articles/Category/nigeria-players-abroad/manchester-city-striker-kelechi-iheanacho-starts-individual-training-after-injury-lay-off/206755 |title=Manchester City Striker Kelechi Iheanacho Starts Individual Training |work=SL10 |date=14 April 2015 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> After his recovery, he began to represent Manchester City at both youth and under-21 level in the latter part of the season. He played in the [[FA Youth Cup]] final, where he scored, but ended on the losing side after [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] claimed a 5–2 aggregate victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/27/chelsea-fa-youth-cup-manchester-city |title=Chelsea retain FA Youth Cup with victory against Manchester City |work=The Guardian |date=27 April 2015 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> The following week, he scored the only goal as Manchester City beat Porto in the final of the [[2014–15 Premier League International Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Match-reports/2015/May/City-EDS-v-Porto-International-Premier-League-Cup-final-match-report-5167 |title=Manchester City EDS v Porto: International Premier League Cup match report |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== In July 2015, Iheanacho was included in City's pre-season tour team in Australia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Tour-2015/2015/Official-Manchester-City-Tour-2015-squad-list/1436520345 |title=Man City News – Manchester City FC Transfers, Injury Updates, Match reports and Interviews |publisher=Manchester City F.C.}}</ref> On the tour, he set up the first goal for [[Raheem Sterling]] and scored the second goal in the win against [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] in the [[2015 International Champions Cup]]. He also set up Sterling for the fourth goal in City's 8–1 victory against the [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam national team]]. In City's last preseason game, against [[VfB Stuttgart]], he came on as a substitute, scoring late on in a 4–2 defeat. Due to his impressive pre-season, Iheanacho was promoted to the Manchester City senior squad.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Roma vs. Manchester City – 21 July 2015 – Soccerway |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/07/21/world/international-champions-cup/as-roma/manchester-city-football-club/2032769/ |work=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref>
On 10 August 2015, Iheanacho was included in a first-team matchday squad for the first time in a competitive fixture, however he remained an unused substitute in their 3–0 win at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in their first game of the [[Premier League]] [[2015–16 Premier League|season]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=West Brom 0–3 Man City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33754829 |accessdate=26 August 2015 |date=10 August 2015}}</ref> Nineteen days later, he made his competitive debut, replacing Raheem Sterling for the final minute of a 2–0 win against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bevan |first1=Chris |title=Man City 2–0 Watford |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025307 |accessdate=29 August 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2015}}</ref> He scored his first competitive goal on 12 September, replacing [[Wilfried Bony]] in the final minute in a match away to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and scoring the only goal of the game.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cryer |first1=Andy |title=Crystal Palace 0–1 Man City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34160754 |accessdate=12 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 September 2015}}</ref>
Iheanacho scored his first career hat-trick on 30 January 2016 against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]], also setting up City's fourth goal, scored by Raheem Sterling.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35389138 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Aston Villa 0–4 Man City |date=30 January 2016 |accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref> The following month, he was put in City's [[UEFA Champions League]] squad at the expense of the injured [[Samir Nasri]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Radamel Falcao: Chelsea striker dropped from Champions League squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35488481 |accessdate=4 February 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 February 2016}}</ref> During February, Iheanacho scored against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in a 2–1 home defeat for City.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City 1–2 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515153 |accessdate=1 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2016}}</ref>
Iheanacho's next goals came on 23 April 2016, where he scored twice against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in a 4–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City 4–0 Stoke City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36061069 |accessdate=1 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 April 2016}}</ref> He followed this up with a Champions League semi-final substitute appearance on 26 April 2016.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City 0–0 Real Madrid |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36125922 |accessdate=1 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 April 2016}}</ref> Five days later, on 1 May 2016, he scored two again, albeit in a 4–2 defeat at the hands of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Southampton 4–2 Manchester City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36122770 |accessdate=1 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 May 2016}}</ref>
<ref name="goal.com">{{Cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/4110/nigerians-abroad/2016/09/11/27404002/outrageous-kelechi-iheanacho-stat-sums-up-wonderkids-class |title=Kelechi Iheanacho stat sums up wonderkid's class |date=11 September 2016|access-date=25 September 2016}}</ref> Iheanacho ended the 2015–16 season with eight Premier League goals and had the best goals-per-minute ratio of any player averaging, a goal every 93.9 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/stats?competition=1&season=20150&category=standard&sort=3 |title=2015–16 English Premier League Player Standard Stats – Goals |publisher=Fox Sports}}</ref> In all competitions he finished with a record of 14 goals and 5 assists from 35 appearances, although he only started 11 of these games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/kelechi-iheanacho/319119/ |title=Nigeria – K. Iheanacho – Profile with news, career statistics and history |publisher=Soccerway}}</ref> His goals total also meant he ended the season as City's third-highest scorer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenigerianscout.blogspot.com/2016/07/5-reasons-why-arsenal-should-bid-20.html |title=Iheanacho Third Highest Scorer Man City |accessdate=6 August 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 10 September 2016, Iheanacho started in the [[Manchester derby]]. He recorded an assist and his first goal of the season in a 2–1 win for City.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.supersport.com/football/nigeria/news/160911/Iheanacho_pleased_with_derby_heroics |title=Iheanacho pleased with derby heroics |publisher=supersport.com |accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> Four days later, Iheanacho came off the bench to score the final goal in City's 4–0 home win in the Champions League, against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37331231 |title=Manchester City 4–0 B M'gladbach |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref> This was his first European goal for Manchester City. Three days after the 4–0 win, Iheanacho scored the second goal, also assisting the third, in City's game against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37325835 |title=Manchester City 4–0 Bournemouth |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=18 September 2016}}</ref> That goal took his tally in the Premier League to 10, allowing him to join an exclusive list of players to have scored 10 Premier League goals before the age of 20. This list includes players such as [[Wayne Rooney]], [[Ryan Giggs]], [[Nicolas Anelka]], [[Michael Owen]] and [[Romelu Lukaku]].<ref name="goal.com"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/106112 |title=Iheanacho joins select teenage club|access-date=25 September 2016}}</ref> In October 2016, Iheanacho was nominated for the [[FIFA]] Golden Boy award, which was eventually won by [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]'s midfielder [[Renato Sanches]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Previous winners of the award include teammates [[Raheem Sterling]] and [[Sergio Agüero]], and five-time [[Ballon d'Or]] winner [[Lionel Messi]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Iheanacho's next goal would come in the Champions League, against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], in a 1–1 home draw on 6 December 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38202631 |title=Manchester City 1–1 Celtic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 December 2016 |accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> Iheanacho's final goal of the season, and subsequently final goal for City, came against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]] in a 5–1 [[FA Cup]] fifth round replay win, in which Iheanacho scored the final goal of the game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39035253|title=Manchester City 5-1 Huddersfield Town|date=2017-03-01|access-date=2019-02-19|language=en-GB}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== Iheanacho was signed by Premier League club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on a five-year contract on 3 August 2017,<ref>{{Cite news |title=Leicester City Sign Striker Kelechi Iheanacho |url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/444855/leicester-city-sign-striker-kelechi-iheanacho/press-release |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=3 August 2017 |accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref> for a reported £25 million fee.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Udoh |first1=Colin |title=Kelechi Iheanacho completes £25 million Leicester switch – sources |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/story/3170320/kelechi-iheanacho-completes-25-million-leicester-switch-sources |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref> He made his debut for the club in a 4–3 defeat to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 11 August 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40822513 |title=Arsenal 4–3 Leicester City |date=11 August 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=6 September 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Leicester in an [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Leeds United]] on 24 October 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41647094 |title=Leicester 3–1 Leeds |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=24 October 2017 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> On 16 January 2018, Iheanacho became the first player in English football to be awarded a goal due to [[Video assistant referee|VAR]], as the referee deemed that the player had been incorrectly ruled offside for his second goal. The goal was Iheanacho's second in a 2–0 win over [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] in the FA Cup Third Round replay.<ref>{{cite web |first=Dom |last=Farrel |title=First VAR Goal in English Football Scored By Kelechi Iheanacho |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/first-var-goal-in-english-football-scored-by-kelechi/6361k4yblize1vs58pz0gjvew |publisher=goal.com |date=16 January 2018 |accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Kelechi Iheanacho-Nigeria.jpg|thumb|upright|Iheanacho with the [[Nigeria national football team]] in 2017]] Iheanacho has represented Nigeria at youth levels from under-13 upwards.<ref name="kickoff">{{cite web |url=http://www.kickoff.com/news/38250/the-players-representing-the-golden-eaglets-of-nigeria- |title=The players representing the Golden Eaglets of Nigeria |work=Kick Off magazine |accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> His first experience of a major international tournament was the [[2013 African U-17 Championship]] in Morocco. For Iheanacho, the highlight was a hat-trick in a win against Botswana. He dedicated his goals to his mother, who died two months before the tournament.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.supersport.com/football/african-youth-championships/news/130421/Iheanacho_dedicates_hattrick_to_late_mum |title=Iheanacho dedicates hat-trick to late mum |work=Super Sport |date=21 April 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> Nigeria reached the final of the competition, where they were defeated on penalties by the Ivory Coast.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19700453 |title=2013 African U-17 Championship |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
Iheanacho played a significant role in the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]], where he won the Golden Ball award for player of the tournament.<ref name="fifa">{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17worldcu/uae2013/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150721112316/http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17worldcu/uae2013/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 July 2015 |title=Golden Eaglets soar to fourth crown |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> Nigeria won the competition, in which Iheanacho scored six times, including once in the final, and provided seven assists.<ref name="fifa"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24874527 |title=Nigeria win Under-17 World Cup |publisher=BBC |date=8 November 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> In the run-up to the [[2014 African Nations Championship]], Iheanacho trained with the [[Nigeria national football team|senior Nigeria squad]] but was released from the squad in order to travel to England to sign with Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11679/9077596/kelechi-iheanacho-is-set-for-a-move-to-england-according-to-stephen-keshi |title=Kelechi Iheanacho is set for a move to England according to Stephen Keshi |work=Sky Sports |date=17 December 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2015}}</ref> He was part of the [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria]] squad for the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in New Zealand, and featured in two matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=372542/index.html |title=Kelechi Iheanacho |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
He was selected by [[Nigeria national under-23 football team|Nigeria]] for their 35-man provisional squad for the [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2016 Summer Olympics]], but failed to make the final 18.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36623763 |title=Kelechi Iheanacho included in Nigeria's Olympics squad |date=24 June 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016 |author=Oluwashina Okeleji |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Iheanacho made his senior debut as a substitute in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|2014 FIFA World Cup qualifying]] match against [[Swaziland national football team|Swaziland]] in which Nigeria drew 0–0.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.supersport.com/football/super-eagles/news/151113/Swaziland_hold_Eagles_to_00_draw |title=Swaziland hold Eagles to a draw |website=supersport.com/|access-date=25 April 2016}}</ref> His first start for the senior team was on 25 March 2016, a 1–1 draw with [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] in a [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifying]] match.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/match/nigeria-vs-egypt/2038209/report |title=Nigeria 1 – 1 Egypt Match report – 3/25/16 Africa Cup of Nations Qualification |website=goal.com|access-date=27 March 2016}}</ref>
Iheanacho was selected by Nigeria in friendly games against Mali and Luxembourg in May 2016. He scored in the two games, providing an assist against Luxembourg.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/match/luxembourg-vs-nigeria/2231289/report |title=Luxembourg 1 – 3 Nigeria Match report – 5/31/16 Friendlies |website=goal.com}}</ref><ref name="premiumtimesng.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/sports/football/204203-iheanacho-scores-super-eagles-beat-mali-france.html |title=Iheanacho scores as Super Eagles beat Mali in France – Premium Times Nigeria |date=27 May 2016}}</ref>
His performance in the friendly matches inspired further confidence within football circles in the nation and was invited to make his competitive debut against Egypt in an African Cup of Nations qualifying series where he provided an assist for [[Oghenekaro Etebo]] in the home game.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/match/nigeria-vs-egypt/2038209/report |title=Nigeria 1 – 1 Egypt Match report – 3/25/16 Africa Cup of Nations Qualification |website=goal.com}}</ref>
Despite the change made in the coaching personnel in August this year, he distinguished himself again as one of the most important players in the team when he scored two super goals in the two matches against Tanzania in Uyo and Zambia in Ndola.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/match/nigeria-vs-tanzania/2038215 |title=Nigeria 1 – 0 Tanzania Match report – 9/3/16 Africa Cup of Nations Qualification |website=goal.com}}</ref>
In May 2018 he was named in Nigeria’s preliminary 30 man [[Nigeria national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb |title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced? - Goal.com |publisher=}}</ref>
