Halifax Town]] | caps2 = 37 | goals2 = 26 | years3 = 2011–2012 | clubs3 = [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] | caps3 = 36 | goals3 = 31 | years4 = 2012– | clubs4 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps4 = 232 | goals4 = 94 | nationalyears1 = 2015– | nationalteam1 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps1 = 26 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | club-update = 17:17, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 21:56, 13 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Jamie Richard Vardy''' (''[[Given name#Name at birth|né]]'' '''Gill'''; born 11 January 1987)<ref name=Worrall/> is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for {{English football updater|LeicestC}} club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[England national football team|England national team]].
After being released by [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] at the age of sixteen, Vardy began his senior career with [[Stocksbridge Park Steels F.C.|Stocksbridge Park Steels]], breaking into the first team in 2007 and spending three seasons before joining [[Northern Premier League]] club [[F.C. Halifax Town]] in 2010. Scoring 25 goals in his debut season, he won the club's "Player's Player of the Year" award, then moved to [[Conference Premier]] club [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] in August 2011 for an undisclosed fee. He scored 31 league goals in his first season at his new team, winning the team's "Player of the Year" award as they won the division.
In May 2012, Vardy signed for Leicester City in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] for a [[non-League football|non-League]] record transfer fee of £1 million, and helped the team win the Championship in 2014. In the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season, he scored in eleven consecutive Premier League matches, breaking [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]]'s record, and was voted the [[Premier League Player of the Season]] and [[FWA Footballer of the Year]] as outsiders Leicester won the title. Vardy made his international debut in June 2015 and was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Early career=== [[File:Steels07.jpg|thumb|upright|Jamie Vardy with [[Stocksbridge Park Steels F.C.|Stocksbridge Park Steels]] in 2007 (back row, third from right)]]
Born in [[Sheffield]], South Yorkshire,<ref>{{Hugman|25646|accessdate=10 June 2018}}</ref> Vardy started his career with the [[Stocksbridge Park Steels F.C.|Stocksbridge Park Steels]] youth system at 16 years old after being released by [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy on Huddersfield's radar? |url=http://www.huddersfield.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=267583 |website=Vital Huddersfield |publisher=Vital Network |date=18 May 2012 |accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref> He made his way through the reserve team and into the first team making his debut under manager Gary Marrow in 2007,<ref name="Departure of Vardy">{{cite news |title=Departure of Vardy |url=http://www.looklocal.org.uk/detail.php?id=1953 |publisher=Look Local |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003195319/http://www.looklocal.org.uk/detail.php?id=1953 |archivedate=3 October 2011}}</ref> earning £30 a week at the club.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Unlikely lads Jamie Vardy and Charlie Austin share a path to England joy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/04/jamie-vardy-charlie-austin-england |accessdate=2 November 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=4 June 2015}}</ref> After impressive displays, a number of [[English Football League|Football League]] teams became interested and in 2009 he spent a week on trial with [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]].<ref name="Vardy is on trial at Crewe">{{cite news |title=Vardy is on trial at Crewe |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/vardy_is_on_trial_at_crewe_1_266496 |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=21 January 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> A move did not materialise and he later turned down a short-term contract with [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].<ref name="Halifax beat League clubs to land Vardy">{{cite news |title=Halifax beat League clubs to land Vardy |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/halifax_beat_league_clubs_to_land_vardy_1_855620 |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2010}}</ref>
In June 2010, manager [[Neil Aspin]], a long time admirer of Vardy's talents, signed him for [[F.C. Halifax Town]] for a fee of £15,000.<ref name="Halifax Town: Aspin's excited about Vardy">{{cite news |title=Halifax Town: Aspin's excited about Vardy |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/sport/halifax_town_aspin_s_excited_about_vardy_1_1948910 |newspaper=Halifax Courier |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2010}}</ref><ref name=Stand>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy's first club Stocksbridge Park Steels to name main stand after Leicester's record-breaking goal-scorer |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3337989/Jamie-Vardy-s-club-Stocksbridge-Park-Steels-main-stand-Leicester-s-record-breaking-goal-scorer.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=29 November 2015 |accessdate=1 December 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 21 August 2010 in the home match against [[Buxton F.C.|Buxton]], scoring the winning goal in a match that ended 2–1 to his new club.<ref name="Match Update">{{cite web |title=Match Update |url=http://www.halifaxafc.co.uk/page/LiveUpdates/0,,10437~2067760,00.html |publisher=F.C. Halifax Town |date=21 August 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824060239/http://www.halifaxafc.co.uk/page/LiveUpdates/0%2C%2C10437~2067760%2C00.html |archivedate=24 August 2010}}</ref> Vardy had a successful first season with "the Shaymen" finishing as the club's top goalscorer with 25 goals from 37 appearances<ref name=Halifax1011/> and being voted the Player's Player of the Season. Towards the end of the season he came close to scoring a [[hat-trick]] of hat-tricks but failed to find a third goal in Halifax's 3–1 win over [[Nantwich Town F.C.|Nantwich Town]].<ref name="Match Report">{{cite news |title=Match Report |url=http://www.halifaxafc.co.uk/page/HalifaxMatchReportDetail/0,,10437~2254664,00.html |publisher=F.C. Halifax Town |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402070546/http://www.halifaxafc.co.uk/page/HalifaxMatchReportDetail/0%2C%2C10437~2254664%2C00.html |archivedate=2 April 2011}}</ref> His goals helped secure the [[Northern Premier League]] Premier Division title for the 2010–11 season.<ref name="A Season In Stats">{{cite web |url=http://evostikleague.pitchero.com/a-season-in-stats-5086/ |title=A Season in Stats |publisher=Northern Premier League |accessdate=24 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519080054/http://evostikleague.pitchero.com/a-season-in-stats-5086 |archivedate=19 May 2011}}</ref> Vardy started the 2011–12 season with Halifax and scored three goals in the opening four matches of the season.<ref name=Soccerway/>
===Fleetwood Town=== [[File:Jamie Vardy 07-04-12.png|thumb|130px|Vardy playing for [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] in 2012]]
After just over a year with Halifax, Vardy signed for [[Conference Premier]] club [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] for an undisclosed fee.<ref name="Vardy Joins Fleetwood ">{{cite web |url=http://www.footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=5352 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923101237/http://www.footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=5352 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=23 September 2011 |title=Vardy joins Fleetwood |publisher=Football Conference |accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> He made his debut the same day in a 0–0 home draw with [[York City F.C.|York City]].<ref name="Fleetwood Town 0-0 York City">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/14671087.stm |title=Fleetwood Town 0–0 York City |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 August 2011 |date=26 August 2011}}</ref> He scored his first goals for the club in his third appearance, scoring twice in a 3–2 win away to [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]] on 3 September. The following week he scored another two goals against [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] at [[Highbury Stadium (Fleetwood)|Highbury Stadium]], including one in added time. He scored twice for a third consecutive match when on in the 3–1 away win against [[Ebbsfleet United F.C.|Ebbsfleet United]], but did not score again for just over a month until he scored a hat-trick in the away match against [[Alfreton Town F.C.|Alfreton Town]] on 18 October.<ref>{{cite news |title=Alfreton 1–4 Fleetwood |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15252437 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 October 2011}}</ref> On 20 September, he was given a straight red card in a 5–2 home win over [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]], a match in which both teams played over an hour with ten men each.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood Town 5–2 Kidderminster |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14893513 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 September 2011}}</ref> Four days after his hat-trick, Vardy scored two more goals in a 4–1 win over [[Bath City F.C.|Bath City]], a result which left Fleetwood two points behind leaders [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood 4–1 Bath |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15319606 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 October 2011}}</ref>
In the first round of the [[FA Cup]] on 12 November, Vardy scored the second goal in a 2–0 win over [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood 2–0 Wycombe |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15604916 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 November 2011}}</ref> Fifteen days later, his goal in a 1–1 draw at Gateshead meant that he had recorded a goal in each of his last six appearances, totalling ten goals in that period;<ref name=base>{{cite web |title=Jamie Vardy |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=61643 |website=Soccerbase |accessdate=21 September 2014}}</ref> he won the Conference Premier Player of the Month award for November.<ref name="Vardy November Honour">{{cite web |url=http://www.footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=5992 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006131654/http://www.footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=5992 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=6 October 2014 |title=Talk of the Town Vardy Takes November Honour |publisher=Football Conference |date=1 December 2011 |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> On 13 December, Vardy confirmed a 2–0 win in added time as Fleetwood triumphed 2–0 away to [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] in the Cup second round replay.<ref>{{cite news |title=Yeovil 0–2 Fleetwood |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16044894 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2011}}</ref>
On 1 January 2012, Vardy scored twice in a 6–0 win over [[Southport F.C.|Southport]], and six days later the team lost 5–1 at home to local rivals [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in the third round of the Cup.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood 1–5 Blackpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16372082 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 January 2012}}</ref> After the match, Blackpool manager [[Ian Holloway]] made a £750,000 offer for him, which Fleetwood rejected, holding on for £1 million and a loan back to the club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood reject Blackpool's Vardy bid |url=http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/sport/football/non-league/fleetwood-reject-blackpool-s-vardy-bid-1-4125677 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |newspaper=Blackpool Gazette |date=11 January 2012}}</ref> He totalled six goals in his first four matches of the calendar year.<ref name=base/> On 21 February, he recorded a second hat-trick of the campaign, in a 6–2 win over Ebbsfleet United which left Fleetwood two points ahead of Wrexham at the top of the table.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood 6–2 Ebbsfleet |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17023097 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 February 2012}}</ref> Vardy scored both Fleetwood goals in a 2–2 draw against [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] on 13 April;<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood 2–2 Lincoln |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17637607 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 April 2012}}</ref> Wrexham's draw against [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] the next day gave Fleetwood the Conference title and a first-ever promotion to the Football League.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fleetwood Town reach Football League for first time |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17716863 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 April 2012}}</ref> Vardy's 31 league goals saw him finish the season as the top scorer in the Conference Premier.<ref name=bsts>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluesqfootball.com/tables/0,20984,1441,00.html |title=League Top Scorers |publisher=bluesqfootball.com |accessdate=21 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521210044/http://www.bluesqfootball.com/tables/0%2C20984%2C1441%2C00.html |archivedate=21 May 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== ====2012–13 season==== On 17 May 2012, it was announced that Vardy would be signing for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] ahead of the 2012–13 season, for a reported fee of £1 million, a non-League record, which could potentially be worth up to £1.7 million with add-ons.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bailey |first=Graeme |title=Foxes agree record Vardy deal |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11712/7762163/Foxes-agree-record-Vardy-deal |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=17 May 2012}}</ref> The next day, he signed on a three-year contract until June 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jamie Vardy signs for City |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2775831,00.html |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |accessdate=18 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120520170738/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2775831%2C00.html |archivedate=20 May 2012}}</ref> On 14 August, Vardy made his debut for Leicester against [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] in the first round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]], playing the entirety of the match at [[Plainmoor]] and heading the final goal in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{cite news |title=Torquay 0–4 Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19159882 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2012}}</ref> Four days later he made his Football League debut at the [[King Power Stadium]], a 2–0 win over [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] in which he set up a goal for [[Andy King (footballer, born 1988)|Andy King]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester 2–0 Peterborough |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221558 |accessdate=19 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2012}}</ref> He scored his first league goal in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 25 August. In September, he scored the winner in two 2–1 comeback victories, against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref name=base/> Vardy's first season at the club was marred by his own loss of form, prompting criticism from some City supporters on social media, and he even considered leaving football until manager [[Nigel Pearson]] and assistant manager [[Craig Shakespeare]] convinced him to continue with the club.<ref name=Rise>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26610750 Jamie Vardy: Leicester City striker's remarkable rise], BBC Sport, 18 March 2014</ref>
====2013–14 season==== [[File:Jamie Vardy.jpg|thumb|upright|Vardy (left) warming up before a pre-season friendly with [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 2013]]
The following season brought a turn around in Vardy's fortunes as he established himself as a prolific scorer in the Leicester attack as the club took a commanding lead at the top of the table.<ref name=Rise/> Vardy scored and won a penalty as Leicester beat high flying local rivals [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 4–1 on 10 January 2014 and reaffirmed their position at the top of the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|Championship]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Derby County beaten 4–1 by Championship leaders Leicester City |url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-beaten-4-1-Championship-leaders/story-20428421-detail/story.html |accessdate=2 November 2015 |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |date=10 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208093834/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-beaten-4-1-Championship-leaders/story-20428421-detail/story.html |archivedate=8 December 2015}}</ref> Vardy finished the season with 16 league goals as Leicester were promoted to the Premier League at the end of the season as champions,<ref name=lg1314/> and was named Leicester's Players' Player of the season at the club's awards.<ref name=lp1314>{{cite web |title=Drinkwater named Player of the Year |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/280414-drinkwater-named-player-of-the-year-1517365.aspx |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |accessdate=2 November 2015 |date=29 April 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== On 19 August 2014, Vardy extended his contract until the summer of 2018.<ref name=lg1314>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/190814-jamie-vardy-signs-new-lcfc-contract-1840114.aspx |title=Jamie Vardy signs new contract |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=19 August 2014 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> After missing the first two matches of the season through injury, he made his Premier League debut on 31 August 2014, as a second-half substitute in a 1–1 draw at home to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. On 21 September, Vardy delivered a man of the match performance by scoring his first [[Premier League]] goal and setting up the other four as Leicester made a surprise comeback from 3–1 down to a 5–3 victory against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29196081 |title=Leicester 5–3 Man Utd |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 September 2014 |accessdate=21 September 2014}}</ref>
On 11 April 2015, Vardy scored a 90th-minute winning goal in the Foxes' 3–2 victory at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32179968 |title=West Brom 2–3 Leicester |date=11 April 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Impressive form throughout the rest of April, including another winning goal, against Burnley on 25 April, saw Vardy nominated for the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-s-Jamie-Vardy-Kasper-Schmeichel/story-26457220-detail/story.html |title=Leicester City's Jamie Vardy and Kasper Schmeichel nominated for Premier League player of the month |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=7 May 2015 |accessdate=10 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518093041/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-s-Jamie-Vardy-Kasper-Schmeichel/story-26457220-detail/story.html |archivedate=18 May 2015}}</ref> Vardy and Leicester ended the 2014–15 season in a safe 14th position having picked up 22 points since 4 April, capping things off by opening the scoring in a 5–1 victory against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on the final day of the Premier League season on 24 May.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32770769 |title=Leicester City 5–1 Queens Park Rangers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2015 |accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:Jamie Vardy 08 sierpnia 2015 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Vardy playing for Leicester City in 2015]]
Vardy started the [[2015–16 Leicester City F.C. season|2015–16]] season by scoring the opening goal as Leicester picked up a 4–2 victory at home against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 8 August 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744669 |title=Leicester City 4–2 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> He scored the equaliser in Leicester's 3–2 comeback victory against Aston Villa on 13 September.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34166753 |title=Leicester City 3–2 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2015 |accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> With two goals in Leicester's 5–2 defeat to Arsenal on 26 September, Vardy reached seven league goals for the season, eclipsing his goal tally of the previous year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34299596 |title=Arsenal forward Alexis Sanchez rediscovered his goalscoring touch as his hat-trick ended Leicester's unbeaten start to the season. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
On 24 October, he scored the only goal of a home win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], the seventh consecutive Premier League match in which he scored, and his tenth goal of the league season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester 1–0 Crystal Palace |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34558440 |accessdate=24 October 2015 |date=24 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Lake |first1=Jefferson |title=Leicester 1–0 Crystal Palace: Jamie Vardy scores in seventh straight Premier League game |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/leicester-vs-c-palace/341280 |accessdate=25 October 2015 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=24 October 2015}}</ref> Vardy scored in his eighth league match in a row on 31 October, and became only the third player ever to do so in the Premier League after [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]] (twice) and [[Daniel Sturridge]], in a 3–2 win over West Bromwich Albion.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/334623910 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20160211075100/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/334623910 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=11 February 2016 |last=Oscroft |first=Tim |title=West Brom 2–3 Leicester |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 October 2015 |accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3298228/West-Brom-2-3-Leicester-Jamie-Vardy-makes-eight-row-Riyad-Mahrez-scores-twice-Foxes-Premier-League.html |title=Jamie Vardy makes it eight in a row and Riyad Mahrez scores twice as Foxes go third in Premier League |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=31 October 2015 |accessdate=31 October 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> A week later, he won and scored a penalty to secure a 2–1 win over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], putting him on nine consecutive matches with a goal, behind Van Nistelrooy's Premier League record of ten.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Steinberg |first1=Jacob |title=Leicester City's Jamie Vardy eyes scoring record after helping defeat Watford |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/07/leicester-city-watford-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=7 November 2015 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=7 November 2015}}</ref> Vardy also became the first player in the Premiership to score in nine consecutive matches in a single season, as Van Nistelrooy's 10 matches were at the end of the 2002–03 season and the beginning of the 2003–04 season.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shemilt |first1=Stephan |title=Leicester City 2–1 Watford |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34686912 |accessdate=7 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 November 2015}}</ref> For his run of good form, Vardy was the Premier League Player of the Month for October 2015, the first Leicester player to be given the accolade since goalkeeper [[Tim Flowers]] in September 2000.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Downes |first1=John |title=Player of the Month ... Jamie Vardy is the first Leicester City player to win since Tim Flowers in 2000, but how many times have your club scooped the award? |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3311646/Player-Month-Jamie-Vardy-Leicester-City-player-win-Tim-Flowers-2000-times-club-scooped-award.html |accessdate=10 November 2015 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=10 November 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref>
On 21 November, Vardy matched Van Nistelrooy's record of consecutive Premier League matches with a goal, opening a 3–0 win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Louise |title=Jamie Vardy equals Premier League record as Leicester win at Newcastle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/21/newcastle-united-leicester-city-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=22 November 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=21 November 2015}}</ref> A week later, against Manchester United, he scored again to claim the record for himself.<ref name=plrecord>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy breaks record for goals in consecutive games |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34953098 |accessdate=28 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 November 2015}}</ref> His run ended on 5 December when he did not score in a 3–0 win at [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], having done so he would have equalled the English top-flight record of 12 consecutive scoring matches set by [[Jimmy Dunne]] for [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in [[1931–32 Football League|1931–32]]; the result nonetheless put Leicester on top of the table.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy falls short as Irishman Jimmy Dunne keeps his goalscoring record |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/jamie-vardy-falls-short-as-irishman-jimmy-dunne-keeps-his-goalscoring-record-34242615.html |accessdate=6 December 2015 |newspaper=Irish Independent |location=Dublin |date=28 November 2015}}</ref> Following his goalscoring exploits, Vardy was again named as the Premier League Player of the Month for November,<ref>{{cite news |title=Vardy and Ranieri win Barclays monthly awards |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2015-16/dec/111215-jamie-vardy-and-claudio-ranieri-win-barclays-monthly-awards-november.html |accessdate=10 November 2015 |publisher=Premier League |date=10 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151216215317/http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2015-16/dec/111215-jamie-vardy-and-claudio-ranieri-win-barclays-monthly-awards-november.html |archivedate=16 December 2015}}</ref> becoming only the fifth ever player to win the award in consecutive months.<ref>{{cite web |title=Claudio Ranieri and Jamie Vardy scoop monthly awards |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/claudio-ranieri-and-jamie-vardy-scoop-monthly-awards-2845562.aspx |accessdate=12 December 2015 |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=11 December 2015}}</ref> He was presented with a certificate from [[Guinness World Records]] for his achievement.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Swatman |first1=Rachel |title=Leicester City striker Jamie Vardy is presented with GWR certificate in honour of his record goal-scoring run |url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/2015/12/leicester-city-striker-jamie-vardy-is-presented-with-gwr-certificate-in-honour-of-408915 |accessdate=20 May 2016 |publisher=Guinness World Records |date=3 December 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Jamie Vardy and family after victory versus Everton at the King Power Stadium. (26831224691).jpg|thumb|300px|Vardy celebrating Leicester's [[Premier League]] title victory with his family in 2016]]
By January 2016, Vardy's transfer value had risen from £2.1 million to £18.8 million,<ref name="Leicester City: Why we are all rooting for the Foxes">{{citation |title=Leicester City: Why we are all rooting for the Foxes |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35480812 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 February 2016 |accessdate=7 February 2016}}</ref> with manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] describing him as "priceless".<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy and Riyad Mahrez priceless – Claudio Ranieri |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35098801 |accessdate=17 January 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 February 2016}}</ref> On 2 February, he scored both goals in a 2–0 win against Liverpool, the first being a long-distance volley described as "world class" by opposing manager [[Jürgen Klopp]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Surlis |first1=Patrick |title=Jurgen Klopp pays tribute to Leicester and Jamie Vardy after Liverpool defeat |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/10153952/jurgen-klopp-pays-tribute-to-leicester-and-jamie-vardy-after-liverpool-defeat |accessdate=7 February 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=3 February 2016}}</ref> Four days later, he signed a new contract to keep himself at Leicester until 2019, increasing his weekly salary to £80,000.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy signs new Leicester City contract until 2019 |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10158717/jamie-vardy-signs-new-leicester-city-contract-until-2019 |accessdate=7 February 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=7 February 2016}}</ref> On 10 April 2016, Vardy scored both goals (his 20th and 21st of the season) in Leicester's 2–0 win at Sunderland, becoming the first Leicester player since [[Gary Lineker]] in the 1984–85 season to score 20 goals in the top division of English football. The result also secured qualification to the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in Leicester's history.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35953062 |title=Sunderland 0–2 Leicester |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 April 2016}}</ref> A week later, Vardy scored the first goal of a 2–2 home draw against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], but was later sent off for [[Simulation (Association football)|diving]] in the penalty area under pressure from [[Angelo Ogbonna]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=James |first1=Stuart |title=Jamie Vardy could face extended suspension after red card |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/english-soccer/jamie-vardy-could-face-extended-suspension-after-red-card-1.2614067 |accessdate=17 April 2016 |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=17 April 2016}}</ref> He was charged with improper conduct for his reaction to the dismissal and was fined £10,000, as well as being suspended for two matches during a vital point of Leicester's eventually successful title campaign.<ref>{{cite news |last=James |first=Stuart |title=Leicester City's Jamie Vardy given extra game's ban for improper conduct |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/25/leicester-city-jamie-vardy-one-game-ban-improper-conduct |accessdate=6 May 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 April 2016}}</ref>
With 24 league goals, Vardy was the second highest scorer in the Premier League for the 2015–16 season, alongside [[Sergio Agüero]], only one goal behind Golden Boot winner [[Harry Kane]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2015-16/may/180516-harry-kane-wins-barclays-golden-boot.html |title=Kane's delight at winning Barclays Golden Boot |publisher=Premier League |date=18 May 2016 |accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref> Vardy was one of four Leicester players in the [[PFA Team of the Year]];<ref name=PFA>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36106596 |title=PFA awards: Leicester and Spurs dominate Premier League team |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2016 |accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref> he was later also named the [[FWA Footballer of the Year]],<ref name=FWA>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10266701/leicester-striker-jamie-vardy-named-football-writers-association-footballer-of-the-year-2015-16 |title=Jamie Vardy named Football Writers' Association Footballer of the Year 2015/16 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 May 2016 |accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref> and the 2016 Barclays [[Premier League Player of the Season]].<ref name="Barclays Player of the Season">{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2015-16/may/130516-leicester-city-jamie-vardy-wins-barclays-player-of-the-season.html |title=Vardy wins Barclays Player of the Season award |publisher=Premier League |date=13 May 2016 |accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 3 June 2016, Arsenal made a bid of £22 million for Vardy, triggering a release clause in his contract. Leicester offered him improved terms, and 20 days later he agreed to a new four-year deal, to be signed on his return from [[UEFA Euro 2016]]. Vardy rejected Arsenal's offer due to not being assured that he would be played in his normal position, and because of the differences between the two club's tactics, with [[Arsène Wenger]] favouring possession and Leicester playing on the counter-attack.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Reynolds |first1=Ben |title=Jamie Vardy snubbed Arsenal over reservations of role under Arsene Wenger – Sky sources |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10323500/jamie-vardy-snubbed-arsenal-over-reservations-of-role-under-arsene-wenger-sky-sources |accessdate=25 June 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=24 June 2016}}</ref>
On 7 August 2016, he scored in a 2–1 defeat to Manchester United in the [[2016 FA Community Shield]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36934956 |title=Community Shield: Leicester City 1–2 Manchester United |publisher=BBC Sport |last=Bevan |first=Chris |date=7 August 2016 |accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref> Twenty days later, Vardy scored his first league goal of the season in Leicester's first win of the campaign, beating Swansea City 2–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37139685 |title=Leicester City 2–1 Swansea City |date=27 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
On 10 December 2016, Vardy ended his ten-match drought within the opening five minutes against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. He ended up scoring another two for his first professional hat-trick to help Leicester to a 4–2 victory, their first win in five league matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38193109 |title=Leicester City 4–2 Manchester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 December 2016}}</ref> A week later, he was sent off in the first half of a 2–2 draw at Stoke City for a challenge on [[Mame Biram Diouf]]; Leicester appealed unsuccessfully against his three-match suspension.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jamie Vardy to serve three-match ban after red card appeal is rejected |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/20/jamie-vardy-red-card-appeal-rejected |accessdate=25 November 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |agency=Press Association |date=20 December 2016}}</ref>
On 22 February 2017, Vardy scored his first [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] goal in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in the first leg of the round of 16.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/feb/22/sevilla-leicester-city-champions-league-last-16-match-report |title=Jamie Vardy hands Leicester Champions League lifeline against Sevilla |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Sid |last=Lowe |date=22 February 2017 |accessdate=22 February 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== [[File:Leicester 1 Chelsea 2 (36325510703) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Vardy playing for Leicester City in 2017]]
Vardy commenced his 6th season at the club on 11 August 2017 by netting two goals in the 4–3 away loss to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the opening day of [[2017–18 Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40822513 |title=Arsenal 4–3 Leicester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> This was followed by three more goals in September, including one in the 1–1 draw against [[Huddersfield Town]] which was one of two points collected by Leicester in four matches this month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/huddsfld-vs-leicester/373140 |title=Huddersfield Town 1–1 Leicester City: Jamie Vardy penalty seals point |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 September 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> On 16 October, Vardy made his 200th appearance for the club by starting in the 1–1 draw against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41547739 |title=Leicester City 1–1 West Bromwich Albion |publisher=BBC Sport |author=Johnston, Neil |date=16 October 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> Two weeks later, he scored the opener of a 2–0 home win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] to give "The Foxes" a second consecutive league win after six winless games and also to send them clear of relegation zone.<ref name="Puel">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/29/leicester-city-everton-premier-league-match-report |title=Claude Puel has winning start as Leicester pile further misery on Everton |newspaper=The Guardian |author=James, Stuart |date=29 October 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> It was also [[Claude Puel]]'s debut match as Leicester manager.<ref name="Puel"/>
Later on 19 December, Vardy scored a 97th-minute equaliser with a penalty kick in the [[EFL Cup]] [[2017–18 EFL Cup#Fifth round|quarter-final]] match against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] to tie the game 1–1; the game subsequently went to penalty shootouts where Vardy along with [[Riyad Mahrez]] were the only players to miss their attempts as Leicester lost 3–4.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42318865 |title=Leicester City 1–1 Manchester City (3–4 pens) |publisher=BBC Sport |author=Hafez, Shamoon |date=19 December 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> Four days later, he netted his 50th Premier League in the 2–2 draw against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/vardy-scores-50th-premier-league-goal-for-leicester-against/u8usgqwtbrvr1elt512yxoj5z |title=Vardy scores 50th Premier League goal for Leicester against Man Utd |publisher=Goal.com |date=23 December 2017 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> Vardy continued his fine form by scoring his 10th Premier League goal of the season on 20 January of the following year via a penalty kick in the 2–0 home win versus [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/match/22576 |title=Leicester City 2–0 Watford |publisher=Premier League |date=20 January 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> The following month, Vardy scored the lone goal of the [[FA Cup]] [[2017–18 FA Cup#Fifth round|fifth round]] match against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] to allow Leicester progression to quarter-finals,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://talksport.com/football/leicester-1-0-sheffield-united-riyad-mahrez-returns-set-vardy-foxes-progress-fa-cup-quarter |title=Leicester 1–0 Sheffield United: Riyad Mahrez returns to set up Vardy as the Foxes progress to FA Cup quarter-finals |publisher=talkSPORt.com |date=16 February 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> only to be eliminated by [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] after extra-time, with Vardy scoring his team's only goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43361317 |title=Leicester City 1–1 Chelsea (aet) |publisher=BBC Sport |author=McNulty, Phil |date=18 March 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
By netting a brace in the final day of the season, a 5–4 away defeat by [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], Vardy reached 20-goal landmark in the Premier League for the second time in his career.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-5-leicester-city-4-spurs-seal-third-spot-with-thrilling-win-in-wembley-swansong-a3837726.html |title=Tottenham 5 Leicester City 4: Spurs seal third with thrilling win in Wembley swansong |newspaper=Evening Standard |author=Veal, Jonathan |date=13 May 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> Overall, he made 42 appearances in all competitions, scoring 23 times as Leicester finished the Premier League in 9th place.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/epl-table-premier-league-standings-gameweek-38-fixtures-latest-score-results-top-scorers-live-tv-a3837761.html |title=EPL table: Final 2017–18 Premier League standings, gameweek 38 fixtures, latest scores, results, top scorers and Golden Boot, live, TV channel, predictions |newspaper=Evening Standard |author=Young, Alex |date=14 May 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> Vardy was the recipient of the [[BBC Goal of the Season]] award for a goal against [[West Bromwich Albion]] where he struck a first-time ball with his weaker foot that was looped over his shoulder at range by his strike partner Riyad Mahrez.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/jamie-vardy-wins-match-days-1563797 |title=Jamie Vardy wins Match of the Day's goal of the season – how fans reacted |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== On 9 August 2018, just before the start of the 2018–19 season, Vardy signed a new four-year deal at Leicester, keeping him at the club until 2022, when he will be 35.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/08/09/jamie-vardy-signs-new-four-year-leicester-contract-will-keep/ |title=Jamie Vardy signs new four-year Leicester contract that will keep him at club until age of 35 |date=9 January 2018 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref> Vardy started the season as a substitute, scoring a 92nd minute consolation goal in the 2–1 away defeat to Manchester United on the opening match of the season.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Begley |first1=Emlyn |title=Manchester United 2 – 1 Leicester City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45053886 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref> He was sent off the following match after a harsh tackle on [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] defender [[Matt Doherty (footballer, born 1992)|Matt Doherty]].<ref name="sportbible">{{cite web |last1=Jarrah |first1=Yousif |title=Mr |url=http://www.sportbible.com/football/news-reactions-fails-jamie-vardy-given-straight-red-card-after-disgusting-high-challenge-20180818 |website=sportbible |publisher=Jack Kenmare |accessdate=22 August 2018 |ref=http://www.sportbible.com/football/news-reactions-fails-jamie-vardy-given-straight-red-card-after-disgusting-high-challenge-20180818}}</ref> On 9 March Vardy scored two goals in a 3–1 home win over Fulham. The first goal being his 100th for The Foxes. This win was [[Brendan Rodgers]] first at his new club.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leicester 3–1 Fulham: Jamie Vardy double earns Brendan Rodgers first win – BBC Sport|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47424846 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Jamie Vardy 2018-06-28 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Vardy playing for [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]]
On 21 May 2015, Vardy was called up to the [[England national football team|English national team]] for the first time ahead of a friendly against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]]. He made his debut on 7 June in the goalless draw against the Republic of Ireland at the [[Aviva Stadium]] in Dublin, replacing captain [[Wayne Rooney]] for the final 15 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |title=R. of Ireland 0–0 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32949838 |accessdate=7 June 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 June 2015}}</ref> On 30 August, Vardy was again called up to the England squad for the matches against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] in UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying,<ref>{{cite news |title=Internationals: England's Vardy among LCFC contingent |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/internationals-englands-vardy-among-lcfc-contingent-2658100.aspx |accessdate=30 August 2015 |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=30 August 2015}}</ref> being selected in the starting line-up as England ran out 6–0 winners against San Marino in [[Serravalle (San Marino)|Serravalle]] six days later.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34165282 |title=San Marino v England: How the players rated |date=5 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Vardy scored his first international goal on 26 March 2016, equalising with a back heel from [[Nathaniel Clyne]]'s cross, as a substitute in a 3–2 away win against [[Germany national football team|Germany]].<ref name="Germany 2–3 England"/> He scored again, three days later, the opening goal in a 2–1 defeat to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/29/england-holland-international-friendly-match-report |title=England frustrated as Luciano Narsingh goal seals Holland's comeback |date=29 March 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
Vardy made his tournament debut on 16 June, in England's second group match at UEFA Euro 2016, coming off the bench in the second half to score an equalising goal against [[Wales national football team|Wales]], helping his team come from behind to win the match 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/16/england-2-wales-1-daniel-sturridge-and-jamie-vardy-come-off-the/ |title=England 2 Wales 1: Daniel Sturridge and Jamie Vardy come off the bench to secure last-gasp win |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Jason |last=Burt |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> During the tournament, there were media rumours of a feud between Vardy and fellow striker Rooney, which were denied by manager [[Roy Hodgson]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Crellin |first1=Mark |title=Wayne Rooney and Jamie Vardy are close friends, says Roy Hodgson |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/10325817/wayne-rooney-and-jamie-vardy-are-close-friends-says-roy-hodgson |accessdate=28 June 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=27 June 2016}}</ref>
He was named in the 23-man England squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
On 28 August 2018, Vardy "stepped aside" from the England national team, telling manager [[Gareth Southgate]] that he did not want to be considered for selection unless there was an injury crisis.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45332294 |title=Jamie Vardy and Gary Cahill step aside from international football |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 August 2018 |date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
==Playing style== [[Ian Wright]], who also rose from non-League football to the Premier League and English national team, wrote in October 2015 that Vardy could be England's equivalent to [[Salvatore Schillaci]] at UEFA Euro 2016: Schillaci, another late bloomer, began the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] as a substitute behind more established players, and ended it as the top scorer.<ref name=wright>{{cite news |last1=Wright |first1=Ian |title=Jamie Vardy can be England's Toto Schillaci at Euro 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34611895 |accessdate=25 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 October 2015}}</ref> Wright, who first learnt of Vardy when his former Burnley teammate [[Micky Mellon]] signed him for Fleetwood, rates Vardy as a hard-working player with a good first touch, who creates constant work for defenders, and plays by instinct instead of being moulded by his managers.<ref name=wright/> Although he usually plays in a central role as a striker, he is a versatile player, who is capable of playing in several attacking positions, and has also been used as a [[Forward (association football)#Winger|winger]].<ref name="dai dilettanti all'Inghilterra">{{cite web |url=http://www.corrieredellosport.it/news/calcio/talent-scout/2015/10/09-4805058/vardy_dai_dilettanti_alla_maglia_dell_inghilterra |title=Vardy, dai dilettanti alla maglia dell'Inghilterra |newspaper=Corriere dello Sport |language=Italian |author1=Chioffi, Stefano |date=9 October 2015 |accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref>
In addition to his goalscoring, Vardy is known for his high work-rate, relentless running, and direct approach, and is also capable of creating chances for his teammates.<ref name="Vardy scales new heights">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/may/21/leicester-jamie-vardy-england |title=Leicester's Jamie Vardy scales new heights with England call-up |date=21 May 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> He is an extremely fast and dynamic striker, with good positioning,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://nypost.com/2015/11/30/how-little-known-jamie-vardy-became-a-goal-scoring-beast/ |title=How little-known Jamie Vardy became a goal-scoring beast |newspaper=The New York Post |author1=Hood, Bryan |date=30 November 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> and an excellent sense of space in the area;<ref name="real deal">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/03/23/players-of-the-season-why-jamie-vardy-is-the-real-deal/ |title=Players of the season: Why Jamie Vardy is the real deal |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=JJ |last=Bull |date=26 March 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> he is also known for his ability to play on the last defender's shoulder, time his runs to beat the defensive line, and stretch opponents,<ref name="Vardy scales new heights"/> which, combined with his pace, makes him a threat on counter-attacks.<ref name="dai dilettanti all'Inghilterra"/> A composed finisher and an accurate [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] taker, he is also good in the air, and capable of striking the ball powerfully with both feet.<ref name="real deal"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/30385/10037779/jamie-vardy-is-the-premier-league-top-scorer-can-he-keep-it-up |title=Jamie Vardy is the Premier League top scorer: Can he keep it up? |publisher=Sky Sports |author1=Bate, Adam |date=22 October 2015 |accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref> England coach and [[Sky Sports]] pundit [[Gary Neville]] commented on how Vardy's approach influences teammates: "He sets the tempo and the tone for the rest of the team and gives no other player behind him any excuse for not working hard."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/614359/Manchester-United-Gary-Neville-hails-Jamie-Vardy-England-great |title=Manchester United legend hails Jamie Vardy as one of the great England forwards |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |author1=Mafham, Colin |date=25 October 2015 |accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>
According to Leicester vice-chairman Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha, Vardy drank heavily every night during his early days at the club, and would turn up at training still intoxicated. Srivaddhanaprabha discussed with Vardy over what he expected in his life, and Vardy gave up drinking and took training more seriously from then on.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sheen |first1=Tom |title=Jamie Vardy used to 'turn up drunk', claims Leicester vice-chairman |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/jamie-vardy-used-to-turn-up-drunk-claims-leicester-vice-chairman-a7014666.html |accessdate=6 May 2016 |newspaper=The Independent |date=5 May 2016}}</ref>
During [[UEFA Euro 2016]], Vardy spoke to the media about his unusual lifestyle choices for a professional sportsperson. He said that he does not exercise in a gym, and that he consumes [[Red Bull]] caffeinated beverages and [[snus]] smokeless tobacco.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Morgan |first1=Tom |title=Jamie Vardy's gym workout revealed: lifting a can of Red Bull and sucking tobacco |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/18/jamie-vardys-gym-workout-revealed-lifting-a-can-of-red-bull-and1/ |accessdate=25 November 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=18 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Jamie Vardy: England staff have no problem with him using nicotine pouches |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36568105 |accessdate=25 November 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 June 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Rebekah Vardy attends England–Panama match at the 2018 FIFA World Cup.jpg|thumb|upright|Vardy's wife Rebekah supporting him at the 2018 FIFA World Cup]]
Before turning professional, Vardy combined playing non-League football with a job as technician making medical [[Splint (medicine)|splints]].<ref>{{citation |title=Our Jamie has come so Var |first=Stuart |last=Hammond |newspaper=The Non-League Paper |page=7 |date=28 September 2014}}</ref> In 2007, he received a conviction for assault following an incident outside a pub, and had to play with an electronic tag fitted for six months, while his curfew also limited his playing time at Stocksbridge Park Steels.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brooks |first1=Gideon |title=Exclusive: Jamie Vardy's former chairman reveals how assault conviction changed career |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/622586/Jamie-Vardy-Leicester-assault-conviction-Premier-League |accessdate=29 November 2015 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=28 November 2015}}</ref>
In August 2015, ''The Sun on Sunday'' published a video of Vardy at a casino the previous month, calling a man of East Asian origin a "[[Jap]]". He apologised for a "regrettable error of judgement" and was fined by Leicester, who put him on an educational course.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City fine Jamie Vardy over racist incident |url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2015/0813/721096-leicester-fine-jamie-vardy-over-racist/ |accessdate=2 September 2015 |publisher=RTÉ Sport |date=13 August 2015}}</ref>
Vardy met Rebekah Nicholson in 2014 while she was working as a nightclub promoter.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://usahint.com/sports/wives-and-girlfriends-of-england-stars-726/5/ |title=#WorldCupWAGs: Wives and Girlfriends of England Stars Rocking the World Cup in Russia |website=USAHint |date=20 June 2018 |accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Who is Rebekah Vardy? I'm A Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here! 2017 profile |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/tv/2017-11-24/im-a-celebrity-2017-rebekah-vardy-profile/ |accessdate=25 November 2017 |publisher=Radio Times}}</ref> The couple married on 25 May 2016 at [[Peckforton Castle]] in Cheshire, with [[David Nugent]] as the best man.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City's Jamie Vardy gets married |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-36382107 |accessdate=25 May 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=25 May 2016}}</ref> Vardy has three biological children, two with his wife, and one from a previous relationship. He is also stepfather to two children from his wife's previous relationships.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Watson |first1=Hayley |title=Fans of I'm A Celebrity star Rebekah Vardy blast show for describing her occupation as 'footballer's wife' |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/news/celebs-tv/rebekah-vardy-footballer-wife-celebrity-810511 |accessdate=25 November 2017 |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=23 November 2017}}</ref>
In November 2015, Vardy launched V9 Academy, an annual week-long camp designed to offer coaching and guidance to 60 non-League players and offer them the opportunity to showcase their talent in front of scouts from league clubs.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34950055 |title=Jamie Vardy: Leicester striker launches non-league academy |date=27 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/27/jamie-vardy-leicester-academy-non-league |title=Leicester's Jamie Vardy sets up academy to help non-league talent |date=27 November 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> The same month, Stocksbridge Park Steels named their main stand after him.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bernstein |first1=Joe |title=Jamie Vardy's first club Stocksbridge Park Steels to name main stand after Leicester's record-breaking goal-scorer |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3337989/Jamie-Vardy-s-club-Stocksbridge-Park-Steels-main-stand-Leicester-s-record-breaking-goal-scorer.html |accessdate=29 November 2015 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=29 November 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> In December 2015, the [[Leicester]]-based food manufacturer [[Walkers (snack foods)|Walkers]] brought out a limited edition 'Vardy Salted' [[Potato chip|crisp]] flavour, in recognition of Vardy's goalscoring run.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gibson |first=Sean |title=Jamie Vardy gets his own limited edition Walkers crisp flavour |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/leicester-city/12046867/Jamie-Vardy-gets-his-own-limited-edition-Walkers-crisp-flavour.html |accessdate=12 December 2015 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=11 December 2015}}</ref> [[Adrian Butchart]], British writer of the [[Goal! (film series)|''Goal!'']] series of football-related fiction films, finished a script in 2016 for a film about Vardy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Tanner |first=Rob |title=Could Danny Boyle direct film of Leicester City striker Jamie Vardy's life? |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/news/leicester-news/could-danny-boyle-direct-film-198025 |accessdate=29 September 2017 |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Vardy is an ambassador for Dorothy Goodman School, a special needs school in [[Hinckley]], Leicestershire.<ref>{{cite web |title=Our School Ambassadors |url=http://www.dorothygoodman.co.uk/our-school-ambassadors/ |publisher=Dorothy Goodman School |accessdate=5 July 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616212125/http://www.dorothygoodman.co.uk/our-school-ambassadors/ |archivedate=16 June 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>

He began his career with [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] before joining [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in 2016. He has also played for [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]]. ==Early life== Maddison was born and raised in [[Coventry]], West Midlands.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-seniors/squad/james-maddison |title=James Maddison |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He is of Irish descent through a grandparent.{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.ie/archives/football/132264/exclusive-fai-track-young-hotshot-james-maddison/ |title=Exclusive: FAI track young hotshot James Maddison |first=Neil |last=O'Riordan |newspaper=The Irish Sun |location=Dublin |date=22 January 2016 |accessdate=15 November 2018}} ==Club career== ===Coventry City=== Maddison joined [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]'s youth team, and was included in the first-team squad in the [[2013–14 Coventry City F.C. season|2013–14 season]],{{cite web |url=https://www.ccfc.co.uk/news/2013/october/pressley-stays-unchanged-for-stevenage/ |title=Pressley stays unchanged for Stevenage |first=Kieran |last=Crowley |publisher=Coventry City F.C. |date=5 October 2013 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} though did not make an appearance.{{cn|date=October 2018}} He made his debut in August 2014, coming on as a substitute in a 2–1 [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] defeat to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].{{cite web |url=https://www.ccfc.co.uk/news/2014/august/match-report-coventry-city-1-2-cardiff-city/ |title=Match report: Coventry City 1–2 Cardiff City |first=Nick |last=Connoll |publisher=Coventry City F.C. |date=13 August 2014 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} Maddison made his league debut, again as a substitute, in a 3–1 home loss against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and his first league start in the following game, against [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]]. He scored his first league goal in the game, with a free-kick in the first-half, as the Sky Blues lost the game 4–1.{{cn|date=October 2018}} In November 2014, Maddison signed his first professional contract, lasting three and a half years,{{cite web |url=https://www.ccfc.co.uk/news/2014/november/coventry-city-midfielder-james-maddison-signs-a-three-and-a-half-year-deal-with-the-club-/ |title=Coventry City midfielder James Maddison signs a three-and-a-half-year deal with the club |first=Matt |last=Joyce |publisher=Coventry City F.C. |date=24 November 2014 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} but missed much of the rest of the [[2014–15 Coventry City F.C. season|2014–15 season]] after being sent-off during a Boxing Day defeat to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] and then picking up a back injury.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30543582 |title=Doncaster Rovers 2–0 Coventry City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 December 2014 |accessdate=9 October 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.coventrytelegraph.net/sport/football/football-news/sky-blues-starlet-james-maddison-8440501 |title=Sky Blues starlet James Maddison struggling to be fit for FA Youth Cup game at Manchester City |first=Andy |last=Turner |newspaper=Coventry Telegraph |date=14 January 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} ===Norwich City=== Maddison signed for [[Premier League]] club [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on 1 February 2016 on a three-and-a-half-year contract for an undisclosed fee, but was immediately [[Loan (sports)|loaned]] back to Coventry City for the remainder of the [[2015–16 Coventry City F.C. season|2015–16 season]].{{cite web |url=https://www.canaries.co.uk/News/2016/february/transfer-news-city-sign-coventrys-james-maddison/ |title=Transfer news: City sign Coventry's James Maddison |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} On 31 August 2016, Maddison was loaned to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] for the first part of the [[2016–17 Aberdeen F.C. season|2016–17 season]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37237269 |title=Norwich City midfielder James Maddison joins Aberdeen on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 August 2016 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He made his debut as a substitute against [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness Caledonian Thistle]], then started and scored in the next match in a 3–1 win against [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37331437 |title=Dundee 1–3 Aberdeen |first=Chick |last=Young |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 September 2016 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He followed this with a last-minute winner against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] on 25 September 2016.{{cite news |url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-match-reports/aberdeen-2-rangers-1-james-8911476 |title=Aberdeen 2 Rangers 1: James Maddison hits perfect free-kick to win it for Dons – three things we learned |first=Gary |last=Ralston |newspaper=Daily Record |location=Glasgow |date=25 September 2016 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} After returning from his loan spell at Aberdeen, Maddison made his long-awaited league debut for Norwich on 17 April 2017, coming on as a substitute in the second half and scoring in a 3–1 win against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at Deepdale. Maddison signed a new four-year contract in June 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.canaries.co.uk/News/2017/june/james-maddison-new-deal/|title=James Maddison signs new deal with the Canaries|website=www.canaries.co.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2019-02-19}} With the arrival of new coach [[Daniel Farke]], Maddison was given regular starts in the team during the [[2017–18 Norwich City F.C. season|2017–18 season]] and was named Norwich City's [[Norwich City F.C. Player of the Season|Player of the Season]] at the end of the campaign,{{cite web |url=https://www.canaries.co.uk/News/2018/april/madders-leeds/ |title=James Maddison: It's one of the best awards you can get |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |date=28 April 2016 |access-date=9 October 2018}} as well as receiving a nomination for the EFL Championship Young Player of the Season award.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43641225 |title=EFL awards: Tom Cairney, Ruben Neves & Ryan Sessgenon on Championship shortlist |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 April 2018 |accessdate=4 April 2018}} ===Leicester City=== Maddison signed for Premier League club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on 20 June 2018 on a five-year contract for an undisclosed fee, thought to be around £20 million.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44553234 |title=Leicester sign midfielder James Maddison from Norwich on five-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 June 2018 |accessdate=2 July 2018}} He scored his first goal in the Premier League on 18 August in a 2–0 win against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45153216 |title=Leicester City 2–0 Wolverhampton Wanderers |first=Harry |last=Poole |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2018 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He later followed up his impressive start for the club with back-to-back Premier League goals, from set-pieces, against [[AFC Bournemouth]] and [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] respectively.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45530720 |title=Leicester City 3–1 Huddersfield Town |first=Mantej |last=Mann |date=22 September 2018 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} ==International career== Maddison was included in an [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] squad in March 2016,{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/nov/02/england-u21s-squad-named-for-ukraine-021117 |title=The England U21s squad to face Ukraine in Kiev has been named by boss Aidy Boothroyd |first=Nicholas |last=Maddison |publisher=The Football Association |date=7 November 2017 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He received his first call-up to the England under-21 team in November 2017, and made his debut against [[Ukraine national under-21 football team|Ukraine]] in a [[2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualifier]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41884793 |title=Ukraine U21 0–2 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2017 |accessdate=9 October 2018}} He received his first call up to the [[England national football team|senior team]] in October 2018 for the [[UEFA Nations League]] matches against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45744731 |title=James Maddison, Jadon Sancho and Mason Mount named in England squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 October 2018
