Reserves and Academy|Aston Villa]] |years1 = 2009–2014 |clubs1 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] |caps1 = 86 |goals1 = 7 |years2 = 2013 |clubs2 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) |caps2 = 4 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2014– |clubs3 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps3 = 143 |goals3 = 10 |nationalyears1 = 2009 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] |nationalcaps2 = 8 |nationalgoals2 = 1 | club-update = 18:03, 1 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Marc Kevin Albrighton''' (born 18 November 1989) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].
He joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at the age of eight, and made his professional debut for them in 2009. he totalled nine goals in 101 professional appearances for Villa, also spending a loan spell at [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2013. After being released in 2014, he signed for [[Leicester City]] where he won the [[Premier League]] in 2015–16, playing in every league match of the season.
Albrighton represented the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] and [[England national under-21 football team|U20]] sides.
==Club career== ===Aston Villa=== ====Early career==== Born in [[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]], [[Staffordshire]], Albrighton started his career at hometown club Mile Oak Monarchs,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisistamworth.co.uk/news/Mile-Oak-Moscow-Aston-Villa-star-Marc/article-732908-detail/article.html |archive-url = https://archive.is/20120913095158/http://www.thisistamworth.co.uk/news/Mile-Oak-Moscow-Aston-Villa-star-Marc/article-732908-detail/article.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 13 September 2012 |title=From Mile Oak to Moscow for Aston Villa star Marc |publisher=thisistamworth.co.uk |date=27 February 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> before he was offered a trial at Villa's local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. He was rejected by Albion, then subsequently signed for Villa at the age of eight.<ref name=profile>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/PlayerProfiles/0,,10265~46559,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423043733/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/PlayerProfiles/0%2C%2C10265~46559%2C00.html |archivedate=23 April 2012 |title=Player Profiles |publisher=[[Aston Villa F.C.]] |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>
After impressing in the under-18 squad and playing in the [[Aston Villa F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserves]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/players/profile?id=132107&cc=5739 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902061708/http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/players/profile?id=132107&cc=5901 |archivedate=2 September 2009 |title=Marc Albrighton Bio |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> Albrighton's first taste of senior action came on 10 July 2008, playing 17 minutes as a substitute in the 6–0 pre-season friendly victory over [[FC Wil|Wil]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~1342074,00.html |archive-url = https://archive.is/20140331212609/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~1342074,00.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 31 March 2014 |title=FC Wil 1900 0–6 VILLA |publisher=[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] |date=10 July 2008 |accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut in the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] match away at [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] on 26 February 2009, a 2–0 loss (3–1 aggregate).<ref name=profile/><ref>{{cite news |title=Albrighton grateful to MacDonald |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/aston_villa/8980936.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 September 2010}}</ref>
During the [[2009–10 Aston Villa F.C. season#Friendly Matches|2009–10 pre-season]], Albrighton was included in the squad which played in the pre-season friendly tournament, the [[2009 Peace Cup]], in which he scored his first goal for the club in a 3–1 win over [[Atlante F.C.|Atlante]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/2200/peace-cup-2009/2009/07/29/1411193/aston-villa-see-off-atlante-to-progress-in-peace-cup |title=Aston Villa See Off Atlante To Progress in Peace Cup |work=[[Goal]] |date=29 July 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> He played in the Peace Cup final in which Villa beat Italians [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] 4–3 in a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/aug/03/villa-peace-cup-juventus |title=Aston Villa win Peace Cup after beating Juventus |work=The Guardian |date=3 August 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
====First team==== Albrighton made his [[Premier League]] debut on 15 August 2009, the opening day of the 2009–10 season against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at [[Villa Park]], coming on as a 68th-minute substitute for [[Habib Beye]] in a 0–2 loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_facts/0,19762,11065_3149182,00.html |title=Aston Villa 0–2 Wigan: Match Facts |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=15 August 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> On 24 September, he extended his contract with Villa by three years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/5580686 |title=Albrighton signs new Villa deal |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref> In December, manager [[Martin O'Neill]] admitted that Albrighton along with fellow youngsters [[Nathan Delfouneso]] and [[Ciaran Clark]] were the subject of many loan offers, but went on to state his belief that the trio were good enough to learn their trade in the fringes of the Aston Villa side.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2096821,00.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=6 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307013237/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2096821,00.html |archivedate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
After a good pre-season, Albrighton made his first Premier League start in the first match of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]] against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 14 August 2010, assisting two goals in Villa's 3–0 win. He scored his first goal for Villa against [[Tottenham Hotspur]] on 2 October. He was sent off against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] on 27 October, therefore missing a chance to play in the following match against local rivals [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]. On 5 November, Albrighton signed a new contract keeping him at the club until 2014. On 23 November, Albrighton was ruled out of action for three to four weeks after having his appendix removed, but made his return ahead of schedule in a 3–0 defeat to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 6 December, playing 65 minutes before being replaced by [[Robert Pires]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2238278,00.html |title=Match report: Liverpool 3–0 Villa | Aston Villa |publisher=Aston Villa F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306221850/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2238278,00.html |archivedate=6 March 2016}}</ref> Albrighton then set up both goals for the home side in the 2–1 defeat of local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion]] in December 2010.
On 21 December 2011, he scored the Premier League's 20,000th goal at home against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], winning a £20,000 cheque from league sponsors [[Barclays]], donated to his chosen charity, [[Acorns Children's Hospice]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/sports-news/football/premier-league/1397/98/albrighton-get-20000th-premier-league-goal-special |title=Football premier-league: Albrighton: To get 20,000th Premier League goal is special | Radio talkSPORT |publisher=Talksport.co.uk}}</ref> He then scored the opening goal in a 3–1 win against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] at the [[Memorial Ground]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16372066.stm "Bristol Rovers 1–3 Aston Villa"] BBC Sport. 7 January 2012. Retrieved 10 January 2012.</ref>
A throat operation restricted Albrighton to a single outing, in the League Cup, up to October 2013. He joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a 28-day loan on 30 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24743368 |title=Marc Albrighton: Aston Villa winger joins Wigan Athletic on loan |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2013 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He made four appearances for Wigan before returning to his parent club on 27 November 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aston Villa recall Marc Albrighton from loan spell at Wigan Athletic |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/9044867/ |work=Sky Sports |publisher=BSkyB |accessdate=28 November 2013 |date=27 November 2013}}</ref> Albrighton was released by Villa on 20 May 2014.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mark Albrighton and Nathan Delfouneso released from Villa |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3845958,00.html |work=Aston Villa Official Website |date=20 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521114941/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3845958,00.html |archivedate=21 May 2014}}</ref>
===Leicester City===
====2014–15 season==== On 23 May 2014, Albrighton joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on a four-year contract, following their return to the Premier League for the first time in a decade.<ref>{{cite web |title=City Seal Deal For Albrighton |date=23 May 2014 |publisher=[[Leicester City F.C.]] |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/230514-city-seal-deal-for-albrighton-1572247.aspx}}</ref> He made his debut for the Foxes on 23 August, replacing [[Riyad Mahrez]] for the final 22 minutes of a 2–0 loss at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. The following 29 April, in the reverse fixture at the [[King Power Stadium]], he scored his first Leicester goal, putting Leicester ahead just before half time in an eventual 3–1 loss.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Leicester 1–3 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32408264 |accessdate=16 January 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 April 2015}}</ref> Albrighton totalled 18 league appearances in his first season at his new club, adding a second goal in the last match of the season, a 5–1 win against [[Queens Park Rangers]] on 24 May.<ref>{{cite news |title=Five-star City end season in style |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-x-QPR-x-match-report/story-26563631-detail/story.html |accessdate=16 January 2016 |work=Leicester Mercury |date=24 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530033538/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-x-QPR-x-match-report/story-26563631-detail/story.html |archivedate=30 May 2015}}</ref> Albrighton struggled to break into the first team squad at the start of the season, but nearer the end of the year was used as a wing-back by manager [[Nigel Pearson]] in a new formation that brought Leicester success. He played an instrumental role in helping complete Leicester's 'great escape' as the team won 7 out of their last 9 matches to finish 14th.
====2015–16 season==== [[File:Leicester 2 Chelsea 1 (23409952749).jpg|thumb|Albrighton (top right) playing for Leicester City in a league match against Chelsea at the King Power Stadium in December 2015]] Albrighton played more regularly under new manager [[Claudio Ranieri]], featuring in every league match in the [[2015–16 Premier League|campaign]]. Albrighton scored his first goal of the season in the opening 4–2 victory over [[Sunderland AFC|Sunderland]], which set the tone for a remarkable season. He partnered [[N'Golo Kanté]], [[Riyad Mahrez]] and [[Danny Drinkwater]] in a regular 4-man midfield as the club won their first ever top-flight title.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Laurence |first1=Martin |title=Why Riyad Mahrez, and not Jamie Vardy, has been the player of the season so far |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2015/dec/08/riyad-mahrez-jamie-vardy-player-season-premier-league |accessdate=17 January 2016 |work=The Guardian |date=8 December 2015}}</ref> Albrighton played on the left of midfield for the majority of the campaign, and was noted for his "diligent work defensively and when going forward, as well as his high-class crossing from open play and set pieces."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Doyle |first1=Paul |title=From Schmeichel to Vardy: Leicester's title winners rated |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/03/leicester-city-player-ratings-2015-16-premier-league-winning-season |accessdate=8 June 2016 |work=The Guardian |date=4 May 2016}}</ref> with manager Ranieri claiming "Albrighton embodies the spirit of Leicester" for his "unmistakable sense of sacrifice."<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester's title-chasers rated player-b-player – by their own manager Claudio Ranieri |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/leicesters-title-chasers-rated-player-7344295 |accessdate=11 June 2016 |work=The Mirror |date=11 May 2016}}</ref> Whilst playing every match, Albrighton scored two goals, with his second coming in Leicester's crucial 4–0 win over Swansea on 24 April.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Leicester City vs Swansea City |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36065530 |accessdate=8 June 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2016}}</ref> He was rewarded with a new four-year contract in August 2016.<ref name="Marc Albrighton: Leicester City midfielder signs four-year contract">{{cite|title = Marc Albrighton: Leicester City midfielder signs four-year contract|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37224897|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 30 August 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 14 September 2016, Albrighton scored the club's first ever [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] goal in a 3–0 win over [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]] at the [[Jan Breydel Stadium]].<ref name="Leicester's Marc Albrighton says Champions League goal will live with him forever">{{cite|title = Leicester's Marc Albrighton says Champions League goal will live with him forever|url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10579303/leicesters-marc-albrighton-says-champions-league-goal-will-live-with-him-forever|publisher = Sky Sports|author = Nathan Orr|date = 15 September 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}}</ref> He was the first Leicester player to score in a European competition since [[Muzzy Izzet]] against [[Red Star Belgrade]] in September 2000.<ref name="Club Brugge 0-3 Leicester City">{{cite|title = Club Brugge 0–3 Leicester City|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37331303|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Patrick Jennings|date = 14 September 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}}</ref> Albrighton described the goal as "probably one of the greatest achievements of my career so far".<ref name="Leicester's Marc Albrighton says Champions League goal will live with him forever"/>
On 25 February 2017, reports emerged alleging that Albrighton was among several teammates who met with chairman [[Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha]] following their 2–1 Champions League defeat at Sevilla on 22 February,<ref name="Sevilla 2-1 Leicester">{{cite|title = Sevilla 2–1 Leicester|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39043648|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Phil Dawkes|date = 22 February 2017|accessdate = 21 October 2017}}</ref> which led to manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] being sacked. Albrighton dismissed the claims as "totally incorrect".<ref name=" Marc Albrighton denies involvement in Claudio Ranieri's exit from Leicester">{{cite|title = Marc Albrighton denies involvement in Claudio Ranieri's exit from Leicester |url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10783294/marc-albrighton-denies-involvement-in-claudio-ranieris-exit-from-leicester|publisher = Sky Sports|date = 26 February 2017|accessdate = 21 October 2017}}</ref>
In Leicester City's Champions League Last 16 tie against [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] on 14 March 2017, Albrighton scored the second goal for the hosts which capped off a remarkable win, sealing a 3–2 aggregate win and progression to the Quarter finals.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39248930 |title=Leicester City 2–0 Sevilla (3–2 agg) |date=14 March 2017 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
==International career== On 2 April 2009, Albrighton made his debut for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under 20s]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/villa-winger-albrighton-stars-england-victory-over-italy-236169 |title=Villa winger Albrighton stars in England victory over Italy |publisher=tribalfootball.com |date=2 April 2009 |accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for [[England national under-21 football team|U21 team]] in September 2010 during their Euro 2011 qualifying play-offs and scored just fifteen minutes after coming on as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web |title=England U21 3–0 Lithuania U21 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8974671.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 September 2010}}</ref>
==Personal life== Albrighton confirmed to the ''[[Birmingham Mail]]'' that his dreams came true in playing for Aston Villa, the team he has supported since a young age.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/boyhood-aston-villa-fan-marc-146530 |title=Boyhood Aston Villa fan Marc Albrighton dreams of being Second City survival derby hero |first=Mat |last=Kendrick |date=14 January 2011}}</ref> He named former Villa players [[David Ginola]], [[Benito Carbone]] and Robert Pires as some of his footballing role models,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2154591,00.html |title=Albrighton determined to keep thrilling the claret and blue faithful |publisher=Aston Villa F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101018184352/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2154591,00.html |archivedate=18 October 2010}}</ref> along with [[England national football team|England]] legend [[David Beckham]] to whom he has been compared due to crossing ability and technique.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2248436,00.html |title=Role model Beckham an inspiration for wing wonder Albrighton | Aston Villa |publisher=Aston Villa F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923191349/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2248436,00.html |archivedate=23 September 2015}}</ref>
Albrighton became a father for the first time on 19 February 2012 when his partner Chloe Fulford gave birth to a baby daughter, Matilda Beau, in [[Sutton Coldfield]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/aston-villa-star-marc-albrighton-179704 |title=Aston Villa star Marc Albrighton keeps eye on the ball at daughter's birth |first=Birmingham |last=Mail |date=24 February 2012}}</ref> Fulford's mother, Sue Davey, was killed in the [[2015 Sousse attacks|Tunisian terror attacks]] in June 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/28/leicester-marc-albrighton-partner-mother-tunisia-massacre |title=Mother of Leicester winger Marc Albrighton's partner killed in Tunisia massacre |work=The Guardian |date=28 June 2015 |accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref>

'''Danny Ward''' (born {{birth date|df=yes|1980|6|15}}), also known by the [[nickname]] of '''"Wardy"''',<ref name="Andrew Henderson explains why he left London and his successor, Danny Ward">{{cite web|url=http://www.totalrl.com/andrew-henderson-explains-left-london-successor-danny-ward|title=Andrew Henderson explains why he left London and his successor, Danny Ward|publisher=Total RL|date=8 November 2017|accessdate=8 November 2017}}</ref> is the head coach of the [[London Broncos]] in the [[Super League]], and an English former professional [[rugby league]] footballer who played in the 1990s, 2000s and 2010s. At international level, he played for [[Great Britain national rugby league team|Great Britain]], and at club level for the [[Leeds Rhinos]], [[Castleford Tigers]], [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] and [[London Broncos#2006–2011: Harlequins Rugby League|Harlequins RL]] in the [[Super League]].
Ward was previously [[Andrew Henderson (rugby league)|Andrew Henderson]]'s assistant coach at the [[London Broncos]], and had held this position since 2015. Prior to this, he was head coach of the Under-19s.
==Background== Ward was born in [[Dewsbury]], [[West Yorkshire]], England.
==Leeds Rhinos== Ward is the son of former Leeds captain and coach [[David Ward (rugby league)|David Ward]]. He was signed for Leeds from Dewsbury Moor, and he made his début as a substitute against [[Sheffield Eagles]] in 1999. He was named the Leeds Alliance Player of the Year in 2000, before becoming a regular first team member the following season.
Ward first played at international level for the Great Britain Academy before being selected for [[John Kear]]'s England Under-21 squad for the tour of South Africa at the end of the 2001 season. England won the First Test 112–6 in the first test and the second 74–14. In 2002 he was selected in the England 'A' squad to play New Zealand at [[Griffin Park]], losing 12–34. He then was part of the squad to tour Fiji and Tonga. One of his highlights in 2002 was a [[Drop goal#Rugby league|drop goal]] in a victory at the Boulevard on his 21st birthday.
Ward emulated his father by playing in the [[Challenge Cup]] Final in 2003. In 2004 he made 14 first team starts and 12 substitute appearances, and scored a [[try]] in the 46–28 win over Wakefield. Ward played for the [[Leeds Rhinos]] at {{rlp|pr}} in their [[2004 Super League Grand Final]] victory against the [[Bradford Bulls]]. In 2004 Ward made the transition into the senior Great Britain team making his début as a substitute against New Zealand in the Tri Nations competition. [[Image:Danny Ward.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Ward in action for Harlequins RL]] As [[Super League IX]] champions, the Rhinos faced [[2004 NRL season]] premiers, the [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs|Bulldogs]] in the [[2005 World Club Challenge]]. Ward played as a {{rlp|pr}} in Leeds' 39–32 victory. In his final season with Leeds, Ward scored a try in the [[2005 Challenge Cup]] Final against Hull and in the Grand Final qualifying win at St. Helens that took the Rhinos back to [[Old Trafford]] for the Grand Final. He played for the Rhinos at {{rlp|pr}} in their [[2005 Super League Grand Final]] loss against [[Bradford Bulls]]. He left Leeds before the 2006 Super League season to join Castleford.
==Castleford Tigers==
At the beginning of the 2006's [[Super League XI]], Ward was released after an unsavoury incident. He joined the [[Castleford Tigers]], who had just been promoted from National League One. Ward adapted well to his new surroundings and one of his highlights that year was a try in the 31–30 victory over his former employers at the Jungle. However, his efforts were not enough to save Castleford from relegation.
==Hull Kingston Rovers==
For the 2007 season, he like [[Luke Dyer]], a teammate of his at Castleford, moved east to pastures new at Craven Park with [[Hull Kingston Rovers]]. So far, Ward has yet to make the impact that he did at both Leeds and Castleford, but his presence presents a danger to any defence in the whole of [[Super League]].
==Harlequins Rugby League== He was released from Hull KR on 17 September 2007. He signed a two-year deal with [[London Broncos#Harlequins RL .282006.E2.80.932011.29|Harlequins]] starting from the 2008 season.<ref name="Prop Ward secures Harlequins move">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_league/super_league/london/7012934.stm|title=Prop Ward secures Harlequins move|publisher=BBC|date=25 September 2007|accessdate=25 September 2007}}</ref>
==Coaching career== Ward was the head coach of the [[London Broncos]] Under-19s for the 2014 and 2015 seasons. He was currently the assistant coach in 2015 and 2017.
He was promoted to head coach from the beginning of the 2018 season. Ward took charge of his first professional game with a 56-12 victory over the [[Barrow Raiders]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://londonbroncosrl.com/news/broncos-beat-barrow-with-storming-win-in-season-opener/ |title=Broncos beat Barrow with storming win in season opener|work=London Broncos|date=7 February 2018|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>

Academy|Sheffield United]] | years1 = 2011–2014 | clubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] | caps1 = 134 | goals1 = 9 | years2 = 2014–2017 | clubs2 = [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] | caps2 = 54 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2015 | clubs3 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps3 = 16 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2017– | clubs4 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps4 = 64 | goals4 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2012 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2017– | nationalteam2 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps2 = 17 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | club-update = 23:56, 22 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:56, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Jacob Harry Maguire''' (born 5 March 1993) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] for {{English football updater|LeicestC}} club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
Born in [[Sheffield]], he came through the youth system at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] before graduating to the first team in 2011. He totalled 166 professional games for the Blades and was their [[Sheffield United F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] three consecutive times, also featuring in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)|PFA Team of the Year]] for [[EFL League One|League One]] as many times. In 2014, he transferred to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for £2.5 million, who loaned him to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2015. He joined Leicester City in 2017 for a potential £17 million fee.
Maguire played one match for [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] in 2012. In October 2017, he made his senior debut, and he was chosen for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] squad.
==Club career== ===Sheffield United=== [[File:Harry Maguire SUFC jrs1967 Owned Image.png|thumb|upright|Maguire playing for [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in 2011]]
Maguire was born in [[Sheffield]], South Yorkshire.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-first=Glenda|editor1-last=Rollin|editor2-first=Jack|editor2-last=Rollin |title=Sky Sports Football Yearbook 2012–2013 |year=2012 |publisher=Headline Publishing Group |location=London |isbn=978-0-7553-6356-8 |page=526 |edition=43rd}}</ref> After coming through the youth system at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], and with the team struggling against relegation, he was promoted to the first-team squad, making his debut after coming on as a half-time substitute and winning the man of the match award in a home match against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in April 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sheffield Utd vs Cardiff City |url=http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10418~52363,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=12 April 2011 |accessdate=12 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525022120/http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10418~52363,00.html |archivedate=25 May 2015}}</ref> He made four further appearances that season but could not prevent the club from slipping into League One.
Having cemented his place in the first team Maguire scored his first goal for the Blades in a 2–0 win at [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on the opening day of the [[2011–12 Football League One|2011–12 League One season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Blades too sharp for Latics |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3407137,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=7 August 2011}}</ref> Having been ever present from the start of the season Maguire was handed an extended deal in October to keep him at [[Bramall Lane]] until 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=Long-term deal for Harry |url=http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~2486883,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=19 October 2011 |accessdate=19 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916174643/http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~2486883,00.html |archivedate=16 September 2016}}</ref> He continued in great form as the Blades pushed for promotion from [[EFL League One|League One]] and was rewarded at the end of the season when he was named as both "Player of the Year" and "Young Player of the Year" by the club.<ref name="pfa 2012">{{cite news |title=Evans named in League One team |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/league1/news/20120422/evans-named-in-league-one-team_2293324_2744947|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130420035518/http://www.football-league.co.uk/league1/news/20120422/evans-named-in-league-one-team_2293324_2744947|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=29 April 2012 |publisher=The Football League |date=23 April 2012}}</ref> The BBC's Match of the Day magazine selected Maguire in its League One Team of The Year for 2011–12.<ref name="pfa 2012"/>
Maguire went into the following season as first choice in the centre of defence and his good form continued as he scored a brace in a [[Football League Trophy]] tie in a 4–1 victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] at [[Meadow Lane]] on 17 October 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/274528/report |title=Blades hammer Magpies in JPT |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 October 2012 |accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref> By the end of February 2013 Maguire had made his 100th start for the Blades in a 0–0 draw against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] at [[Bramall Lane]] at the age of just 19.<ref>{{cite news |title=Milestone for Blades teenager |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11683/8529188/Milestone-for-Blades-teenager |accessdate=1 March 2013 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=28 February 2013}}</ref>
On 21 June 2014 it was revealed that United had offered Maguire an improved contract amid interest from [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in signing Maguire with United already rejecting a £1 million and an improved £1.5 million bid from Wolves.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sheffield United: Blades made fresh offer to defender |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheff-utd/sheffield-united-blades-made-fresh-offer-to-defender-1-6686126 |accessdate=22 June 2014 |newspaper=Sheffield Star |date=21 June 2014}}</ref>
===Hull City=== [[File:Harry Maguire 2016-05-28 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Maguire following [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]'s victory over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in the [[2016 Football League Championship play-off Final|2016 Championship play-off Final]]]]
On 29 July 2014, Maguire joined [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in a deal worth £2.5 million, signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tigers Complete Maguire And Robertson Deals |url=http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-magure-robertson-double-signing-1789887.aspx |publisher=Hull City A.F.C. |accessdate=29 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729142146/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-magure-robertson-double-signing-1789887.aspx |archivedate=29 July 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He made his debut for the Tigers on 21 August in the [[UEFA Europa League]] play-off round first leg away to [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|Lokeren]] of Belgium, a 1–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite news |title=KSC Lokeren 1–0 Hull City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28878317 |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2014}}</ref> He did not make his [[Premier League]] debut until 20 December, when he replaced the injured [[Curtis Davies]] for the final 13 minutes of a home loss by the same score against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Premier League: Ki Sung-yueng's goal gives Swansea 1–0 win at Hull |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/hull-city-vs-swansea/313548 |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=22 December 2014}}</ref>
After making only six appearances across all competitions at Hull, Maguire joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] of the Championship on a one-month loan deal on 10 February 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31359454 |title=Harry Maguire: Wigan Athletic sign Hull City defender on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 February 2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> A week later, he debuted in a 1–0 win at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Maguire reflects on victorious debut |url=https://www.wiganathletic.com/news/2015/february/maguire-reflects-on-victorious-debut/ |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C. |date=18 February 2015}}</ref> On 28 February, he scored a header from [[Jermaine Pennant]]'s cross in a 3–1 win away to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackpool 1–3 Wigan Athletic |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31562249 |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 February 2015}}</ref> Having played as many games in his month-long loan as he had for Hull in the first half of the season, Maguire's stay at the [[DW Stadium]] was extended until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Maguire: Wigan extend Hull City defender's loan deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31869124 |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 March 2015}}</ref>
While Maguire was out on loan, Hull had been relegated to the Championship. On 28 May 2016, they won promotion back with a 1–0 [[2016 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]] win over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] at [[Wembley Stadium]], with him replacing goalscorer [[Mohamed Diamé]] in the final minute.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hull City 1–0 Sheffield Wednesday |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36348885 |accessdate=8 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 May 2016}}</ref>
In 2016–17, manager [[Mike Phelan]] made Maguire into a first-team regular.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/11096728/harry-maguires-rise-from-sheffield-united-to-leicester-and-england |title=Harry Maguire's rise from Sheffield United to Leicester and England |first=Nick |last=Wright |publisher=Sky Sports |date=25 October 2017 |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> Maguire scored his first goal for Hull in a 2–1 [[EFL Cup]] win against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 25 October 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37686652 |title=Bristol City 1–2 Hull |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> Maguire captained Hull City in their league victory against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 5 April 2017 and scored his first Premier League goal in the 4–2 win.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39426885 |title=Hull City 4–2 Middlesbrough |date=5 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> In a season that ended with relegation, he was voted Hull's Player of the Year by both the fans and the players.<ref name=HA/>
===Leicester City=== On 15 June 2017, Maguire signed for Premier League club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on a five-year contract for an initial £12 million fee, potentially rising to £17 million with add-ons.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Maguire: Leicester City sign Hull City defender in £17m deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40271696 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 June 2017 |accessdate=16 June 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 11 August as the season began with a 4–3 loss at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40822513 |title=Arsenal 4–3 Leicester City |first=Jonathan |last=Jurejko |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2017 |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> and eight days later he scored his first goal for the Foxes, heading in [[Riyad Mahrez]]'s corner to conclude a 2–0 win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] at the [[King Power Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40908332 |title=Leicester City 2–0 Brighton & Hove Albion |first=Luke |last=Reddy |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 August 2017 |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> He played in every minute of the [[2017–18 Leicester City F.C. season|2017–18 season]] and was awarded player of the season, as well as players' player of the season at the club's end of season awards.<ref name="LCFCAwards">{{cite web |url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/675477/maguire-bags-a-brace-of-awards-at-end-of-season-dinner/featured |title=Maguire Bags A Brace Of Awards At End Of Season Dinner |first=Sam |last=Stevens |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=1 May 2018 |accessdate=7 July 2018}}</ref>
Amid speculation about a transfer to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] for a potential world record fee for a defender, Maguire's Leicester manager [[Claude Puel]] confirmed on transfer deadline day of 9 August 2018 that Maguire would stay at the club, his only travel to Manchester being to face United with the Leicester squad in the fixture the evening after.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/11466775/claude-puel-says-world-record-bid-for-harry-maguire-would-be-rejected |title=Claude Puel says world record bid for Harry Maguire would be rejected |last=Gallagher |first=Danny |publisher=Sky Sports |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Harry Maguire and Kieran Tripper 2018 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Maguire during training with [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]]
Maguire was called up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]] for the first time in November 2012 for a friendly against [[Northern Ireland national under-21 football team|Northern Ireland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/2012/maguire-waghorn-called |title=Duo called up to under-21s |publisher=The Football Association |date=11 November 2012 |accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref> [[Danny Wilson (footballer, born 1960)|Danny Wilson]] stated "He has got a fantastic maturity for his age, he takes everything in his stride and nothing fazes him. I don't expect this call-up to either because he is such a level headed character."<ref>{{cite web |title=Recognition deserved |url=http://www.sufc.co.uk/news/article/20121112-recognition-deserved-481676.aspx |accessdate=12 November 2012 |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=12 November 2012}}</ref> Maguire duly made his England under-21 debut as a substitute in the 60th minute, coming on for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]'s [[Andre Wisdom]] in a 2–0 win against Northern Ireland Under-21s at [[Bloomfield Road]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Harry makes England bow |url=http://www.sufc.co.uk/news/article/20121113-harry-makes-england-bow-481297.aspx |accessdate=13 November 2012 |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=13 November 2012}}</ref>
On 24 August 2017, [[England national football team|England]] manager [[Gareth Southgate]] included Maguire in his squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]] matches against [[Malta national football team|Malta]] and [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=England: Nathaniel Chalobah and Harry Maguire in squad for World Cup qualifiers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41039802 |accessdate=24 August 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2017}}</ref> He made his debut when starting in England's 1–0 away win over [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]], which was the team's final match in their successful 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification campaign.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Lithuania 0–1 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41457291 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 October 2017 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
Maguire was named in the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref> He assisted [[Harry Kane]]'s winner against [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] on 18 June 2018 in England's World Cup opener. England won 2–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://englandfootball.org/2018/06/18/review-tunisia-1-2-england-18-06-18/ |title=Review – Tunisia 1–2 England – 18–06–18 |date=18 June 2018 |publisher=}}</ref> Maguire scored his first England goal on 7 July 2018 with a 30th-minute header from [[Ashley Young]]'s cross in a 2–0 win over [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in the quarter-final.<ref name=Sweden/>
==Personal life== Maguire's brothers, Joe and [[Laurence Maguire|Laurence]], are also footballers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chesterfield-fc.co.uk/teams/first-team/defender/laurence-maguire/ |title=Laurence Maguire – Defender – First Team |publisher=Chesterfield F.C. |accessdate=8 December 2017}}</ref> He attended [[St Mary's Roman Catholic High School, Chesterfield]] and returned to present a signed shirt to the school.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.derbyshiretimes.co.uk/news/chesterfield-school-welcomes-back-england-star-and-his-spireite-brother-1-8952242 |title=Chesterfield school welcomes back England star and his Spireite brother |publisher=}}</ref> He is engaged to Fern Hawkins.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/newsbeat-44765085 |title=Harry Maguire memes himself with 'put the bins out' caption |first=Shiona |last=McCallum |publisher=BBC News |date=9 July 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref>

He started his professional career at [[Grasshopper Club Zürich|Grasshopper]] in 2004, then moved to [[FC Thun]] a year later. After success there, Jakupović joined [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] in March 2006. In September 2011, he joined [[Aris F.C. (Thessaloniki)|Aris]], and in 2012, he moved to Hull. In 2017, he left Hull City after their relegation back to the [[EFL Championship]] to join [[Premier League]] side, [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].
Having played at under-21 level for both Bosnia and Switzerland, he earned his only senior cap for the latter in 2008, and was part of their squad at [[UEFA Euro 2008]].
==Club career== ===Early career=== Jakupović was born in [[Prijedor]], SFR Yugoslavia, present-day [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. He moved to [[Switzerland]] at a young age due to the [[Bosnian War]] and started his professional career at [[Grasshopper Club Zürich|Grasshopper]] in 2004. He then moved to [[FC Thun]] in 2005. After a successful spell at FC Thun, Jakupović joined [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] in March 2006.
===Grasshopper=== Jakupović moved on a year-long [[loan (sports)|loan]] to Grasshopper on 30 August 2007. He scored a 94th-minute equaliser against [[BSC Young Boys]] in his third match for the club, earning Grasshopper a 3–3 draw. During the season Jakupović forced [[Fabio Coltorti]] to the bench as his backup. At the end of the 2007–08 season, Jakupović extended his loan at Grasshopper for another year, which meant new signing goalkeeper [[Massimo Colomba]] was benched.
===Lokomotiv return=== On 31 August 2009, Jakupović was confirmed as part of the Lokomotiv Moscow squad, with [[Ivan Pelizzoli]] leaving on loan to join [[U.C. AlbinoLeffe|AlbinoLeffe]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer news |url=http://www.eng.fclm.ru/?info-centr/news/8A24EBEEB1AF430C85617994A845CE1E/BA1B315FF3F144A483735B8B616EDC9C#news_BA1B315FF3F144A483735B8B616EDC9C |publisher=Lokomotiv Moscow |date=1 September 2009 |accessdate=5 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005003503/http://eng.fclm.ru/?info-centr%2Fnews%2F8A24EBEEB1AF430C85617994A845CE1E%2FBA1B315FF3F144A483735B8B616EDC9C#news_BA1B315FF3F144A483735B8B616EDC9C |archivedate=5 October 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> Due to the number of foreigners in the Lokomotiv squad, Jakupović was asked to go out on loan again. In December, Jakupović went on trial at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and had a successful week.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spurs set to land Swiss keeper Eldin Jakupovic on loan|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Spurs-set-to-land-Swiss-keeper-Eldin-Jakupovic-on-loan-article243121.html|publisher=The Mirror|accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref> However, due to various reasons a deal could not be completed with Lokomotiv Moscow. After a turbulent time with the Lokomotiv management, Jakupović was allowed to be released.
===Olympiakos Volou=== Jakupović had a fine season with [[Olympiakos Volou 1937 F.C.|Olympiakos Volou]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2012}} After they were [[promotion and relegation|relegated]] to the [[Delta Ethniki]], Jakupović left the team.
===Aris=== On 30 September 2011, Jakupović joined [[Aris F.C. (Thessaloniki)|Aris]], with three other ex-teammates, [[Noe Acosta]], [[Javier Umbides]] and [[Khalifa Sankare]]. He made his debut on 5 November 2011, against [[Olympiakos SFP]], which finished 2–3.
===Hull City=== On 20 March 2012, Jakupović joined English [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on trial, and after impressing in training and a friendly match Hull manager [[Nick Barmby]] expressed a desire to sign Jakupović on a permanent contract.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tigers in Jakupovic talks|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11714/7620782/Tigers-in-Jakupovic-talks|publisher=Sky Sports|date=23 March 2012|accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> Following the sacking of Nick Barmby, Jakupović had trials with Ipswich Town. On 9 July 2012, Jakupović signed for Hull City on a two-year contract, becoming [[Steve Bruce]]'s first full signing as manager.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull agree keeper deal|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11714/7883832/Hull-agree-keeper-deal|accessdate=9 July 2012|newspaper=Sky Sports|date=9 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~2836048,00.html |title=Tigers Complete Jakupovic Signing |date=9 July 2012 |work=The Tigers Official Website |publisher=Hull City A.F.C. |accessdate=9 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711235940/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10338~2836048%2C00.html |archivedate=11 July 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> He officially joined the team on their pre-season training session in Portugal. He made his debut in a 3–1 friendly win against [[North Ferriby United F.C.|North Ferriby United]] on 16 July 2012. His first Championship match for The Tigers came on 21 December 2012 at [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], when he played in a 2–1 victory as Hull moved into second place in the Championship table.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20723125| title = Derby 1–2 Hull| date = 21 December 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 8 January 2013}}</ref> This was followed up by three more league appearances, all of which consisted of clean sheets.
In January 2014 Jakupović joined [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on loan until 8 February.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.leytonorient.com/news/article/jakupovic-signs-070113-1279511.aspx|title = Jakupovic Signs|publisher = Leyton Orient FC|date = 7 January 2014|accessdate = 7 January 2014}}</ref> On 29 January 2014, Jakupović was recalled to parent club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref name="Hull City recall keeper Eldin Jakupovic from Leyton Orient">{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25951807 | title = Hull City recall keeper Eldin Jakupovic from Leyton Orient | date = 29 January 2014 | publisher = BBC | work = BBC Sport | accessdate = 29 January 2014}}</ref> On 13 February 2014, Jakupović re-joined [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] until 17 May 2014,<ref>{{cite web |title=NEWS: Eldin Jakupovic Returns |url=http://www.leytonorient.com/news/article/jakupovic-returns-130214-1356722.aspx |work=Leyton Orient FC |date=13 February 2014|accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> but was again recalled on 27 March 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26768875 | title = Hull City recall keeper Eldin Jakupovic from Leyton Orient | date = 27 March 2014 | publisher = BBC | work = BBC Sport | accessdate = 27 March 2014}}</ref>
On 9 July 2014 Jakupović signed a new two-year contract with Hull City,<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-jakupovic-new-contract-1730809.aspx |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140709174528/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-jakupovic-new-contract-1730809.aspx |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 9 July 2014 |title = New Two-Year Contract For Jakupovic |date = 9 July 2014 |work = The Tigers Official Website |publisher = Hull City A.F.C. |accessdate = 9 July 2014 }}</ref> and began their [[Premier League]] campaign as third-choice goalkeeper behind [[Allan McGregor]] and [[Steve Harper|Steven Harper]]. He made his first appearance of the season on 18 October away to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] as a substitute when Harper injured his arm before half-time, and did not concede until [[Danny Welbeck]] equalised for 2–2 in added time.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Winton|first1=Richard|title=Arsenal 2–2 Hull|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29580152|accessdate=1 November 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=18 October 2014}}</ref> A week later he started for the first time in the division, keeping a clean sheet in a goalless draw against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Emons|first1=Michael|title=Liverpool 0–0 Hull|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29670447|accessdate=1 November 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=25 October 2014}}</ref>
Jakupović started for Hull against Arsenal in the [[FA Cup]] fifth round on 20 February 2016, at the [[Emirates Stadium]]. He made 12 saves to earn his side a 0–0 draw, which led to a replay at the [[KCOM Stadium|KC Stadium]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = FA Cup: Arsenal 0–0 Hull City highlights|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35622349|website = BBC Sport|access-date = 20 February 2016}}</ref>
On 24 June 2016 Jakupović signed a new 2-year deal with Hull City.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36619947 | title = Eldin Jakupovic: Hull City goalkeeper signs new deal | date = 24 June 2016 | work = BBC Sport | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 24 June 2016}}</ref> Since McGregor was out with a back injury that ruled him out for about six month,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11714/10498669/hull-city-duo-allan-mcgregor-and-alex-bruce-suffer-injuries |title=Hull City duo Allan McGregor and Alex Bruce suffer injuries |date=11 July 2016 |publisher=SkySports|accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref> Jakupović started off the 2016–17 season against Premier League Champions, [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and helped earn the Tigers a 2–1 victory on opening day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36994520 |title=Hull City 2-1 Leicester City |date=13 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sports|accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref>
===Leicester City===
On 19 July 2017, following Hull City's relegation back to the second tier of English football, Jakupović signed a three-year deal with [[Premier League]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.lcfc.com/news/439614/leicester-city-sign-goalkeeper-eldin-jakupovi/featured | title = Leicester City Sign Goalkeeper Eldin Jakupovic | date = 19 July 2017 | work = LCFC | publisher = LCFC | accessdate = 19 July 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on [[2017–18 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third round match against [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42519386 | title = Fleetwood Town 0–0 Leicester City | date = 6 January 2018 | work = BBC Sport | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 9 January 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:080603 jakupovic.jpg|thumb|Jakupović in training for the Swiss national team in June 2008]] Jakupović has dual citizenship, both [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian]] and [[Switzerland|Swiss]], and has represented both at under-21 level.
He has played for Bosnia and Herzegovina U21 for two competitive matches,<ref>http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/history/season=2006/round=1910/match=74413/report=lu.html</ref><ref>http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/history/season=2006/round=1910/match=74414/report=lu.html</ref> and a friendly match against [[Austria national under-21 football team|Austria U21]] for Switzerland on 1 March 2006.
In August 2005, Jakupović received his first call-up to the Bosnia and Herzegovina national squad which was a match against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] and [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]], however he did not accept the call up. In March 2007, Jakupović was asked again to play for the senior [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] against Norway, but declined the offer. Jakupović was included in the Swiss [[UEFA Euro 2008]] squad. He made his debut on 20 August 2008 in a friendly match against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]]. He was called up for the first two matches of [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|qualification]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=863881.html|title=Hitzfeld snubs unfit Senderos|agency=Reuters|date=28 August 2008|accessdate=1 July 2009}}</ref> but was an unused substitute.
In October 2008, Jakupović said that he would not play again for the Swiss national team due to family reasons.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.football.ch/nm/de/Archiv_A-Team.aspx?vNews=1&newsID=84|title=Djourou fällt aus|publisher=football.ch|date=13 October 2008|accessdate=1 July 2009|language=German}}</ref>

==Club career== ===Djurgårdens IF=== Amartey started out playing for second tier club [[International Allies F.C.|International Allies]] in Ghana where he was spotted as a sixteen-year-old by [[Magnus Pehrsson]] who was on a scouting trip in [[Africa]] during his preparation to take over as manager of [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]]. When Pearson became manager he secured the transfer rights for Amartey from the day he turned 18.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dif.se/2011/08/26/mp-om-de-nya-ghananerna/ |title=MP om de nya ghananerna |date=26 August 2011 |publisher=Djurgårdens IF |language=Swedish |accessdate=1 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910135527/http://dif.se/2011/08/26/mp-om-de-nya-ghananerna/ |archivedate=10 September 2011 |df=}}</ref> To help prepare Amartey for his future permanent move to [[Sweden]] in 2013 the club brought him over for shorter periods of time in both 2011 and 2012 where he got to play for the club's U21 team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dif.se/2011/08/27/afrikanska-loften-pa-kaknas/ |title=Afrikanska löften på Kaknäs |date=27 August 2011 |publisher=Djurgårdens IF |language=Swedish |accessdate=1 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129133434/http://dif.se/2011/08/27/afrikanska-loften-pa-kaknas/ |archivedate=29 January 2013 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dif.se/2012/07/11/daniel-amartey-ansluter-i-augusti/ |title=Daniel Amartey ansluter i augusti |date=11 July 2012 |publisher=Djurgårdens IF |language=Swedish |accessdate=1 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127164406/http://dif.se/2012/07/11/daniel-amartey-ansluter-i-augusti/ |archivedate=27 January 2013 |df=}}</ref>
Amartey made his [[Svenska Cupen]] debut on 3 March 2013 against [[Umeå FC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dif.se/2013/03/03/ertons-hattrick-sankte-umea/ |title=Ertons hattrick sänkte Umeå |date=3 March 2013 |publisher=Djurgårdens IF |language=Swedish |accessdate=12 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308015912/http://dif.se/2013/03/03/ertons-hattrick-sankte-umea/ |archivedate=8 March 2013 |df=}}</ref> He then made his league debut in the [[2013 Allsvenskan]] opening game away against [[Helsingborgs IF]] on 31 March.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://svenskfotboll.se/allsvenskan/match/?scr=result&fmid=1995655&html5=1 |title=Allsvenskan, herrar Matchinformation: Helsingborgs IF – Djurgården |date=31 March 2013 |publisher=SvFF |language=Swedish |accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> Amartey was praised by the media for his strong start to the 2013 season, and foreign clubs like [[FC Schalke 04]] and [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]] started to scout him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotboll/sverige/allsvenskan/djurgarden/article16876660.ab |title=Månsson: Nu har det vänt för Djurgården |date=30 May 2013 |work=[[Aftonbladet]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotboll/sverige/allsvenskan/djurgarden/article17017046.ab |title=Han jagas av storklubbar |date=25 June 2013 |work=[[Aftonbladet]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref> On 26 May he scored his first ever goal for the club when he headed home the 1–1 equalizer in the [[2013 Svenska Cupen Final]] which Djurgården eventually lost against [[IFK Göteborg]] on penalties.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://svenskfotboll.se/cuper-och-serier/arkiv/cuper-serier/2013/05/goteborg-cupmastare/ |title=IFK Göteborg cupmästare efter straffar |date=26 May 2013 |publisher=[[Swedish Football Association]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> After his first season in the Swedish league as an eighteen-year-old Amartey was ranked as the 10th best player in the league by newspaper [[Expressen]] and 18th best by [[Aftonbladet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expressen.se/sport/fotboll/allsvenskan/har-ar-allsvenskans-50-basta-spelare---ar-2013/ |title=Här är allsvenskans 50 bästa spelare – år 2013 |date=6 November 2013 |work=[[Expressen]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotboll/sverige/allsvenskan/article17728499.ab |title=Allsvenskans 50 bästa spelare |date=26 October 2013 |work=[[Aftonbladet]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> In November 2013 Amartey confirmed that he was in talks with [[Liverpool F.C.]] over a possible move to the English club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/11/02/djurgarden-star-daniel-amartey-confirms-transfer-talks-with-liverpool-4170663/ |title=Djurgarden star Daniel Amartey confirms transfer talks with Liverpool |date=2 November 2013 |publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref>
===Copenhagen=== In July 2014, Amartey moved to [[F.C. Copenhagen]] for a fee of €2.5 million plus add ons, and made his [[Danish Superliga|Superliga]]-debut on 20 July in a match against [[Silkeborg IF]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.in/football/match?gameId=398600|title=Silkeborg IF vs. FC Copenhagen - Football Match Summary - July 20, 2014|website=ESPN|language=en|access-date=2019-02-19}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== [[File:Daniel Amartey and Jamie Vardy (30297726041).jpg|thumb|Amartey playing for Leicester City in October 2016]] On 22 January 2016, Amartey joined [[Premier League]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on a four-and-a-half-year contract for a fee around the region of up to £6 million.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Leicester City Sign Ghana Star Daniel Amartey |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/leicester-city-sign-ghana-star-daniel-amartey-2914554.aspx |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=22 January 2016}}</ref> In his first season in his new country, Amartey featured five times as his team Leicester City won the Premier League title. He made his debut for the club on 27 February 2016, in 1–0 win over [[Norwich City]] at the [[King Power Stadium]].<ref name="Leicester City 1-0 Norwich City">{{cite|title = Leicester City 1–0 Norwich City|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35619679|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 27 February 2016}}</ref>
In the 2016–17 season, Amartey became a first team regular following the departure of [[N'Golo Kanté]].<ref name="Leicester City's Daniel Amartey filling the Kanté void will take time">{{cite|title = Leicester City's Daniel Amartey filling the Kante void will take time|url = http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-s-daniel-amartey-filling-the-kante-void-will-take-time/story-29763963-detail/story.html|work = Leicester Mercury|date = 29 September 2016|accessdate = 5 January 2017|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160930171817/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-s-daniel-amartey-filling-the-kante-void-will-take-time/story-29763963-detail/story.html|archivedate = 30 September 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> partnering teammate [[Danny Drinkwater]] in the central midfield role.<ref name="Daniel Amartey will be the Leicester star to replace N'Golo Kante, says Copenhagen boss Stale Solbakken">{{cite|title = Daniel Amartey will be the Leicester star to replace N'Golo Kante, says Copenhagen boss Stale Solbakken|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3847668/Daniel-Amartey-Leicester-star-replace-N-Golo-Kante-says-Copenhagen-boss-Stale-Solbakken.html|work = Daily Mail|date = 18 October 2016|accessdate = 5 January 2017}}</ref> While his workrate roughly equalled Kanté's, he has been unable to match his tackles and interceptions.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City: What has changed at the Premier League champions? |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38879315 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 February 2017 |accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref> Amartey scored his first goal for Leicester in an 88th-minute equaliser away at [[Stoke City]] on 17 December 2016, salvaging a 2–2 draw.<ref name="Stoke City 2-2 Leicester City">{{cite|title = Stoke City 2–2 Leicester City|publisher = BBC Sport|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38272819|date = 17 December 2016}}</ref> On 8 February 2017, just over 12 hours after returning to Leicester from international duty, Amartey played 120 minutes (including [[Overtime (sports)|AET]]) in a 3–1 [[FA Cup]] fourth-round replay win over [[Derby County]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City 3–1 Derby County Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38822191 |accessdate=8 February 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 February 2017}}</ref>
==International career== In May 2012 Amartey made his debut for the [[Ghana national under-20 football team]] in a game against [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/ghana-u-20-outscores-nigeria-in-five-goal-thriller/ |title=Ghana U20 get their revenge against Nigeira U-20 in five-goal thriller |date=25 May 2012 |publisher=Ghana Soccernet |accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> He was also selected to play in the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] but Djurgården wanted to keep him in Sweden since the tournament clashed with the [[2013 Allsvenskan]] season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expressen.se/sport/fotboll/allsvenskan/talangen-kunde-spelat-vm---stoppades-av-dif/ |title=Talangen kunde spelat VM – stoppades av Dif |date=25 June 2013 |work=[[Expressen]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref> In January 2015, Amartey played in all the group matches for Ghana at the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations, where the Black Stars finished as runners-up.
He played six times at the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]], lasting 90 minutes in every match to help Ghana finish fourth in the tournament.<ref name="Leicester City's Amartey in AFCON team of tournament - at centre-half"/> His performances saw him named in the CAF Team of the tournament.<ref name="Leicester City's Amartey in AFCON team of tournament - at centre-half">{{cite news |title=Leicester City's Amartey in AFCON team of tournament – at centre-half |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-s-amartey-in-afcon-team-of-tournament-at-centre-half/story-30114584-detail/story.html#k0HrfcHm2FCRzssh.99 |work=Leicester Mercury |author=MJClayton |date=6 February 2017 |accessdate=9 February 2017}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

| club-update = 20:37, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 18:32, 16 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Harvey Lewis Barnes''' (born 9 December 1997) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].
==Early life== Barnes is from [[Countesthorpe]]<ref>[https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/leicester-city-starlet-harvey-barnes-224715 Leicester City starlet Harvey Barnes commits future to club with four-year deal – Leicester Mercury]. Retrieved 9 March 2018.</ref> and is the son of former professional footballer [[Paul Barnes (footballer)|Paul Barnes]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester midfielder Harvey Barnes ready for biggest test of career – at Wimbledon – as team-mates host Sevilla in Champions League |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/03/13/leicester-midfielderharvey-barnes-ready-biggest-test-career/ |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=13 March 2017 |accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref> In 2009, Barnes played for Greenfield Primary School<ref>http://www.greenfield.leics.sch.uk/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://greenfieldprimary.net/|title=Greenfield Primary School|website=greenfieldprimary.net}}</ref> in the Leicestershire & Rutland Schools Football Association competition known as The Rice Bowl.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lrschoolsfa.org.uk/index.php?page=rice-bowl-winners|title=Leicestershire and Rutland Schools Football Association - Rice Bowl Winners|website=www.lrschoolsfa.org.uk}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Leicester City=== Barnes is a product of the [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] academy, which he joined at the age of nine. He signed his first professional contract with the club on 25 June 2016<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/youngsters-muskwe-and-barnes-pen-pro-leicester-city-deals-3144030.aspx |title=Youngsters Muskwe And Barnes Pen Pro Leicester City Deals |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=25 June 2016 |accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref> and on 7 December 2016 made his debut for the first team as a second-half [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 5–0 [[UEFA Champions League]] defeat to [[FC Porto]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38226552 |title=PC Porto 5–0 Leicester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2016 |accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref> During the first half of the [[2016–17 Professional U23 Development League|2016–17]] [[Professional Development League|Premier League 2]] season for [[Leicester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Leicester City U23]], Barnes scored five goals and provided assists for five others.<ref name="Milton Keynes Dons Official Site">{{cite web |url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/2016-17/dons-bring-in-premier-league-midfielder-3528614.aspx |title=Dons bring in Premier League midfielder |publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |date=20 January 2017 |accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref>
On 21 July 2017, Barnes signed a new 4-year contract, keeping him at the King Power Stadium until July 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/440794|title=Harvey Barnes Signs New Four-Year Contract|website=www.lcfc.com}}</ref> He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 19 April 2018, as a 91st minute substitute in a 0–0 draw against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester City 0–0 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43734550|accessdate=19 April 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 April 2018}}</ref>
====Milton Keynes Dons (loan)==== On 20 January 2017, Barnes joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2016–17 Milton Keynes Dons F.C. season|2016–17 season]].<ref name="Milton Keynes Dons Official Site"/> A day later, Barnes scored on his home debut as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Chuks Aneke]] in a 5–3 win over [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/2016-17/report-mk-dons-5-3-northampton-town-3531174.aspx |title=MK Dons 5–3 Northampton Town |publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |date=21 January 2017 |accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> Barnes followed his debut goal with another goal a week later, on 28 January, scoring in a 0–4 away win over rivals [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/2016-17/report-pboro-utd-0-4-dons-3541776.aspx |title=Report:P'boro Utd 0–4 MK Dons |publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |date=28 January 2017 |accessdate=28 January 2017}}</ref>
On 2 May 2017, after impressing with 6 goals in 21 appearances for the club, he was awarded Milton Keynes Dons' Young Player of the Year 2016–17 award.<ref name="Williams named Player of the Year">{{cite web |url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/2016-17/williams-named-player-of-the-year-3702868.aspx |title=Williams named Player of the Year |publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |date=2 May 2017 |accessdate=2 May 2017}}</ref>
====Barnsley (loan)==== On 11 August 2017, Barnes joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on a season long loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/448063/press-release |title=Barnes Joins Barnsley in Season-Long Loan |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=11 August 2017 |accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> The following day, he made his debut for the club as an 80th-minute substitute in a 1–2 home defeat to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40834636 |title=Barnsley 1–2 Ipswich Town |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Barnsley against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 26 August 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40983504 |title=Barnsley 3–0 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 August 2017 |accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
On 1 January 2018, Barnes was recalled from his loan spell at Barnsley and returned to Leicester City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/2018/january/barnes-leicester/ |title=Harvey Barnes Recalled By Leicester City. |publisher=Barnsley F.C. |date=1 January 2018 |accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref>
====West Bromwich Albion (loan)==== On 24 July 2018, Barnes signed a new four-year contract with Leicester and joined newly relegated Championship club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a season long loan.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Harvey Barnes: West Bromwich Albion sign Leicester City winger on loan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44941296|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Albion recruit Barnes |url=https://www.wba.co.uk/news/2018/july/albion-recruit-barnes/ |accessdate=24 July 2018 |publisher=West Bromwich Albion FC |date=24 July 2018}}</ref> He scored a spectacular goal on his league debut during a 2–1 home defeat against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 4 August 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=West Bromwich Albion 1–2 Bolton Wanderers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44989043 |accessdate=4 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 August 2018}}</ref> On 11 January 2019, Barnes was recalled by Leicester with immediate effect.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Barnes recalled by Leicester|url=https://www.wba.co.uk/news/2019/january/barnes-recalled-by-leicester/|publisher=W.B.A. FC|date=11 January 2019|accessdate=11 January 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Barnes was called up as one of six over-age players for the [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] squad entered into the [[2017 Toulon Tournament]]. He made his debut on 29 May 2017, featuring as a substitute in a 1–0 win over group rivals [[Angola national under-20 football team|Angola U20]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-foot-espoirs.com/direct_festival_foot.php?tournoi_id=2 |title=Festival International Espoirs |publisher=Festival Foot Espoirs |date=29 May 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> On 1 June 2017, Barnes scored twice in a 7–1 win over [[Cuba national under-20 football team|Cuba U20]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-foot-espoirs.com/direct_festival_foot.php?tournoi_id=8 |title=Festival International Espoirs |publisher=Festival Foot Espoirs |date=1 June 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613084504/http://www.festival-foot-espoirs.com/direct_festival_foot.php?tournoi_id=8# |archive-date=13 June 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 8 June 2017, Barnes scored another brace in the competition's semi-final, in a 3–0 win over [[Scotland national under-20 football team|Scotland U20]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-foot-espoirs.com/direct_festival_foot_uk.php?tournoi_id=19 |title=Festival International Espoirs |publisher=Festival Foot Espoirs |date=8 June 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> and on 10 June 2017 went on to score his penalty in a deciding shootout during the final against [[Ivory Coast national under-20 football team|Ivory Coast U20]], with England being victorious.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40236422 |title=Toulon Tournament: England 1–1 Ivory Coast (5–3 penalties) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 June 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> Overall, Barnes finished the tournament as joint recipient of the Golden Boot (top scorer) award with 4 goals along with teammate [[George Hirst (footballer)|George Hirst]] and Angola U20's [[Chico Banza]].
On 28 September 2017, Barnes was called up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] national team,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/sep/28/england-u20s-squad-named-for-italy-and-czech-republic-280917 |title=U20s Squad Selected |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 September 2017 |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> and on 5 October 2017 featured as a substitute in a 1–5 away friendly win over [[Italy national under-20 football team|Italy U20]].
