FSV Mainz 05|Mainz]] |caps3 = 65 |goals3 = 27 |years4 = 2015– |clubs4 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps4 = 112 |goals4 = 14 |nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 |nationalteam1 = [[Japan national under-23 football team|Japan U23]] |nationalcaps1 = 14 |nationalgoals1 = 1 |nationalyears2 = 2008– |nationalteam2 = [[Japan national football team|Japan]] |nationalcaps2 = 116 |nationalgoals2 = 50 |club-update = 19:14, 22 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 2 July 2018 }} {{nihongo|'''Shinji Okazaki'''|岡崎 慎司|Okazaki Shinji|born 16 April 1986}} is a Japanese [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]] as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] or [[attacking midfielder]]. Internationally, he is currently the top active Japan national team goalscorer and third all-time in team history with [[Japan national football team#Records|50 goals]]. He won the [[Premier League]] with Leicester in 2016. ==Club career== ===Shimizu S-Pulse=== After graduating Takigawa Daini High School in 2004, Okazaki signed full professional terms with [[Shimizu S-Pulse]] the following year. In December 2005, he made his first [[J.League Division 1|J.League]] appearance as a substitute against [[Sanfrecce Hiroshima]]. On 15 April 2007, he scored his first professional goal against [[Kawasaki Frontale]]. Okazaki ended his [[2007 J.League Division 1|first season]] as a first team player with three goals from 13 matches. Okazaki scored ten times in 27 matches during the [[2008 J. League Division 1|2008 J. League season]] and also represented S-Pulse in the [[2008 J. League Cup#Final|J. League Cup Final]], where the team lost 2–0 to [[Oita Trinita]]. He continued his promising goalscoring in the [[2009 J. League Division 1|2009]] and [[2010 J. League Division 1|2010 season]]s and, in January 2011, was signed by German side [[VfB Stuttgart]] of the [[Bundesliga]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/verpflichtung-shinji-okazaki/page/439-0-1-1296449195.html|title=Shinji Okazaki in Stuttgart|work=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=30 January 2011|date=30 January 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304203717/http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/verpflichtung-shinji-okazaki/page/439-0-1-1296449195.html|archive-date=4 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===VfB Stuttgart=== [[File:Dinamo-Stutgart (5).jpg|thumb|200px|Okazaki with the [[VfB Stuttgart]] in 2012]] On 30 January 2011, Okazaki signed a three-and-a-half-year contract with Stuttgart.{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/pk-shinji-okazaki/page/446-0-1-1296469536.html|title=Shinji Okazaki signs for VfB|publisher=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=30 January 2011|date=30 January 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304203728/http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/pk-shinji-okazaki/page/446-0-1-1296469536.html|archive-date=4 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On 17 February 2011, clearance to play for the club was granted for Okazaki by [[FIFA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/freigabe-okazaki/page/486-0-1-1297962975.html|title=Clearance for Shinji Okazaki|publisher=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=17 February 2011|date=17 February 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719112218/http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/2010/freigabe-okazaki/page/486-0-1-1297962975.html|archivedate=19 July 2011}} He made his competitive debut for VfB on the same night in a [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] match against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]]. On 20 February 2011, Okazaki made his [[Bundesliga]] debut for VfB against [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen]]. Okazaki scored his first goal against [[Hannover 96]], which he scored from outside the box.{{cite web | url = http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/sc20110509a2.html | title = Okazaki gets maiden Stuttgart goal | date = 9 May 2011 | accessdate = 25 September 2011 | work = Japan Times}} Okazaki came on as a second-half substitute for Stuttgart in their first game of the [[2011–12 Bundesliga]] season against [[FC Schalke 04]]. His side were up 2–0 and Okazaki added a goal scoring from long range in the 90th minute, sealing a 3–0 win.{{cite web | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/gamecast?id=321039&cc=5901 | title = VfB Stuttgart 3 – 0 Schalke 04 | publisher = ESPN Soccernet | date = 6 August 2011 | accessdate = 25 September 2011}} Okazaki's goal from a bicycle kick on 19 February 2012 in a Bundesliga match of VfB Stuttgart against Hannover 96 was selected [[Goal of the Month (Germany)|Goal of the Month]]. After [[Yasuhiko Okudera]] in April 1978, Okazaki was the second player from Japan to win this award in Germany.{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/news/2012/tor-des-monats-okazaki/page/1354-0-1-1331528931.html|title=Goal of the Month|publisher=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=12 March 2012|date=11 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312105945/http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/news/2012/tor-des-monats-okazaki/page/1354-0-1-1331528931.html|archivedate=12 March 2012}} Okazaki had a poor [[2012–13 VfB Stuttgart season|2012–13]] season, scoring only once in the [[2012–13 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]]. However, he scored his first goals in European competition with two goals against [[FC Steaua București]] in the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]]. ===1. FSV Mainz 05=== On 1 July 2013, Okazaki moved to [[1. FSV Mainz 05]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/news/2013/wechsel-shinji-okazaki-vfb-stuttgart/page/2370-1-1-.html|title=Shinji Okazaki moves to Mainz|work=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=25 June 2013|date=25 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023144626/http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/news/2013/wechsel-shinji-okazaki-vfb-stuttgart/page/2370-1-1-.html|archivedate=23 October 2014}} He scored his first goal for Mainz on his debut in a 3–2 win against his former club Stuttgart on the opening matchday of the [[2013–14 Bundesliga]] season.{{cite news|url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/liga/news/2013/0000264412.php|title=Okazaki and Müller fire Mainz to victory|date=11 August 2013|accessdate=13 October 2013|work=Bundesliga|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022152122/http://www.bundesliga.com/en/liga/news/2013/0000264412.php|archivedate=22 October 2013}} At the end of the season he ended with 15 league goals. Okazaki became the most prolific Japanese player in Bundesliga history on 13 September 2014, scoring his 27th and 28th league goals in Mainz's 3–1 win over [[Hertha BSC|Hertha Berlin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/german-bundesliga/match/396972/hertha-berlin-mainz/report |title=Hertha Berlin 1–3 Mainz |work=ESPNFC |date=13 September 2014 |accessdate=13 September 2014 }} ===Leicester City=== [[File:Shinji Okazaki.png|thumb|Okazaki against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] at the [[King Power Stadium]] on 17 April 2016]] On 26 June 2015, Okazaki moved to [[Premier League]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for a fee believed to be in the region of £7 million, subject to obtaining a work permit.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/shinji-okazaki-agrees-leicester-city-deal-2509148.aspx|title=Shinji Okazaki Agrees Leicester City Deal|work=Leicester City|accessdate=26 June 2015|date=26 June 2015}} He made his debut for the club on 8 August 2015 in Leicester City's 4–2 opening day win against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and scored his first goal for the club the following week in a 2–1 win against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. On 19 December 2015, Okazaki scored the winner in a 3–2 win over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] at [[Goodison Park]], to ensure that [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] topped the table at Christmas.{{cite web|url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2015/12/19/tt-48-touches-3-shots-leicester-city-star-shinji-okazaki-superb|title=Shinji Okazaki Stars in Everton Win|accessdate=20 December 2015|date=19 December 2015}} On 10 January 2016, Okazaki scored Leicester's second goal in the [[FA Cup]] clash at [[White Hart Lane]] with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] despite drawing to a late [[Harry Kane]] penalty in the 90th minute. On 14 March 2016, Okazaki scored the winning goal in a league fixture against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], a spectacular overhead strike that won Leicester City the game 1–0 and took them five points clear at the top of the [[Premier League]] table.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35741942|title=Leicester City 1–0 Newcastle United|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 May 2016|date=14 March 2016}} Okazaki went on to win the league that year thus becoming the second Japanese player to win the Premier League after [[Shinji Kagawa]].{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2016/05/04/soccer/okazaki-in-wonderland-after-leicesters-premier-league-triumph|title=Okazaki in wonderland after Leicester's Premier League triumph|work=Japan Times|accessdate=27 May 2016|date=4 May 2016}} His performances in the 2015–16 season earned him the [[Asian Footballer of the Year|Asian International Player of the Year]] award in December 2016.{{cite|title = Okazaki: I’m thrilled to win Asian award|url = https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2016/m=12/news=okazaki-i-m-thrilled-to-win-asian-award-2859619.html|publisher = FIFA|date = 12 December 2016|accessdate = 1 January 2017}} ====2016–17==== Okazaki scored twice in a 2–4 defeat to Chelsea in the third round of the 2016–17 [[EFL Cup]] on 20 September 2016.{{cite web|last1=Rose|first1=Gary|title=Leicester City 2–4 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37346049|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 September 2016}} He scored his first league goal of the season in a 3–1 win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 22 October 2016, earning him [[Man of the match]] and achieving an 84.8% pass success rate, more than any other Leicester player.{{cite|title = Leicester City 3–1 Crystal Palace|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37663854|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Aimee Lewis|date = 22 October 2016|accessdate = 9 January 2017}} On 22 November 2016, Okazaki scored in a 2–1 win over [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]] in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League group stage|Champions League group stage]], becoming the sixth Japanese player to score a [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] goal and the first since [[Keisuke Honda]] in November 2013.{{cite|title = Leicester City 2–1 Club Brugge|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38054997|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Neil Johnston|date = 22 November 2016|accessdate = 14 October 2017}} He finished the season with only three league goals.{{cite|title = Shinji Okazaki reveals secrets to Leicester City goal-scoring form|url = http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/shinji-okazaki-reveals-secrets-leicester-508090|work = Leicester Mercury|author = James Sharpe|date = 20 September 2017|accessdate = 25 September 2017}} ====2017–18==== Okazaki was in goalscoring form at the start to the 2017–18 season, scoring four goals in six appearances for Leicester in all competitions.{{cite|title = Leicester City 2–3 Liverpool Verdict: Jamie Vardy misses penalty in another frustrating defeat in five-goal thriller|url = 2017}} ==International career== [[File:Flickr - tpower1978 - International friendly match (1) cropped.jpg|thumb|200px|Okazaki with the [[Japan national football team]]]] [[File:Japan national football team World Cup 2018.jpg|thumb|Okazaki with Japan at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia]] After competing for the country's [[Japan national under-23 football team|under-23]] team at the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008 Olympic Games]] in China, Okazaki made his full international debut for [[Japan national football team|Japan]] against the [[United Arab Emirates national football team|United Arab Emirates]] in October 2008.{{cite web| url =http://www.japannationalfootballteam.com/en/players/okazaki_shinji.html| title =OKAZAKI Shinji| publisher =Japan National Football Team Database| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20130922094423/http://www.japannationalfootballteam.com/en/players/okazaki_shinji.html| archivedate =22 September 2013| df =dmy-all}} On 20 January 2009, he scored his first goal for ''Samurai Blue'' in the team's opening [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]] [[2011 AFC Asian Cup qualification|qualifier]] against [[Yemen national football team|Yemen]]. In October 2009, Okazaki scored [[hat-trick]]s in consecutive matches as Japan beat [[Hong Kong national football team|Hong Kong]] and [[Togo national football team|Togo]] 6–0 and 5–0 respectively. He was named The World's Top Goal Scorer of 2009 by the [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] for his 15 goals with the national team.{{cite web | url =http://www.as.com/futbol/articulo/iffhs-designa-japones-shinji-okazaki/20100109dasdasftb_2/Tes|language=Spanish | title =La IFFHS designa al japonés Shinji Okazaki mejor goleador de 2009| date = 9 January 2010 | accessdate = 5 January 2013 | publisher =[[Diario AS]]}} Okazaki was included in Japan's [[2010 FIFA World Cup squads|squad]] for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] and appeared as a substitute in all four of the team's matches. He scored once in the final [[2010 FIFA World Cup Group E|Group E]] match, a 3–1 defeat of [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]], to send the Japanese into the second round. On 8 October 2010, Okazaki scored as Japan beat [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] 1–0 in friendly match to record its first ever win over the [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978]] and [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]] world champions.{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/japan-beat-argentina-for-1st-time-20101009-16chw.html|title=Japan beat Argentina for 1st time|date=9 October 2010|accessdate=13 October 2013|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} Okazaki scored his third international hat-trick in a 5–0 [[2011 AFC Asian Cup Group B|Group B]] win against [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] at the [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]]. He then scored his kick in the semi-final [[Penalty shootout|shootout]] win over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] and played all 120 minutes of the [[2011 AFC Asian Cup Final|final]] as Japan beat [[Australia national football team|Australia]] to win the trophy for a fourth time. Okazaki finished as [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)#Goalscorers|top goalscorer]] in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|Asian section]] of [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|qualification]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] with eight goals. Okazaki scored twice at the [[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup]], against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] respectively. However, Japan lost all three of its matches and was eliminated at the end of the group stage.{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22916862|title= Japan 1 Mexico 2|date=22 June 2013|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 June 2013 }} In June 2014, Okazaki was selected in Japan's squad for the 2014 FIFA World Cup.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/japan/10826657/Japan-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Japan World Cup 2014 squad|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014|work=The Telegraph}} In the team's third group match, a 4–1 defeat to [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], he scored Samurai Blue's only goal with a header in the 45th minute.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25455848|title=Japan 1–4 Colombia|date=24 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=BBC}} Okazaki was included in Japan's squad for the [[2015 AFC Asian Cup]] and scored in a 4–0 defeat of [[Palestine national football team|Palestine]] during the group stage.{{cite Tielemans''' (born 7 May 1997) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] of the [[Premier League]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from [[Ligue 1]] club [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]]. Considered one of the brightest young prospects in world football,{{cite news|last1=Tighe|first1=Sam|title=Top 100 European Football Prospects Aged Under 21|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2236373-top-100-european-football-prospects-aged-under-21/page/101|accessdate=11 December 2015|work=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=30 October 2014}} he began his career at [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]], where he made 185 official appearances and scored 35 goals across four seasons. He won the [[Belgian First Division A|league title]] twice and in 2017 was chosen as the [[Belgian professional football awards|Belgian Professional Footballer of the Year]]. He is the youngest Belgian to play in the [[UEFA Champions League]], making his debut in the competition at the age of 16 years and 148 days. Tielemans represented Belgium at several youth levels and gained his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] for [[Belgium national football team|the full side]] in November 2016, aged 19. He was part of their squad that came third at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]. ==Club career== ===Anderlecht=== [[File:Anderlecht vs Zenit 01 - 17 Feb 2017.png|left|thumb|Tielemans (right) captaining Anderlecht against [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]]'s [[2016–17 UEFA Europa League#Round of 32|round of 32]], 17 February 2017.]] Born in [[Sint-Pieters-Leeuw]], located just outside the [[Brussels-Capital Region]], Tielemans is a youth product of [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] and signed his first professional contract with the club at the age of 16.{{cite web|last1=De Cock|first1=Bjorn|title=In the footsteps of Vincent Kompany: Youri Tielemans|url=http://www.benefoot.net/in-the-footsteps-of-vincent-kompany-youri-tielemans/|website=Benefoot|accessdate=13 April 2016|date=28 October 2013}} On 21 July 2013, he was included in the senior squad for the first time, remaining an unused substitute in the 1–0 win over [[KRC Genk|Genk]] in the [[2013 Belgian Super Cup]]. A week later, he made his first-team debut in the opening round of the [[Belgian First Division A|Belgian Pro League]] season against [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|Lokeren]], replacing injured [[Sacha Kljestan]] after 25 minutes of a 2–3 home loss.{{cite news|title=Lokeren smeert jong Anderlecht al nederlaag aan|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/matchcenter/mc_voetbal/2.28512/speeldag1/1.1685335|accessdate=24 December 2016|publisher=Sporza|date=28 July 2013|language=Dutch}} This made him the fourth-youngest player in the league's history. On 2 October 2013, he became the youngest Belgian player to play in the [[UEFA Champions League]], starting in a match against [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] at the age of 16 years and 148 days.{{cite news |first=Berend |last=Scholten |title=UEFA.com's weekly wonderkid: Youri Tielemans |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2209100.html |website=UEFA.com |publisher=Union of European Football Associations |date=14 February 2015 |accessdate=6 May 2015 }} He played 29 games – of which 21 starts – as Anderlecht won the [[2013–14 Belgian Pro League]], scoring to open a 3–0 win over [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]] at the [[Constant Vanden Stock Stadium]] on 6 April 2014, a game in which he also assisted [[Cyriac]].{{cite news|title=Club go down 3–0 at Anderlecht|url=http://clubbrugge.be/en/news/game-reports/17958/club-gaat-met-3-0-onderuit-op-anderlecht?page=15|accessdate=24 December 2016|publisher=Club Brugge|date=7 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225000932/http://clubbrugge.be/en/news/game-reports/17958/club-gaat-met-3-0-onderuit-op-anderlecht?page=15#|archive-date=25 December 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Tielemans won the [[Belgian professional football awards#Young Professional Footballer of the Year|Belgian Young Player of the Year]] award in each of his first two seasons.{{cite news|title=Who is Youri Tielemans? We profile exciting Anderlecht midfielder|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10052669/anderlecht-midfielder-youri-tielemans-profiled|accessdate=24 December 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=2 November 2015}} [[File:Youri Tielemans 2016.jpg|200px|thumb|Tielemans in action for [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] in 2016]] Tielemans scored 13 times in 37 Belgian First Division A matches as Anderlecht won the [[2016–17 Belgian First Division A]]. He won the 2017 [[Ebony Shoe Award]] for best player of African origin, and was named [[Belgian professional football awards|2016–17 Belgian Professional Footballer of the Year]].{{cite news|title=Gala du Footballeur Pro: Youri Tielemans élu joueur de l'année, René Weiler sacré entraîneur!|trans-title=Professional Footballer Awards: Youri Tielemans elected player of the year, René September 2017|publisher=DH|date=22 May 2017|language=French}} He scored 5 goals in 15 [[2016–17 UEFA Europa League]] matches, with his club reaching the quarter-finals, and was selected in its Squad football|footballer]] who plays for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. His regular position is in [[midfielder|midfield]], but he can play in [[defender (association football)|defence]] when required. James began his career with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], where his brother [[Reece James (footballer, born 1993)|Reece]] also came through the youth ranks, but left the club for a spell on loan at [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] before joining Leicester on a permanent basis in 2012.
==Club career==
===Manchester United=== Born in [[Bacup]], Lancashire, James joined the [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester United Academy]] at an early age, and made his first appearance for the under-18 side in October 2005, at the age of 14. His next appearance for the under-18s came just over a year later, when he came on as a substitute for [[Magnus Wolff Eikrem|Magnus Eikrem]] in a [[Premier Academy League]] fixture against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. He made a further eight appearances for the under-18s during the 2006–07 season, before establishing himself as a regular in the team in 2007–08, although he began the season filling in<!--not a mistake--> in defence. James scored his first goals in a Manchester United shirt during the 2007–08 season, both of them in the league. After making his first appearance for the reserve team in November 2007, James became a regular for the reserves during the 2008–09 season, while remaining a relative mainstay in the under-18 side. At the end of a season in which he had made 22 appearances for the reserves and 14 for the under-18s, James received his first call-up to the Manchester United senior team on 24 May 2009. Given the number 47 jersey, James was named on the bench for the match, but did not take to the field.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Hughes |title=Hull 0–1 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8048308.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=24 May 2009 |accessdate=2 July 2009}}</ref>
James signed his first professional contract with Manchester United in July 2009,<ref>{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Coppack |title=Teen trio turn pro |url=http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid={F9E570E6-407E-44BC-800F-4A3110258114}&newsid=6635556 |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=2 July 2009 |accessdate=2 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> before playing in the 1–0 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in the final of the [[2008–09 Lancashire Senior Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Reserves: Bolton 0 Utd 1 |url=http://www.manutd.com/default.sps?pagegid={B4CEE8FA-9A47-47BC-B069-3F7A2F35DB70}&newsid=6637945 |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=17 August 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8323041.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=27 October 2009}}</ref>
===Preston North End (loan)=== In February 2010, James followed in the footsteps of Manchester United teammate [[Danny Welbeck]] by signing on loan with [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] until the end of the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Preston North End set to sign Man Utd's Matthew James |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/8505108.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=8 February 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2010}}</ref> He went straight into the Preston first-team for their match against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 9 February 2010, and scored within 10 minutes as his deflected shot from outside the penalty area beat Sheffield United goalkeeper [[Ian Bennett (footballer)|Ian Bennett]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Preston 2–1 Sheff Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8501344.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=9 February 2010 |accessdate=10 February 2010}}</ref> James returned to Manchester United at the end of the 2009–10 season, but rejoined Preston on a season-long loan on 2 July 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United's Matthew James rejoins Preston |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/8783280.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=2 July 2010 |date=2 July 2010}}</ref>
On 30 December 2010, [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] chose to recall [[Ritchie De Laet]], [[Joshua King (footballer)|Joshua King]] and James from their loans at Preston after the sacking of his son. De Laet and King returned immediately, but due to the terms of James' loan, he did not return to Manchester United until 4 January 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=James Returns To United |url=http://www.pnefc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10362~2257986,00.html |work=pnefc.net |publisher=Preston North End FC |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327081645/http://www.pnefc.net/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10362~2257986%2C00.html |archivedate=27 March 2012 |df=}}</ref>
===Leicester City===
====2012–13 season==== On 15 May 2012, Matty James and his Manchester United teammate [[Richie De Laet]] moved to [[Leicester City F.C|Leicester City]] in a double transfer, for which the fee was undisclosed. The pair each signed three-year contracts.<ref name="Agreement reached for United Duo">{{cite web |title=Agreement reached for United Duo |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2773743,00.html |publisher=Leicester City FC |work=LCFC.co.uk |date=15 May 2012 |accessdate=15 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518112245/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2773743%2C00.html |archivedate=18 May 2012}}</ref> James, along with De Laet and [[Jamie Vardy]], made his competitive debut for Leicester against [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]], scoring his first goal for the club (and Leicester's third of the night) as the Foxes ran out 4–0 winners in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie.<ref name="Torquay 0-4 Leicester">{{cite web |title=Torquay 0–4 Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19159882 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=17 August 2012}}</ref> James added another 3 goals (all in the league) over the course of the season, including one in the 3–2 win against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on the final day of the season, helping Leicester to the final play-off position.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nott'm Forest 2–3 Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22320604 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC Sport |date=4 May 2013 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> James started both legs of the eventual 3–2 aggregate defeat to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in the Championship [[2013 Football League play-offs|play-off semi final]].
====2013–14 season==== James found himself starting more games during the [[2013–14 Leicester City F.C. season|2013–14]] season, being in the line-up for Leicester's first 5 league games before being shown the first red card of his career in the 1–2 defeat to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], after being shown two yellow cards, a decision that left many perplexed.<ref>{{cite web |title=Charlton 2 Leicester 1: Why did the ref send Matty James off? |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Charlton-2-Leicester-1-did-ref-send-Matty-James/story-19739158-detail/story.html |work=Leicester Mercury |date=2 September 2013 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> On 8 February 2014, James scored his only goal of the season, helping Leicester come from 2–0 down to draw 2–2 with Watford. James played 35 times in the league as Leicester won promotion to the [[Premier League]], collecting the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] trophy along the way.
====2014–15 season==== Having missed the start of the season through injury, James made his first Premier League appearance on 21 September 2014, as a second-half substitute in a 5–3 victory against his former club, Manchester United.<ref>{{cite web |title=Leicester City 5–3 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29196081 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC Sport |date=21 September 2014 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> On 10 January 2015, James picked up the second red card of his career in the 1–0 victory over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], he was given a straight red following a strong challenge on [[Jores Okore]] and an ensuing altercation with [[Ciaran Clark]] that resulted in Clark receiving a second yellow card himself.<ref>{{cite web |title=Report: Leicester City 1 Aston Villa 0 |url=http://www.lcfc.com/fixtures-results/match-report/?matchid=3734979&tcmuri=1651452 |publisher=Leicester City |date=10 January 2015 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> In a 2–0 win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 9 May, James ruptured his anterior ligaments and was ruled out for between six and nine months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Matty James: Leicester City midfielder out for up to nine months |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32738758 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2015 |accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
Due to his injury, James missed the entire 2015–16 campaign, in which the club became the [[Premier League]] champions.
====2016–17 season==== At the beginning of the season, James played with [[Leicester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Leicester City U23]] squad to regain fitness.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/08/15/england/u21-premier-league/manchester-united-u23/leicester-city-u23/2300120/ |title=Manchester United U23 vs. Leicester City U23 – 15 August 2016 – Soccerway |website=int.soccerway.com}}</ref> On 26 November 2016, James returned to the first-team squad against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-team-news-for-premier-league-clash-with-middlesbrough-matty-james-returns-to-squad/story-29936752-detail/story.html |title=Leicester City team news for Premier League clash with Middlesbrough: Matty James returns to squad |date=26 November 2016 |publisher=Leicester Mercury}}</ref>
On 25 January 2017, he joined [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on a loan deal until the summer of 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/reds-land-matty-james-3537558.aspx |title=Reds Land Matty James! |publisher=Barnsley F.C.}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== On 19 August 2017, James made his first start for the club since May 2015 in a 2–0 win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/matty-james-scouting-report-leicester-11018642 |title=Matty James scouting report: Leicester midfielder proves he is ready to step into Chelsea target Danny Drinkwater's boots |last=McLeman |first=Neil |date=19 August 2017 |work=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref>
==International career== James has played regularly for the England Under-16s and Under-17s sides, and in 2009 he was called up to the Under-19s for the [[2009 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship|2009 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |title=England U19 Players |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/MensUnder19s/Players.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20090405001456/http://www.thefa.com/England/MensUnder19s/Players.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 April 2009 |work=TheFA.com |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=10 February 2010}}</ref> He was named captain and in his first game as skipper, England recorded a 3–2 victory in their opening game against Austria.
==Personal life== James' father, Linton James, played non-league football for [[Bacup Borough F.C.|Bacup Borough]] and later worked as assistant manager of the club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dream debut for Valley star Matty |url=https://www.rossendalefreepress.co.uk/news/local-news/dream-debut-valley-star-matty-7832486 |accessdate=19 January 2019 |work=[[Rossendale Free Press]] |date=25 September 2014}}</ref> His younger brother, [[Reece James (footballer, born 1993)|Reece James]], currently plays for [[Sunderland AFC|Sunderland]]. He was educated at [[Fearns Community Sports College]].<ref>{{cite news |title=James the first |url=https://www.rossendalefreepress.co.uk/sport/other-sport/james-the-first-1708891 |accessdate=19 January 2019 |work=[[Rossendale Free Press]] |date=4 May 2007}}</ref>

Do NOT include other goals. --> | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[France national under-18 football team|France U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam2 = [[France national under-19 football team|France U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 8 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2011–2013 | nationalteam3 = [[France national under-20 football team|France U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 13 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2010–2014 | nationalteam4 = [[France national under-21 football team|France U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 5 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 20:38, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 19:03, 4 September 2014 (UTC) }} '''Nampalys Mendy''' (born 23 June 1992) is a French professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[defensive midfielder]] for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], and is a former [[France national youth football team|French youth international]].
Due to his small stature, simple distribution, and reliable style of play, Mendy has been compared to former [[France national football team|French international]], [[Claude Makelele]]. Monaco club scout [[Didier Christophe]], for example, referred to Mendy as a "[[carbon copy]]" of Makelele.<ref name=MendyFuture>{{Cite web |url=http://www.planete-asm.fr/actualite/6196-nampalys-mendy-un-petit-futur-grand.html |title=Nampalys Mendy, un petit futur grand |date=18 September 2010 |publisher=Planete ASM |language=French |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== After leaving [[Sporting Toulon Var|Sporting Toulon]] in June 2007, Mendy went on trial with the football section of [[RC Toulonnais|RC Toulon]]. According to Monaco scout [[Didier Christophe]], the Toulon coaches stated that Mendy was there to "make up the numbers". However, while observing Mendy in training, Christophe noticed the player's intelligence and understanding of the game and recommended him to [[Dominique Bijotat]], who was serving as head of the Monaco youth academy.<ref name="MendyFuture" />
===Monaco=== On 27 April 2010, Mendy signed his first professional contract, agreeing to a three-year deal with Monaco until June 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Premier contrat professionnel pour Nampalys Mendy |url=http://www.leparisien.fr/sports/football/monaco-premier-contrat-professionnel-pour-nampalys-mendy-27-04-2010-901878.php |date=27 April 2010 |work=[[Le Parisien]] |accessdate=15 August 2010 |language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Nampalys Mendy passe pro |url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/20100427_152012_nampalys-mendy-passe-pro.html |date=27 April 2010 |work=[[L'Equipe]] |accessdate=15 August 2010 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823030637/http://www.lequipe.fr/Football/20100427_152012_nampalys-mendy-passe-pro.html |archivedate=23 August 2010 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> In July 2010, he was called up to the first team by manager [[Guy Lacombe]] for pre-season training, again to make up the numbers with Lacombe missing several players such as [[Diego Pérez (footballer)|Diego Pérez]], [[Nicolas N'Koulou]], [[Park Chu-Young]], and [[Lukman Haruna]], who had all participated in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="MendyFuture" />
On 7 August 2010, Mendy made his professional debut in the club's opening league match against [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]]. He played the entire 90 minutes, receiving a yellow card in the second half.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.asm-fc.com/filactu.aspx?id=12138 |title=F. Bulot et N. Mendy : Premières en L1 |date=7 August 2010 |work=[[AS Monaco FC]] |accessdate=7 August 2010 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726013009/http://www.asm-fc.com/filactu.aspx?id=12138 |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53639 |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |title=Lyon v. Monaco Match Report |language=French |date=7 August 2010 |accessdate=7 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313203412/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53639 |archivedate=13 March 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Mendy picked up his first ever red card on 19 August 2011 against [[Amiens SC]], sent off at the 70th minute mark in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2011/08/19/france/ligue-2/association-sportive-monaco-fc/amiens-sporting-club-football/1115135/ |title=Monaco vs. Amiens SC 1 – 1 (8/11/11) |work=Soccerway |date=11 August 2011}}</ref>
During the [[2012–13 Ligue 2|2012–13 season]], Mendy played a key role in Monaco's promotion back to [[Ligue 1]]. Despite the successful season, Mendy decided to leave Monaco at the end of the season after his contract expired.<ref name="Nampalys Mendy: Nice right move">{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.us/french-ligue-1/story/1514850/nampalys-mendy-moving-to-nice-was-right-choice |publisher=ESPN |title=Nampalys Mendy: Nice right move |date=6 August 2013 |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref>
===Nice=== Mendy was linked to teams such as [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="Nampalys Mendy: Nice right move"/> Despite calling Manchester United his "dream club", Mendy rejected the move to the English side because he wanted to stay in France.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/212979.html |publisher=ESPN |title=Mendy: Man United my 'dream club' |date=14 June 2013 |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> After some positive talks with Nice's manager, [[Claude Puel]], Mendy decided to join [[OGC Nice]] on a free transfer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11667/8856900/nice-midfielder-nanpalys-mendy-denies-manchester-united-link |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Nice midfielder Nanpalys Mendy denies Manchester United link |date=6 August 2013 |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref>
Mendy made his debut on 17 August 2013, in a 2–1 win against [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Stade Rennais]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/08/17/france/ligue-1/olympique-gymnaste-club-de-nice-cote-dazur/stade-rennais-fc/1479061/ |title=Nice vs. Rennes 2 – 1 (8/17/13) |date=17 August 2013}}</ref> After club captain [[Didier Digard]] left for [[Real Betis]] on a free transfer at the end of 2014–15 season,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realbetisbalompie.es/en/noticias/last-news/4931/el-real-betis-firma-didier-digard-para-las-tres-pr/ |title=Real Betis signs Didier Digard for the next three seasons |date=8 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817161043/http://www.realbetisbalompie.es/en/noticias/last-news/4931/el-real-betis-firma-didier-digard-para-las-tres-pr/ |archivedate=17 August 2016}}</ref> and new captain [[Mathieu Bodmer]] was injured, Mendy was named captain.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/bodmer-pouplin-join-nice-injury-list-182342933--sow.html/ |work=Yahoo Sports |title=Bodmer, Pouplin join Nice injury list |date=10 August 2015}}</ref>
Mendy made 110 appearances in three seasons for [[OGC Nice|Nice]] and helped them to a fourth-place finish in [[Ligue 1]] in 2015–16.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/leicester-city/375/blog/post/2907417/nampalys-mendy-can-be-leicesters-unlikely-hero-with-or-without-kante |title=Nampalys Mendy can be Leicester's unlikely hero with or without Kante |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> He had the second highest number of passes behind [[Thiago Motta]] (2950), the most passes per game (78), and a passing accuracy of (92%), best of any player not a member of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]].<ref name="Leicester's new signings: The stats that made them stand out">{{cite|title = Leicester's new signings: The stats that made them stand out|url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10512501/leicester8217s-new-signings-the-stats-that-made-them-stand-out|publisher = Sky Sports|author = Adam Bate|date = 27 July 2016|accessdate = 9 January 2017}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== [[File:Mendy LCFC.jpg|thumb|Mendy (in blue) playing for Leicester City in January 2017]]
On 3 July 2016, Mendy moved to [[Premier League]] champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], managed by his former boss at Monaco, [[Claudio Ranieri]], signing a four-year deal for £13 million, a club record at the time.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36697432 |title=Nampalys Mendy: Leicester City sign midfielder from Nice |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2906808/leicester-city-sign-nampalys-mendy-from-ogc-nice-on-four-year-deal |title=Leicester City sign Nampalys Mendy from OGC Nice on four-year deal |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> The transfer record was broken again when [[Ahmed Musa (footballer)|Ahmed Musa]] joined Leicester for £16 million five days later,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2909897/leicester-city-sign-nigerias-ahmed-musa-from-cska-moscow-for-15-million-pounds |title=Leicester City seal signing of Nigeria's Ahmed Musa from CSKA Moscow |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> and yet again less than two months later when [[Islam Slimani]] joined Leicester for £29 million.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37217072 |title=Islam Slimani: Leicester City sign Sporting Lisbon forward |accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref>
Mendy played his first competitive game for Leicester in a 2–1 defeat to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the [[2016 FA Community Shield]] on 7 August, coming on as a 63rd-minute substitute for [[Andy King (footballer, born 1988)|Andy King]].<ref name="Community Shield: Leicester City 1-2 Manchester United">{{cite|title = Community Shield: Leicester City 1–2 Manchester United|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36934956|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Chris Bevan|date = 7 August 2016|accessdate = 17 January 2017}}</ref> He suffered an ankle injury on his league debut at home against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 20 August 2016 and was substituted in the 53rd minute.<ref name="Leicester City 0-0 Arsenal">{{cite|title = Leicester City 0–0 Arsenal|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37067830|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Phil McNulty|date = 20 August 2016|accessdate = 17 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Nampalys Mendy nearing Leicester City return following ankle injury">{{cite|title = Nampalys Mendy nearing Leicester City return following ankle injury|url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10599854/nampalys-mendy-nearing-leicester-city-return-following-ankle-injury|publisher = Sky Sports|author = Jordan Brown|date = 30 September 2016|accessdate = 17 January 2017}}</ref> Mendy was sidelined for more than three months,<ref name="Leicester City midfielder Papy Mendy says he is getting back to his best form after injury nightmare">{{cite|title = Leicester City midfielder Papy Mendy says he is getting back to his best form after injury nightmare|url = http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-midfielder-papy-mendy-says-he-is-getting-back-to-his-best-form-after-injury-nightmare/story-30059679-detail/story.html|work = Leicester Mercury|author = Rob Tanner|date = 15 January 2017|accessdate = 17 January 2017}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and did not make his return until 7 December 2016 in a [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group G|group stage]] match away to [[FC Porto|Porto]], playing the entire game in a 5–0 defeat.<ref name="FC Porto 5-0 Leicester City">{{cite|title = FC Porto 5–0 Leicester City|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38226552|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Gary Rose|date = 7 December 2016|accessdate = 17 January 2017}}</ref> He ultimately made only four league appearances for the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2892/transfer-zone/2017/06/27/36668282/leicester-midfielder-mendy-wants-bordeaux-move |title=Leicester midfielder Mendy wants Bordeaux move |website=Goal |last=Smith |first=Jamie |date=27 June 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref>
On 31 July 2017, Mendy rejoined [[OGC Nice|Nice]] on loan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City send Nampalys Mendy back to Nice on loan |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/soccer-transfers/story/3193334/leicester-city-send-nampalys-mendy-back-to-nice-on-loan |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=ESPN FC |date=31 August 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Mendy is a former [[France national youth football team|French youth international]] having earned caps at the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[France national under-18 football team|under-18]], and [[France national under-19 football team|under-19]] levels. With the under-17 team, he went unnoticed by coach [[Philippe Bergeroo]] until the [[2009 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] when he was finally called up to the team. Mendy appeared in all three group stage matches as France were eliminated without winning a match. With the under-18 team, he made his debut on 29 October 2009 in a friendly match against the [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]].<ref>{{cite news |title=France v. Denmark Match Report |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur_new/match.php?id_match=150 |date=29 October 2009 |work=[[French Football Federation]] |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref>
Mendy was initially called up to the under-19 team in August 2010 only to play in the Sendai Cup in Japan, but due to his consistent performances domestically, Monaco coach Guy Lacombe convinced Bergeroo to make him a permanent part of the squad.<ref name="MendyFuture" /> He was officially called up to the under-19 team for [[2011 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship qualification|qualification]] matches for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]]. Mendy made his debut with the team in a 3–0 victory over [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and appeared as a starter in the next two qualification matches against [[Montenegro national under-19 football team|Montenegro]] and [[Austria national under-19 football team|Austria]], as France won both matches to finish the round undefeated.<ref>{{cite news |title=France v. San Marino Match Report |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/matches/season=2011/round=2000081/match=2001647/index.html |date=8 October 2010 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=France v. Montenegro Match Report |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/matches/season=2011/round=2000081/match=2001673/index.html |date=10 October 2010 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Austria v. France Match Report |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/matches/season=2011/round=2000081/match=2001699/index.html |date=13 October 2010 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref>
On 9 November 2010, while still eligible to represent the under-19 and [[France national under-20 football team|under-20]] teams, Mendy was called up to the [[France national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] for a friendly match against [[Russia national under-21 football team|Russia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nampalys Mendy avec les Bleuets |url=http://www.asm-fc.com/filactu.aspx?id=13055 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120731114411/http://www.asm-fc.com/filactu.aspx?id=13055 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 31 July 2012 |date=11 November 2010 |work=[[AS Monaco FC]] |accessdate=13 November 2010 |language=French}}</ref>
==Personal life== Mendy is the cousin of fellow footballers [[Bafétimbi Gomis]] and [[Alexandre Mendy (footballer, born 1994)|Alexandre Mendy]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.girondins33.com/Breves-20218-alexandre-et-nampalys-mendy-une-histoire-de-famille-dans-le-mercato-bordelais |title=Alexandre et Nampalys Mendy, une histoire de famille dans le mercato bordelais ? |website=girondins33.com |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref>
==Style of play== Mendy is a defensive midfielder known for his resilience, intelligence, and good distribution of the ball. Despite his age and size, Mendy has been praised for his mature and robust play, inviting comparison with former France international [[Claude Makelele]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/new-makelele-mendy-thrilled-to-reunite-with-ranieri-at-leicester-4136535 |title='New Makelele' Mendy thrilled to reunite with Ranieri at Leicester |first=Vyom |last=Chaudhary |website=Tribal Football |accessdate=27 January 2019}}</ref>

Genk|Genk]] |caps1 = 61<!--two games in Belgian League Europa League play-offs are not counted--> |goals1 = 4 |years2 = 2017– |clubs2 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps2 = 81 |goals2 = 4 |nationalyears1 = 2013–2015 |nationalteam1 = [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria U20]] |nationalcaps1 = 7 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2015– |nationalteam2 = [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] |nationalcaps2 = 23 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |club-update = 17:57, 16 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = 18:36, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Onyinye Wilfred Ndidi''' (born 16 December 1996) is a Nigerian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for {{English football updater|LeicestC}} club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria national team]] as a [[midfielder]].
==Club career== ===Genk=== Ndidi made his [[Belgian Pro League]] debut with [[K.R.C. Genk|Genk]] on 31 January 2015 against [[R. Charleroi S.C.|Charleroi]] in a 1–0 away defeat. He played the first 74 minutes of the game, before being substituted for [[Jarne Vrijsen]].<ref name="soccerway2">{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/01/31/belgium/pro-league/royal-charleroi-sporting-club/krc-genk/1697243/ |title=Charleri vs. Genk – 31 January 2015 – Soccerway |publisher=soccerway.com |accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref>
During the Belgian League play-off game against [[Club Brugge]], Ndidi scored a long-range goal, which was named the goal of the season in the Belgian league. After receiving an attempted-clearance outside the penalty box, he lofted the ball smoothly over an opposing player before unleashing a ferocious volley into the top right corner.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XNrukUXR8bc |title=Wilfred Ndidi Amazing Goal ● KRC Genk vs Club Brugge KV ● Belgium Jupiler League 20/04/2016 |first= |last=Football Score |date=20 April 2016 |publisher= |via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20160523_02303545 |title=Hanni is Profvoetballer van het Jaar, ook Preud'homme, Bailey, Sels, Ndidi en Simons bekroond |publisher=}}</ref> The ball was adjudged to be travelling at over 111 km/h.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lavenir.net/cnt/dmf20160524_00830880/footballeur-pro-de-l-annee-wilfred-ndidi-auteur-du-plus-beau-but |title=Footballeur Pro de l’année: Wilfred Ndidi, auteur du plus beau but |publisher=}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== On 3 December 2016, Genk agreed a £17 million transfer deal with English champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccerblitz.net/2016/12/23/7-facts-you-didnt-know-about-leicester-city-new-signing-wilfred-ndidi/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224114517/http://soccerblitz.net/2016/12/23/7-facts-you-didnt-know-about-leicester-city-new-signing-wilfred-ndidi/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 December 2016 |title=7 FACTS you didn’t know about Leicester City new signing Wilfred Ndidi |date=23 December 2016 |accessdate=5 January 2017 |publisher=soccerblitz.com |author=Seyi Daniels}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/3031389/leicester-agree-deal-to-sign-nigeria-international-wilfred-ndidi-from-genk |title=Leicester agree deal to sign Nigeria international Wilfred Ndidi from Genk |newspaper=ESPNFC.com|access-date=5 January 2017}}</ref> The deal was confirmed on 5 January 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/2016-17/wilfred-ndidi-new-signing-trains-after-finalising-leicester-city-transfer-3503085.aspx |title=Wilfred Ndidi: New Signing Trains After Finalising Leicester City Transfer |date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=5 January 2017 |publisher=lcfc.com}}</ref>
Ndidi made his debut for the club on 7 January 2017, in a 2–1 win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in the third round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38474504 |title=Everton 1–2 Leicester City |last=McNulty |first=Phil |date=7 January 2017 |work=www.bbc.co.uk/sport |publisher=BBC Sport |language=en-GB|access-date=29 January 2017}}</ref> He made his first [[Premier League]] start on 14 January 2017 against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at home in a 3–0 defeat.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/fixtures-results/match-report/index.aspx?matchid=3925162 |title=Match Report – Leicester 0–3 Chelsea |last= |first= |date=14 January 2017 |website=www.lcfc.com |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |language=en-GB|access-date=29 January 2017}}</ref> In the English FA Cup game against Derby County on 8 February 2017, Ndidi came on in the first half of extra time and scored his first goal for Leicester through a long-range shot.<ref>{{cite |url=http://www.espnfc.us/report?gameId=473321|title=Ndidi first Leicester goal|newspaper=espnfc.com|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> In a 3–1 win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 27 February 2017, Ndidi won 11 of his 14 tackles,<ref name="Leicester City 3-1 Liverpool">{{cite|title = Leicester City 3–1 Liverpool|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39024318|publisher = BBC Sport|author = Phil Dawkes|date = 27 February 2017|accessdate = 3 June 2017}}</ref> a feat bettered only by Chelsea's [[N'Golo Kanté]] who made 14 tackles against the same club in January.<ref name="Leicester dynamo Wilfred Ndidi has potential to surpass N'Golo Kante">{{cite|title = Leicester dynamo Wilfred Ndidi has potential to surpass N'Golo Kante|url = http://www.espnfcasia.com/club/leicester-city/375/blog/post/3070662/leicester-dynamo-wilfred-ndidi-has-potential-to-surpass-ngolo-kante|publisher = ESPN FC|author = Colin Udoh|date = 28 February 2017|accessdate = 3 June 2017}}</ref>
Ndidi got his first career red card in a 3–0 loss to Crystal Palace on 16 December 2017 – which also happens to be his birthday.<ref>{{cite|title = Birthday boy Ndidi gets first career red against Crystal Palace |url = http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/birthday-boy-wilfred-ndidi-gets-first-career-red-against-crystal-/1mlilf6w849gv1c3auyaiowxj6|publisher = GOAL.COM|author = Shina Oludare|date = 16 December 2017|accessdate = 17 December 2017}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Wilfred Ndidi-Nigeria.jpg|thumb|left|Wilfred Ndidi with Nigeria against Argentina, Uzomedia]] Ndidi was part of the Nigerian youth setup during his time at Nathaniel Boys of Lagos. While playing the African U-17 Championship with Nigeria, he was excluded along with two other players from the competition as a precaution, following an MRI age test that suggested he was just slightly above the threshold.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.naij.com/31032.html |title=Three Nigerian Footballers Caught Age Cheating |first=Katherine |last=Baffour |date=15 April 2013 |publisher=}}</ref> Notwithstanding, he joined up with his teammates in the U-20 team the following year, forming the bedrock of the midfield. He was called up to the Senior [[Nigeria national football team]] on 8 October 2015, making his debut in the friendly game against DR Congo, and playing again a few days later in the 3–0 win against Cameroon, when he replaced [[John Obi Mikel]] in the 63rd minute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/match/nigeria-v-cameroon/5fmctvxcfgmzoh832z12em6ll |title=Nigeria v Cameroon Live Commentary & Result, 11/10/2015, Friendlies - Goal.com |publisher=}}</ref>
He was selected by Nigeria for their 35-man provisional squad for the 2016 Summer Olympics.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36623763 |title=Kelechi Iheanacho included in Nigeria's Olympics squad |date=24 June 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016 |author=Oluwashina Okeleji |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In May 2018 he was named in Nigeria’s preliminary 30 man [[Nigeria national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb |title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced? - Goal.com |publisher=}}</ref>

Wiener Neustädter SC|Wiener Neustadt]] | years1 = 2002–2003 | clubs1 = [[1. Wiener Neustädter SC|Wiener Neustadt]] | caps1 = 12 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2003–2008 | clubs2 = [[SV Mattersburg]] | caps2 = 141 | goals2 = 11 | years3 = 2008–2011 | clubs3 = [[VfL Bochum]] | caps3 = 53 | goals3 = 6 | years4 = 2010–2011 | clubs4 = → [[1. FSV Mainz 05]] (loan) | caps4 = 31 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2011–2015 | clubs5 = [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] | caps5 = 99 | goals5 = 4 | years6 = 2015– | clubs6 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps6 = 96 | goals6 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2002–2003 | nationalteam1 = [[Austria national under-17 football team|Austria U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 24 | nationalgoals1 = 6 | nationalyears2 = 2003–2005 | nationalteam2 = [[Austria national under-19 football team|Austria U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2005–2006 | nationalteam3 = [[Austria national under-21 football team|Austria U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 10 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | nationalyears4 = 2006–2016 | nationalteam4 = [[Austria national football team|Austria]] | nationalcaps4 = 78 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | pcupdate = 08:02, 17 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Christian Fuchs''' ({{IPA-de|ˈkʁɪs.ti̯a(ː)n ˈfʊks}};<ref>{{cite book|author1=Dudenredaktion|last2=Kleiner|first2=Stefan|last3=Knöbl|first3=Ralf|year=2015|orig-year=First published 1962|title=Das Aussprachewörterbuch|trans-title=The Pronunciation Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T6vWCgAAQBAJ|language=German|edition=7th|location=Berlin|publisher=Dudenverlag|isbn=978-3-411-04067-4|pp=277, 382}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Krech|first1=Eva-Maria|last2=Stock|first2=Eberhard|last3=Hirschfeld|first3=Ursula|last4=Anders|first4=Lutz Christian|title=Deutsches Aussprachewörterbuch|trans-title=German Pronunciation Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E-1tr_oVkW4C&dq=deutsches+ausspracheworterbuch&source=gbs_navlinks_s|language=German|year=2009|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|location=Berlin|isbn=978-3-11-018202-6|pp=413, 522}}</ref> born 7 April 1986) is an Austrian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[left back]] for English club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].
He began his senior career as a teenager at [[1. Wiener Neustädter SC|Wiener Neustadt]] before signing his first professional contract at 17 with [[SV Mattersburg]], challenging for the [[Austrian Football Bundesliga]] title and taking part in European competitions. In 2008, he left for Germany, signing for [[VfL Bochum]]. After a season on loan at [[1. FSV Mainz 05]], he signed for [[FC Schalke 04]] in 2011, where he contested the [[UEFA Champions League]] but suffered a serious knee injury. In 2015, he signed for Leicester, winning the [[Premier League]] in his first season at the club.
A full international for a decade starting from his debut in 2006, Fuchs earned 78 caps for [[Austria national football team|Austria]], making him their eighth-most capped player of all time. He played for the nation at [[UEFA Euro 2008]] and [[UEFA Euro 2016]], captaining them for the first time in 2010 and on a permanent basis from 2012, before retiring from international duty in 2016.
==Club career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Neunkirchen, Austria|Neunkirchen]], [[Lower Austria]], and his father was an amateur [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. He began as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] at local team SVg Pitten before moving to [[1. Wiener Neustädter SC]] at the age of 11. At the age of 15, while still an amateur and at mainstream school, Fuchs played for their senior team. When he was 17, he signed his first professional deal at [[SV Mattersburg]], a team who despite coming from a town of 6,000 drew league record average crowds of 17,000, came third in the [[Austrian Football Bundesliga]] and played in European competition.<ref name=ordinary/>
Prior to [[UEFA Euro 2008]], he joined the German side [[VfL Bochum]].<ref name="Fuchs kommt">{{cite web | url = http://www.vfl-bochum.de/webcache/Aktuelles_meldung_5217_3_en.htm | title = Fuchs kommt | publisher = VfL Bochum | date = 25 June 2008 | accessdate = 30 April 2011 | language = German | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090222152751/http://www.vfl-bochum.de/webcache/Aktuelles_meldung_5217_3_en.htm | archivedate = 22 February 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He later described it as a useful move to play regularly while attracting attention from bigger teams.<ref name=ordinary/> In 2010, he was signed on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] by [[1. FSV Mainz 05]],<ref name="Fuchs kommt"/> a newly promoted team who ended the season in the top five.<ref name=ordinary/>
===Schalke=== On 6 June 2011, Fuchs signed a contract until 30 June 2015 with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]].<ref name="Schalke sign Austria skipper Fuchs">{{cite news|title=Schalke sign Austria skipper Fuchs |url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/06062011/58/bundesliga-schalke-sign-austria-skipper-fuchs.html |accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=[[Eurosport]]|date=6 June 2011}}</ref> The transfer fee is reportedly undisclosed by Schalke's sport and communications manager [[Horst Heldt]].<ref name="Schalke sign Austria skipper Fuchs"/> Fuchs was assigned the number 23 shirt, previously worn by [[Danilo Fernando Avelar]].<ref name="Schalke sign Austria skipper Fuchs"/>
In his time at the team from [[Gelsenkirchen]], he competed in the [[UEFA Champions League]], but suffered a long-term knee injury.<ref name=ordinary/>
===Leicester City=== [[File:Leicester 0 Chelsea 3 (31944658370).jpg|thumb|Fuchs in a league match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 14 January 2017]] On 3 June 2015, [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] announced the signing of Fuchs on a [[Free transfer (association football)|free transfer]], signing a three-year deal with the Foxes effective from 1 July.<ref name="Leicester City sign Christian Fuchs on free transfer from Schalke">{{cite web |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32999056 | title = Leicester City sign Christian Fuchs on free transfer from Schalke | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 3 June 2015 | accessdate = 10 June 2015}}</ref> Signed under previous manager [[Nigel Pearson]], Fuchs didn't have a regular spot in new manager [[Claudio Ranieri]]'s squad until October. Fuchs made an appearance in Leicester's third round League Cup tie against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], providing an assist for [[Andy King (footballer, born 1988)|Andy King]]'s extra time winner. Following a 2–5 loss to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 26 September,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34299596 |title=Ranieri must plug leaky defence |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Timothy |last=Abraham |date=26 September 2015}}</ref> Ranieri elected to shake up his defensive back four, inserting Fuchs and teammate [[Danny Simpson]] in place of [[Jeffrey Schlupp]] and [[Ritchie De Laet]], respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/norwich-1-leicester-city-2-8211-match-report/story-27915218-detail/story.html |title=Jamie Vardy and Jeff Schlupp score as City bounce back with win |work=Leicester Mercury |first=James |last=Sharpe |date=3 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007232120/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Norwich-1-Leicester-City-2-8211-match-report/story-27915218-detail/story.html |archivedate=7 October 2015 }}</ref> Fuchs made his first Premier League start the next week against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/fuchs-hails-foxes-defensive-resilience-2730870.aspx |title=Fuchs Hails Foxes' Defensive Resilience |work=Leicester City Football Club |date=7 October 2015}}</ref>
In his first season, Leicester finished as champions on odds of 5,000–1, making Fuchs the first Austrian to receive a [[Premier League]] winners' medal since Arsenal's [[Alex Manninger]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester City: The ridiculous statistics|url=http://www.football365.com/news/leicester-city-the-ridiculous-statistics|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=Football 365|date=3 May 2016}}</ref> Following the insertion of Fuchs into the lineup on Matchday 8, Leicester City led the Premier League in clean sheets along with Arsenal, with 15. Fuchs himself led the league during this period in successful tackles with 77, while finishing second in interceptions with 98.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fantasyfootballscout.co.uk/2016/05/19/team-of-the-season-christian-fuchs/ |title=Team of the Season – Christian Fuchs |work=Fantasy Football Scout |first=James |last=Harding |date=19 May 2016}}</ref>
Prior to signing for Leicester, Fuchs had an offer to play in the United States, where his family live, but he turned it down for financial reasons. He said in March 2016 "My intention is to play in the US. I have come [to Leicester] for three years. I decided that I would sign one last contract in Europe, when I left Schalke, then go to the US."<ref name=ordinary/>
On 21 October 2016, Fuchs signed a new contract with Leicester, keeping him with the club until June 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37726922 |title=Christian Fuchs: Leicester City defender agrees new three-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 October 2016}}</ref> The next day, Fuchs scored his first goal for Leicester against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], volleying home a corner-kick clearance by [[Christian Benteke]] for the team's final goal in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/match-centre/leicester-city-crystal-palace-live-8694433 |title=Christian Fuchs scores stunner as Foxes ease to win |work=Mirror |date=22 October 2016}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:AUT vs. MDA 2015-09-05 (042).jpg|thumb|upright|Fuchs taking a [[throw-in]] during a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] qualifier against [[Moldova national football team|Moldova]] in September 2015]] Fuchs made his debut for [[Austria national football team|Austria]] on 23 May 2006 in a friendly match against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], replacing [[Stefan Lexa]] for the final six minutes of the 1–4 loss at the [[Ernst-Happel-Stadion]] in [[Vienna]].
He was part of the Austrian international squad as they co-hosted [[UEFA Euro 2008]] alongside [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]]. He made only one appearance in the group stage elimination, playing the entirety of the 1–0 loss to Germany in their last match of the tournament.<ref name="ÖFB (Austrian Football Association) Media Centre - Stegersbach">{{cite web|title=ÖFB (Austrian Football Association) Media Centre – Stegersbach|url=http://www.oefb.at/_uploads/_elements/10908_file1.pdf|format=PDF|page=32|accessdate=5 August 2014|work=oefb.at|publisher=[[Austrian Football Association|''Österreichischer Fußball-Bund'']] (ÖFB)|date=7 June 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808035519/http://www.oefb.at/_uploads/_elements/10908_file1.pdf|archive-date=8 August 2014|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
On 11 August 2010, in the absence of regular skipper [[Marc Janko]], Fuchs captained his nation for the first time in a 0–1 friendly loss to the Swiss in [[Klagenfurt]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Zu harmlos für die Schweiz|trans-title=Too harmless for Switzerland|url=http://sport.orf.at/stories/2008533/2008526/|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=ORF|date=13 August 2010|language=German}}</ref> That 17 November, he scored his first international goal, equalising in a 1–2 home friendly loss to [[Greece national football team|Greece]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Debüttreffer reicht nicht|trans-title=First goal not enough|url=http://de.uefa.com/uefaeuro/news/newsid=1564966.html|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=17 November 2010|language=German}}</ref>
Fuchs received the armband on a permanent basis at the behest of manager [[Marcel Koller]] on 13 August 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fußball: Christian Fuchs neuer Nationalteam-Kapitän|trans-title=Football: Christian Fuchs is new national team captain|url=http://diepresse.com/home/sport/fussball/1277914/Fussball_Christian-Fuchs-neuer-NationalteamKapitaen|accessdate=3 May 2016|work=Die Presse|date=13 August 2012|language=German}}</ref> He played all 10 games as they [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|qualified]] for [[UEFA Euro 2016]], the first time they did so, and featured in every minute of the [[UEFA Euro 2016 Group F|group stage elimination]] in France. Afterwards, he retired from international play with a total of 78 caps, declaring "I am very proud of the 10 years that I have spent with the national team. I did everything with passion and, as I said, I am very, very proud."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Turner|first1=Stephen|title=Leicester's Christian Fuchs quits internationals after Austria exit|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/33864/10328117/leicesters-christian-fuchs-quits-internationals-after-austria-exit|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=29 June 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:AUT vs. LIE 2015-10-12 (022).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Fuchs, his wife, and their children, October 2015]] Fuchs' wife Raluca Gold-Fuchs, with whom he has a stepson, son, and daughter, is a businesswoman formerly of [[Goldman Sachs]]. She lives with their children in [[Manhattan]] and Fuchs sees them once a month.<ref name=ordinary>{{cite news|last1=Tanner|first1=Rob|title=Leicester City EXCLUSIVE: Why Christian Fuchs is no ordinary footballer|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Christian-ordinary-footballer/story-28906310-detail/story.html|accessdate=3 May 2016|work=Leicester Mercury|date=12 March 2016}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He runs a public relations company and a football academy in the same city, and plans to move there permanently after his football career.<ref name=ordinary/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2016/04/29/leicester-city-christian-fuchs-draft/|title=Christian Fuchs is living the dream with Leicester City. Next, why not the NFL?|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
The ''[[Leicester Mercury]]'' described Fuchs as "not your stereotypical footballer...[he] has more strings to his bow than an orchestra".<ref name=ordinary/> He is noted for his online video series "No Fuchs Given", a play on his surname and the English-language obscenity "''[[fuck]]''"; the series consists of himself and teammates doing unusual football-related challenges, such as him and [[Robert Huth]] shooting the ball as hard as possible into each other's backsides.<ref name=ordinary/> His surname "Fuchs" is the German word for "[[Fox]]".
