Do NOT include other goals. --> | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]| caps4= 17 | goals4= 1 | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[France national under-20 football team|France U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] | nationalcaps2 = 16 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | club-update = 18:19, 1 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:24, 16 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Rachid Ghezzal''' ({{lang-ar|رشيد غزال}}; born 9 May 1992) is an Algerian professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and the [[Algeria national football team|Algeria national team]].<ref name="ghezzal_buteur">{{cite news |title=Rachid Ghezzal: "Je choisirai l'Algérie" |url=http://www.lebuteur.com/foot-en-vrac/actualites/rachid-ghezzal-je-choisirai-l-algerie |work=Le Buteur |date=20 August 2010 |accessdate=7 October 2012 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815001044/http://www.lebuteur.com/foot-en-vrac/actualites/rachid-ghezzal-je-choisirai-l-algerie |archivedate=15 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
He began his career at [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]], where he made his debut in October 2012. He played 119 games and scored 13 goals for them across all competitions. In August 2017, he moved to [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] on a free transfer.
Born in France, Ghezzal represented France at [[France national under-20 football team|under-20 level]]. He made his senior debut for his ancestral [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in 2015 and was part of their squad at the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]].
==Club career==
===Lyon=== Born in [[Décines-Charpieu]], [[Metropolitan Lyon]], in July 2010 Ghezzal signed a five-year ''élite'' contract with [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Rachid Ghezzal signe un contrat Elite à l'OL |url=http://www.dzfoot.com/news-6886/verts-rachid-ghezzal-signe-un-contrat-elite-a-l-ol/ |work=DZFoot |date=7 July 2010 |accessdate=7 October 2012 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101210232308/http://www.dzfoot.com/news-6886/verts-rachid-ghezzal-signe-un-contrat-elite-a-l-ol |archivedate=10 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> After featuring with the club's reserve team in the [[Championnat de France amateur]] for two consecutive seasons, ahead of the [[2012–13 in French football|2012–13 season]], he was promoted to the senior team by manager [[Rémi Garde]] and assigned the number 31 shirt. Ghezzal made his senior team debut on 4 October 2012 in a [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]] group stage away match against Israeli club [[Hapoel Ironi Kiryat Shmona F.C.|Ironi Kiryat Shmona]]; he started the match as Lyon won the contest 4–3.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lyon leave it late to see off Kiryat Shmona |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000356/match=2009931/postmatch/report/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012 }}</ref>
In the 2013–14 season, Ghezzal suffered a back injury for the first six months of Lyon's campaign, which saw him out of action until 10 January 2014, missing 32 of Lyon's games in the process. He then returned to the squad but did not make any appearances for Lyon for the rest of the season; either being not named in match day squads or being named on the bench. Since January 2016, he had been playing regularly.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} He finished the 2015–16 season with 8 goals and 8 assists in 29 Ligue 1 matches.<ref name="chronicle">{{cite news|last1=Jamieson|first1=Stuart|title=Who is Sunderland target Rachid Ghezzal? Why Lyon star is attracting so much attention|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/who-sunderland-target-rachid-ghezzal-11377895|accessdate=17 August 2016|work=[[Evening Chronicle]]|date=24 May 2016}}</ref> In June 2017, Lyon announced that Ghezzal's contract would not be renewed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Transfer news: Lyon sign Mendy but lose Ghezzal|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/11/transfer-zone/2017/06/29/36719732/lyon-sign-mendy-but-ghezzal-and-gonalons-to-depart|website=Goal|accessdate=1 July 2017|date=29 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Nick|title=Free agents XI: the best out-of-contract bargains available this summer|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jun/28/free-agents-xi-best-out-of-contract-bargains-football|accessdate=1 July 2017|work=The Guardian|date=28 June 2017}}</ref>
===Monaco=== On 7 August 2017, Ghezzal joined fellow Ligue 1 team [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] by signing a four-year contract that would run until June 2021. It was reported that Monaco would pay him a [[signing bonus]] of €3 million and a monthly salary of about €180,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Transferts-rachid-ghezzal-lyon-file-vers-monaco/822955|title=Transferts : Rachid Ghezzal (Lyon) file vers Monaco|publisher=L'Équipe|date=4 August 2017}}</ref> As his Lyon contract had expired on 30 June 2017, he arrived on a free transfer.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Okeleji|first1=Oluwashina|title=French champions Monaco sign Algerian winger Rachid Ghezzal|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40851309|accessdate=16 August 2017|work=BBC Sport|date=7 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Rachid-ghezzal-a-signe-a-monaco/823911|title=Rachid Ghezzal a signé à Monaco|publisher=L'Équipe|date=7 August 2017}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== On 5 August 2018, Ghezzal joined [[Premier League]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], signing a four-year deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/794576/leicester-city-sign-winger-rachid-ghezzal-from-as-monaco/press-release|title=Leicester City sign winger Rachid Ghezzal from AS Monaco|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=5 August 2018|accessdate=5 August 2018}}</ref> In his first start for the club, he scored his first Leicester goal -a long range strike from outside the box- in a 4–0 win over Fleetwood Town.
==International career== At international senior level, Ghezzal was eligible to represent both [[France national football team|France]] and [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] and had stated his preference is to represent the latter nation.<ref name ="ghezzal_buteur"/> In 2013, he received the call from [[France national under-20 football team|France U20]] to compete in the [[2013 Toulon Tournament|Toulon Tournament]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tournoi de Toulon : Rachid Ghezzal sélectionné avec l'équipe de France des U-20|url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/letemps/93680|website=Djazairess|accessdate=17 August 2016|language=French|date=17 May 2013}}</ref> However, Ghezzal later chose to play for Algeria, scoring his first goal in March 2016 against Ethiopia.<ref name="chronicle"/>
==Personal life== He is the younger brother of Algerian international [[Abdelkader Ghezzal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/espn-fc-united-blog/68/post/3045065/arsenal-could-pounce-on-rachid-ghezzals-lyon-conundrum|title=Arsenal could pounce on Rachid Ghezzal's Lyon conundrum|first=Michael|last=Yokhin|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=24 January 2017}}</ref>

Dinamo Zagreb === [[File:20160824 RBS DIN 6900.jpg|left|thumb|Benković playing for Dinamo Zagreb against [[FC Red Bull Salzburg|Red Bull Salzburg]] in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League qualifying phase and play-off round#Red Bull Salzburg v Dinamo Zagreb|UEFA Champions League]]]] ==== 2015–16 season ==== On 19 July 2015, Benković made his debut for the club in a 1–1 draw with [[NK leg]] of the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League qualifying phase and play-off round#Third qualifying round|third qualifying round]] of the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]]; playing twelve minutes after coming off the bench as a substitute in the 78th minute.{{Cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000631/match=2015612/index.html|title=UEFA Champions League – Fola-Dinamo Zagreb|work=UEFA.com|access-date=9 August 2018}} He went on to make a total of 18 competitive appearances for the club in the [[2015–16 GNK Dinamo Zagreb season|2015–16 season]].{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/filip-benkovi/318349/|title=Croatia – F. Belupo]], after Dinamo went 0–1 in the 92nd minute, Benković scored a last-minute equalizing goal in the 94th minute, to make it 1–1.{{Cite web|url=http://prvahnl.hr/matches/306592/dinamo-slaven-belupo-1-1/|title=Remi Dinama i Slaven Belupa |work=Hrvatski Telekom Prva liga|language=hr|access-date=9 August 2018|date=29 July 2016}} On 10 August, Benković played the full 90 minutes in a 4–0 away win over [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]].{{Cite web|url=http://prvahnl.hr/matches/306589/hajduk-dinamo-0-4/|title=Slavlje Dinama nad web|url=http://prvahnl.hr/matches/306628/lokomotiva-dinamo-0-1/|title=Dinamo svladao Lokomotivu |work= Hrvatski Telekom Prva liga|language=hr|access-date=9 August 2018|date=23 September 2016}} In the news|url=http://www.goal.com/hr/vijesti/benkovic-nastavlja-s-terapijama-u-zagrebu/1fsxwq6jsnypc1qy3t7zzbosif|title=Filip Benković misteriozna ozljeda|publisher= Goal.com|access-date=9 August Sébastien Perruchet da Silva''' (born 15 March 1989), known as '''Adrien Silva''',{{cite web|url=http://www.sporting.pt/en/football/main-team/squad/adrien-sebastian-perruchet-silva|title=Adrien Silva|publisher=Sporting CP|accessdate=11 July 2016}} is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Ligue 1]] club [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], on loan from [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], and the [[Portugal national football team|Portugal national team]]. A [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]], he is known for his dribbling and passing skills.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportvox.fr/article.php3?id_article=14457|title=Adrien Silva: la nouvelle perle lusitaine|trans-title=Adrien Silva: the new Lusitanian pearl|publisher=Sport Vox|language=fr|date=14 June 2007|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407104736/http://www.sportvox.fr/article.php3?id_article=14457|archivedate=7 April 2012}} He began his career with [[Sporting CP|Sporting]], making his first-team debut at the age of 18. In ten years with the club he played 237 games and scored 39 goals, and won the [[2008 Taça de Portugal Final|2008]] and [[2015 Taça de Portugal Final|2015 Taça de Portugal]] trophies. He had loan spells with [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] and [[Associação Académica de Coimbra – O.A.F.|Académica]], where he won the Taça de Portugal again. In 2018 he moved to Leicester, and joined Monaco on loan in January 2019. Silva won 46 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] at youth level, including 13 for the [[Portugal national under-21 football team|under-21 team]]. He made his senior debut in 2014 and played at [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]], which Portugal won, and the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]]. ==Club career== ===Early years=== Silva was born in [[Angoulême]], [[Poitou-Charentes]], France, to a Portuguese father and a French mother.{{cite web|url=http://www.olheiros.net/artigo/ler/216|title=Adrien Silva, o futuro bate à porta|trans-title=Adrien Silva, the future knocks on the door|publisher=Olheiros|language=pt|date=22 January 2008|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708001443/http://www.olheiros.net/artigo/ler/216|archivedate=8 July 2010}} He began his football career at the age of 10 with [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux]], but after one year there his father, who worked in [[aeronautics]], returned to Portugal and the family settled in [[Arcos de Valdevez]].{{cite web|url=http://www.machainesport.fr/le-blog/2011/02/bischoff-adrien-le-juste-milieu/|title=Bischoff & Adrien, le juste milieu|trans-title=Bischoff & Adrien, the right midfield|publisher=Ma Chaine Sport|language=fr|date=3 February 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426072525/http://www.machainesport.fr/le-blog/2011/02/bischoff-adrien-le-juste-milieu/|archivedate=26 April 2012}} Silva spent two seasons with local Associação Recreativa e Cultural de Paçô, who later began to host a tournament in his honour, the A.R.C.Paçô–Adrien Silva Tournament, held every June.{{cite news|url=http://gazetadosarcos.com/ver/1930|title=Torneio Adrien Silva nos dias 10, 11 e 12 de Junho |trans-title=Adrien Silva Tournament on 10, 11, and 12 June|newspaper=Gazeta dos Arcos|language=pt|date=2 June 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207065555/http://gazetadosarcos.com/ver/1930|archivedate=7 February 2012}} Silva then spent six years in [[Sporting CP|Sporting]]'s academy, and won four national and three regional championships.{{cite web|url=http://www.centenariosporting.com/index.php?content=1719|title=2006–2007 – Adrien Silva no Sporting até 2012|trans-title=2006–2007 – Adrien Silva at Sporting until 2012|publisher=Centenário Sporting|language=pt|accessdate=26 December 2011}} At the age of 15 he was scouted by [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], along with [[Portugal national under-16 football team|Portugal under-16]] teammates Ricardo Fernandes and [[Fábio Ferreira (Portuguese footballer)|Fábio Ferreira]], and the three players trained at the English club's facilities in January 2005. Sporting filed a complaint with [[FIFA]] that Chelsea had not followed the correct procedures,{{cite web|url=http://inhome.rediff.com/sports/2005/jan/06chel.htm|title=Chelsea facing FIFA complaint|publisher=[[Rediff.com]]|date=6 January 2005|accessdate=25 March 2009}} and Silva stayed with Sporting, although Fernandes and Ferreira did later move to the London club.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10268~861913,00.html|title=Chelsea bring in 11 first year players|publisher=Chelsea F.C|date=5 July 2005|accessdate=25 March 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308221809/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10268~861913%2C00.html|archivedate=8 March 2012}} ===Sporting=== In March 2007, Silva signed his first professional contract, agreeing to a five-year deal with Sporting. In July, after spending the final two months of [[2006–07 Primeira Liga|the season]] playing with the [[Sporting CP B|reserve team]], he was officially promoted to the main squad by manager [[Paulo Bento]] ahead of the [[2007–08 Primeira Liga|upcoming campaign]]. He made his [[Primeira Liga]] debut on 17 August, appearing as a late [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 4–1 home win against [[Associação Académica de Coimbra – O.A.F.|Académica de Coimbra]];{{cite news|url=https://www.cmjornal.pt/cm-ao-minuto/detalhe/sporting-goleia-academica|title=Sporting goleia Académica|trans-title=Sporting rout Académica|newspaper=[[Correio da Manhã]]|language=pt|date=17 August 2007|accessdate=3 September 2017}} on 12 December, after appearing as an unused substitute in several league and European matches, he made his first professional start and [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] debut in a 3–0 victory over [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2008/matches/round=15105/match=301242/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Sporting bow out with a win|publisher=UEFA|date=13 December 2007|accessdate=1 January 2018}} Four days later he made his first start in the league, in a 2–1 win at [[C.S. Marítimo]].{{cite news|url=https://www.cmjornal.pt/desporto/futebol/detalhe/leao-soube-merecer-sorte|title=Leão soube merecer a sorte|trans-title=Lion earnt his luck|newspaper=Correio da Manhã|language=pt|date=17 December 2007|accessdate=3 September 2017}} Silva featured in both legs of Sporting's round of 32 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in the [[2007–08 UEFA Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/237585?cc=5901|title=Bolton 1–1 Sporting Lisbon: Advantage Portugal|publisher=[[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]]|date=6 March 2008|accessdate= 26 December 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=237593&cc=5901|title=Sporting Lisbon 1–0 Bolton|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=13 March 2008|accessdate=26 December 2011}} On 16 April he started in the 5–3 victory over Benfica in [[2007–08 Taça de Portugal|the semi-final]] of the [[Taça de Portugal]], being replaced after only 35 minutes in what was the last of his 15 appearances of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/sporting-benfica-5-3-cronica|title=Sporting-Benfica, 5–3 (crónica)|trans-title=Sporting-Benfica, 5–3 (match report)|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=16 April 2008|accessdate=3 September 2017}} As in his first year, Silva struggled for minutes in [[2008–09 Primeira Liga|2008–09]]. He played his first match on 22 November 2008 in a 1–0 league win over [[Associação Naval 1º de Maio]], playing 16 minutes off the bench.{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2008/11/22/desporto/noticia/liedshow-da-mais-tres-pontos-e-o-terceiro-lugar-ao-sporting-1350899/amp|title="Liedshow" dá mais três pontos e o terceiro lugar ao Sporting|trans-title=“Liedshow” gives Sporting another three points and third place|newspaper=[[Público (Portugal)|Público]]|language=pt|date=22 November 2008|accessdate=3 September 2017}} He made his first start in a [[2008–09 Taça da Liga|3–0 home win]] against Marítimo in the [[Taça da Liga]],{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/desporto/jornal/sporting-entra-a-ganhar-na-taca-da-liga-com-vitoria-sobre-o-maritimo-288014|title=Sporting entra a ganhar na Taça da Liga com vitória sobre o Marítimo|trans-title=Sporting have League Cup winning debut with victory over Marítimo|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=15 December 2008|accessdate=3 September 2017}} and he also made Bento's starting XI three months later in the ''Lions''' 1–7 defeat to [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] in [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League|the Champions League last 16 second leg]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2009/round=15277/match=302799|title=Record-breaking Bayern stroll past Sporting|publisher=UEFA|date=11 March 2009|accessdate=26 December 2011}} He made 19 appearances in all competitions, notably playing the full 90 minutes in home wins against [[C.F. Estrela da Amadora]]{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/desporto/jornal/liedson-deu-ao-sporting-liberdade-para-continuar-a-sonhar-com-titulo-304276|title=Liedson deu ao Sporting liberdade para continuar a sonhar com título|trans-title=Liedson allowed Sporting to keep dreaming of title|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=26 April 2009|accessdate=3 September 2017}} and [[C.D. Nacional]].{{cite news|url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/desporto/sporting-termina-liga-com-vitoria-3-1-sobre-nacional=f516578|title=Sporting termina Liga com vitória (3–1) sobre Nacional|trans-title=Sporting end League with win (3–1) over Nacional|newspaper=[[Expresso (newspaper)|Expresso]]|language=pt|date=24 May 2009|accessdate=3 September 2017}} Silva scored his first career goal in a [[2009–10 Primeira Liga|2009–10]] [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Hertha BSC|Hertha Berlin]], the match-winner in a [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League|1–0 win]], when he also was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] after collecting a second yellow card in injury time.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000037/match=2000793/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Sporting end hoodoo to streak clear|publisher=UEFA|date=1 October 2009|accessdate=1 January 2018}} On 28 November 2009, in the [[Derby de Lisboa|Lisbon derby]], which ended 0–0,{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2009/11/28/desporto/noticia/sporting-renasce-das-cinzas-mas-ainda-nao-chega-1411859|title=Sporting renasce das cinzas, mas ainda não chega|trans-title=Sporting rise from the ashes, but it's still not enough|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=28 November 2009|accessdate=3 September 2017}} he made headlines in the Portuguese media because he covered the most distance of any Sporting player, having traveled over {{convert|10,049|m|mi}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.publico.pt/Desporto/saviola-e-adrien-foram-os-que-mais-correram-no-derby-1411914|title=Saviola e Adrien foram os que mais correram no "derby"|trans-title=Saviola and Adrien ran the most in derby|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=29 November 2009|accessdate=26 December 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120908131521/http://www.publico.pt/Desporto/saviola-e-adrien-foram-os-que-mais-correram-no-derby-1411914|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 September 2012}} Coach [[Carlos Carvalhal]] started him in 13 of the team's next 15 matches, but he eventually fell out of favour, as Sporting went on to finish in only fourth place with 48 points, the club's worst points total since the [[1992–93 Primeira Liga|1992–93 campaign]]. On 27 June 2010, it was announced that Silva would be joining [[Israel]]i side [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.]] on a season-long loan deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-sporting-news/12488-sporting-loan-adrien-silva-to-m-haifa |title=Sporting loan Adrien Silva to Maccabi Haifa|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=27 June 2010|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807165351/http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-sporting-news/12488-sporting-loan-adrien-silva-to-m-haifa|archivedate=7 August 2010}} The move was facilitated by the player's agent [[Pini Zahavi]], based in [[Tel Aviv]].{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/superliga-geral/adrien-silva-adrien-sporting-maccabi-haifa-maccabi/1173303-1676.html|title=Oficial: Sporting empresta Adrien Silva a clube de Israel|trans-title=Official: Sporting loan Adrien Silva to club in Israel|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=27 June 2010|accessdate=26 December 2011}} He made his debut for his new team on 29 July, in the first leg of the [[2010–11 UEFA Europa League|Europa League third qualifying round]] tie against [[FC Dinamo Minsk]];{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000126/match=2002768/index.html|title=M. Haifa 1–0 Dinamo Minsk|publisher=UEFA|date=29 July 2010|accessdate=26 December 2011}} he was rarely played in the [[Israeli Premier League]], but was a regular in [[2010–11 Toto Cup Al|the campaign]] in the [[Toto Cup]]. In January 2011, it was reported that Silva was considering going back to Portugal to regain match fitness. On the 16th, he spoke of his desire, telling daily sports newspaper ''[[A Bola]]'': "Returning to Portugal is an option that I like a lot since I can be followed more closely. In Israel, I don't have great visibility";{{cite web|url=http://academicacoimbra.com/home.php?sel=noticia¬i=501|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715131544/http://academicacoimbra.com/home.php?sel=noticia¬i=501|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 July 2012|title=Adrien a caminho?|trans-title=Adrien on the way?|publisher=Académica Coimbra|language=pt|date=16 January 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011}} Three days later, a six-month loan to Académica de Coimbra was confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://www.academica-oaf.pt/noticias/futebol-profissional/860-adrien-silva-assina-pela-academica/|title=Adrien Silva assina pela Académica|trans-title=Adrien Silva signs for Académica|publisher=Académica de Coimbra|language=pt|date=19 January 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011}} Silva found the net in his first appearance with the ''Students'', who were defeated 1–2 away against [[S.C. Olhanense]].{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/academica-liga-olhanense-ficha-adrien-silva-liga-2010-11-maisfutebol/520bb22f3004acea5b9acc23.html|title=Olhanense-Académica, 2–1 (ficha)|trans-title=Olhanense-Académica, 2–1 (match sheet)|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=22 January 2011|accessdate=3 September 2017}} He was again used rarely, but now due to injury problems – he fractured the fifth [[metatarsal]] in his right foot in a game with [[U.D. Leiria]] in March, which sidelined him for the rest of [[2010–11 Primeira Liga|the season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/academica-adrien-fracturou-quinto-metatarso-do-pe-direito|title=Académica: Adrien fracturou quinto metatarso do pé direito|trans-title=Académica: Adrien fractured right foot metatarsal|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=4 March 2011|accessdate=3 September 2017}} On 5 July 2011, Sporting and Académica extended the loan for [[2011–12 Primeira Liga|a further season]].{{cite web|url=http://relvado.aeiou.pt/mercado/transferencias/academica-adrien-fica-mais-uma-epoca-225516|title=Académica: Adrien fica mais uma época|trans-title=Académica: Adrien stays another season|publisher=Relvado|language=pt|date=5 July 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011}} On 26 September, completely recovered from his injury, Silva scored his first career brace in a 4–0 home win against [[C.D. Feirense]];{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2011/09/26/desporto/noticia/academica-goleia-feirense-e-segura-quinto-lugar-na-classificacao-1513805|title=Académica goleia Feirense e segura quinto lugar na classificação|trans-title=Académica rout Feirense and hold on to fifth place in table|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=26 September 2011|accessdate=4 September 2017}} on 19 November, in the [[2011–12 Taça de Portugal|fourth round of the Portuguese Cup]], he scored his team's second in a 3–0 shock triumph over Porto,{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-portuguese-cup-news/29706-fc-porto-humbled-by-academica|title=Porto humbled by Academica|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=19 November 2011|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125160853/http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-portuguese-cup-news/29706-fc-porto-humbled-by-academica|archivedate=25 January 2012}} adding another double in the next round against [[Leixões S.C.|Leixões SC]] (5–2 after [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]]).{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2011/12/04/desporto/noticia/academica-passa-leixoes--1523748|title=Académica passa Leixões|trans-title=Académica overcome Leixões|newspaper=Público|language=pt|date=4 December 2011|accessdate=4 September 2017}} He played the full 90 minutes in [[2012 Taça de Portugal Final|the final]] against Sporting, a 1–0 win which saw the [[Coimbra]] side lift its first domestic cup in 73 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-portuguese-cup-news/33587-cup-final-sporting-v-academica|title=Académica shock Sporting to lift Portuguese Cup|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=19 May 2012|accessdate=17 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102122918/http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-portuguese-cup-news/33587-cup-final-sporting-v-academica|archivedate=2 November 2013}} After returning to Sporting, Silva was awarded [[Sporting CP#Player of the Year|the club's Player of the Year award]] on 28 November 2013.{{cite web |url=https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/sporting/adrien-silva-e-william-carvalho-em-destaque-nos-premios-stromp_v699420 |title=Adrien Silva e William Carvalho em destaque nos Prémios Stromp |trans-title=Adrien Silva and William Carvalho highlighted at the Stromp Awards |publisher=[[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal]] |language=pt |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} He Portugal|Portuguese Cup]].{{cite news |url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/Sporting/interior.aspx?content_id=949424 |title=Adrien preparado para cumprir sonho no Jamor |accessdate=25 March 2016}} ===Leicester City=== [[File:Leicester 1 Chelsea 2 (AET) (39086583210).jpg|thumb|Silva (right) playing for Leicester City in an [[2017–18 FA Cup|FA Cup]] match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in March 2018]] On 31 August 2017, Sporting agreed a £22 million fee for Silva to move to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], pending international clearance.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/01/leicester-adrien-silva-transfer |title=Leicester await international clearance from Fifa over Adrien Silva transfer |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=2 January 2018}} The documents relating to his transfer did not reach FIFA until 14 seconds after the deadline; thus, he remained ineligible to play for the club until the next transfer window.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41118927 |title=Adrien Silva: Fifa rejects Leicester City's application for midfielder |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |first=Steve |last=Crossman |date=6 September 2017|accessdate=2 January 2018}} In an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'' in March 2018, Silva said it was "a very poor decision" by FIFA, despite his appeals, to uphold his ban.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/mar/18/adrien-silva-leicester-chelsea-fa-cup-fifa-sporting-lisbon |title=Adrien Silva: ‘I will never understand Fifa’s decision. We’re talking seconds’ |newspaper=The Guardian |first=Stuart |last=James |date=18 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018}} Silva was officially registered on 1 January 2018, and made his debut that same day as a late substitute in a 3–0 win at home to {{afc|Huddersfield Town}} in the [[Premier League]].{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/11191426/adrien-silva-completes-leicester-move-four-months-after-agreeing-deal |title=Adrien Silva completes Leicester move four months after agreeing deal |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |first=Andy |last=Charles |date=1 January 2018 |accessdate=2 January 2018}} He was given the number 14 jersey, referring to his transfer difficulties.{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/5249482/adrien-silva-shirt-number-leicester-debut/ |title=THE IRONY OF IT ALL Adrien Silva has the No 14 shirt at Leicester… a funny nod to the delayed paperwork that saw him wait four months for his debut |newspaper=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |first=Tom |last=Sheen |date=2 January 2018 |accessdate=3 January 2018}} Silva struggled for game time under manager [[Claude Puel]], having not started a league match since 10 August 2018.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/12/10/fulham-line-january-loan-deal-islam-slimani-claudio-ranieri/?WT.mc_id=tmg_share_tw|title=Fulham line up January move for Islam Slimani as Claudio Ranieri plots Premier League survival|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|first=John|last=Percy|date=10 December 2018|accessdate=11 December 2018}} He made only five appearances in all competitions, and was not included in the squad for a league match after 22 September.{{cite web|url=https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2018/12/10/leicester-reportedly-willing-to-loan-adrien-silva-out-perfect-fo/page/1/|title=Leicester reportedly willing to loan Adrien Silva out, perfect for Wolves?|publisher=HITC|first=Will|last=Butcher|date=10 December 2018|accessdate=11 December 2018}} On 31 January 2019, Silva joined [[AS Monaco FC]] – coached by his compatriot [[Leonardo Jardim]] – on loan until June, with [[Youri Tielemans]] moving in the opposite direction.{{cite web|url=https://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/football/monaco-adrien-silva-arrive-tielemans-file-1622819.html|title=Monaco: Adrien Silva arrive, Tielemans file|trans-title=Monaco: Adrien Silva arrives, Tielemans splits|publisher=[[RMC (France)|RMC]]|first1=Laurent|last1=Picat|first2=Loïc|last2=Tanzi|language=fr|date=30 January 2019|accessdate=30 January 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/999996/youri-tielemans-joins-on-loan-as-adrien-silva-heads-to-monaco/press-release|title=Youri Tielemans joins on loan as Adrien Silva heads to Monaco|publisher=Leicester City F.C|date=31 January 2019|accessdate=31 January 2019}} He made his [[Ligue 1]] debut on 2 February, playing 18 minutes in the 2–1 home victory over [[Toulouse FC]] after replacing compatriot [[Gelson Martins]].{{cite web|url=https://www.francefootball.fr/news/Ligue-1-premier-but-pour-cesc-fabregas-premiere-victoire-a-domicile-pour-monaco-face-a-toulouse/984789|title=Ligue 1: Premier but pour Cesc Fabregas, première victoire à domicile pour Monaco face à Toulouse|trans-title=Ligue 1: First goal for Cesc Fabregas, first home win for Monaco against Toulouse|publisher=[[France Football]]|first=Jérémy|last=Docteur|language=fr|date=2 February 2019|accessdate=4 February 2019}} ==International career== ===Youth=== [[File:20150616 - Portugal - Italie - Genève - Adrien Silva et Franco Vazquez.jpg|thumb|300px|Silva contesting possession of the ball with [[Italy national football team|Italy]]'s [[Franco Vázquez]] in a June 2015 friendly]] Though born in France, Silva elected to play for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]], and represented the country at every youth level. With [[Portugal national under-16 football team|the under-16s]] he appeared at the ''Tournoi du Val-de-Marne'', featuring in all three group stage matches – however, after he was found to have done unauthorized training with Chelsea, he was suspended by the [[Portuguese Football Federation]]. He played with the [[Portugal national under-17 football team|under-17 team]] as they attempted to qualify for the [[2007 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2007 UEFA European Championship]], being a regular as the side eventually fell short in [[2006 UEFA European Under-17 Championship elite round|the elite round]]. On 30 January 2007, the Portuguese Federation announced that Silva would be participating in the [[2007 UEFA–CAF Meridian Cup|2007 Meridian Cup]] (for under-18 players) as the country's only representative,{{cite web|url=https://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=3166653|title=Adrien Silva na Meridian Cup|trans-title=Adrien Silva at the Meridian Cup|publisher=[[Portuguese Football Federation]]|language=pt|date=30 January 2007|accessdate=26 December 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120801220805/http://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=3166653|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 August 2012}} and he declared that he was "very proud to represent Portugal in a European selection". However, prior to the start of the competition, he suffered an injury and was replaced by compatriot [[Romeu Ribeiro]].{{cite news|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/index.asp?op=ver¬icia=117094&tema=3|title=Romeu Ribeiro chamado à selecção da Europa de sub-18|trans-title=Romeu Ribeiro called for Europe team's under-18|newspaper=[[A Bola]]|language=pt|date=23 February 2007|accessdate=26 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070225085710/http://www.abola.pt/nnh/index.asp?op=ver¬icia=117094&tema=3|archivedate=25 February 2007}} Silva was limited to only seven appearances with the [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portuguese under-19s]], due to his increased involvement with Sporting's first team. He scored his first goal in the age group on 6 November 2007, in [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|the first round of qualification]] for the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2008 European Championship]] against the [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|Republic of Ireland]];{{cite web|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/fixturesresults/round=15034/match=300655/index.html|title=Portugal 2–1 Republic of Ireland|publisher=UEFA|date=6 November 2007|accessdate=26 December 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717065051/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/fixturesresults/round=15034/match=300655/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 July 2012}} despite a 2–1 victory, Portugal failed to progress past the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Championship elite qualification|elite stages]]. On 5 February 2009, Silva earned his first call up to the [[Portugal national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] under coach [[Rui Caçador]], for a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] with [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland]] that was played five days later.{{cite web|url=https://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=4618254|title=Sub-21: Convocados|trans-title=Sub-21: The selection|publisher=Portuguese Football Federation|language=pt|date=5 February 2009|accessdate=26 December minutes, before being substituted in a 3–1 win.{{cite web|url=https://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=4615158|title=No bom caminho|trans-title=Right on participant in the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|qualification campaign]] for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2011 European Championships]], appearing in five out of nine matches and scoring in a 1–1 draw with [[Macedonia national under-21 football team|Macedonia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season=2011/round=2000006/match=2000226/index.html|title=Timely Portugal dash Macedonian hopes|publisher=UEFA|date=13 October 2009|accessdate=26 December 2011}} ===Senior=== Silva was called up by new Portugal coach [[Fernando Santos (Portuguese footballer)|Fernando Santos]] for a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] in [[France national football team|France]] on 11 October 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.charentelibre.fr/2014/10/11/adrien-silva-le-portugais-ne-a-angouleme-fetera-sa-1ere-selection-contre-la-france-video,1919086.php|title=Adrien Silva: le portugais né à Angoulême fêtera sa 1ère sélection contre la France|trans-title=Adrien Silva: the Portuguese born in Angoulême will mark his first international appearance against France|publisher=Charente Libre|language=fr|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=7 November 2014}} but did not play in the 1–2 defeat. He made his senior international debut in another friendly, replacing [[André Gomes]] midway through the second half of a 1–0 win over [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] at [[Old Trafford]] on 18 November.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2839904/Argentina-0-1-Portugal-Raphael-Guerreiro-scores-injury-time-winner-Cristiano-Ronaldo-Lionel-Messi-withdrawn-half-time-heavyweight-showdown-Old-Trafford.html|title=Argentina 0–1 Portugal: Raphael Guerreiro scores injury-time winner as Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi are withdrawn at half-time in heavyweight showdown at Old Trafford|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last1=Bernstein|first1=Joe|date=18 November 2014|accessdate=18 November 2014}} Silva was selected for the [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]] squad.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/portugal/story/2874983/new-bayern-munich-signing-renato-sanches-picked-for-portugal-squad|title=Portugal name Bayern Munich signing Renato Sanches for Euros squad|publisher=ESPN FC|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}} His first game in the tournament took place on 25 June, when he played the full 120 minutes in the round of 16 clash against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], a 1–0 win after [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com//uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000744/match=2017998/postmatch/report/index.html#portugal+snatch+extra+time|title=Quaresma snatches extra-time win for Portugal|publisher=UEFA|date=25 June 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}} Having also been picked for the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]],{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/internacional/selecao/noticias/interior/direto--os-convocados-de-portugal-para-a-taca-das-confederacoes-8506152.html|title=Éder fica fora dos convocados, Beto e José Sá nas escolhas|trans-title=Éder out of squad, Beto and José Sá picked|newspaper=[[O Jogo]]|language=pt|date=25 May 2017|accessdate=2 July 2017}} Silva contributed with four appearances as Portugal finished third. He scored his first goal for his country on 2 July, a 104th-minute [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] to help defeat [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] 2–1 in the third place play-off.{{cite web|url=http://www.tsf.pt/desporto/interior/portugal-tenta-o-terceiro-lugar-na-despedida-da-taca-das-confederacoes-8607365.html|title="Portugal fez uma prova excelente", diz Fernando Santos|trans-title="Portugal had an excellent tournament", Fernando Santos says|publisher=[[TSF (radio station)|TSF]]|language=pt|date=2 July 2017|accessdate=2 July 2017}} Silva was selected for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/portugal-world-cup-squad|title=Nearly half Portugal's Euro squad to miss World Cup|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=17 May 2018|accessdate=17 May 2018}} He played in three games, and Portugal were knocked out by [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in the second round. ==Career statistics== professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven|OH Leuven]], on loan from [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. ==Club career== ===Leicester City=== Kapustka was signed by [[Premier League]] club Leicester City for a reported £7.5m in August 2016, signing a five-year contract.{{cite|title = Bartosz Kapustka: Leicester City sign Poland winger|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36946485|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 3 August 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}} He cited manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] as his motivation for joining the club.{{cite|title = Bartosz Kapustka explains why he wants move to Leicester|url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10517451/bartosz-kapustka-explains-why-he-wants-move-to-leicester|publisher = Sky Sports|date = 31 July 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}} However, Kapustka did not receive any first team football for the first half of the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016-17]] season and was only named in two match day squads.{{cite|title = Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri unsure when £7.5m signing Bartosz Kapustka will be ready for Premier League|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3981420/Leicester-boss-Claudio-Ranieri-unsure-7-5m-signing-Bartosz-Kaputska-ready-Premier-League.html|publisher = Daily Mail Online|date = 29 November 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}} Ranieri admitted he was unsure when Kapustka "will be ready to play in the Premier League".{{cite|title = Leicester City recruitment under fire as Claudio Ranieri admits £7.5m signing is not ready for Premier League|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/28/leicester-city-recruitment-fire-claudio-ranieri-admits-75m-signing/|publisher = The Telegraph|date = 28 November 2016|accessdate = 8 January 2017}} Having already played for the [[Leicester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Leicester Under-23s]], a [[Loan (sports)|loan]] move was not possible due to FIFA rules prohibiting a player from appearing for three clubs in one season.{{cite|title = Leicester misfit Bartosz Kapustka travels with squad for FA Cup game against Everton as club consider loan|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4096460/Leicester-misfit-Bartosz-Kapustka-included-squad-FA-Cup-game-against-Everton-club-consider-loan.html|publisher = Daily Mail Online|date = 7 January 2017|accessdate = 8 January 2017}}"Players may be registered with a maximum of three clubs during one season. During this period, the player is only eligible to play official matches for two clubs". https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/31104494 Kapustka finally made his senior debut for Leicester in a 1–2 [[FA Cup]] third-round win at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 7 January 2017, coming on as an 84th-minute substitute for [[Marc Albrighton]].{{cite|title = Everton 1-2 Leicester City|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38474504|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 7 January 2017|accessdate = 8 January 2017}} He made his full debut in a 3–1 FA Cup fourth-round replay win over [[Derby County]] on 8 February 2017,{{cite web |title=Leicester City 3-1 Derby County |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38822191 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 February 2017 |accessdate=9 February 2017}} playing in a [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|central attacking role behind striker]] [[Ahmed Musa (footballer)|Ahmed Musa]].{{cite web |title=Leicester City fans react on Twitter to Bartosz Kapustka's performance |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/02/08/leicester-city-fans-react-on-twitter-to-bartosz-kapustkas-perfor/page/1-2/ |publisher=HITC Sport |author=Dan Coombs |accessdate=11 February 2017}} Kapustka made 47 touches and two interceptions before he was replaced by [[Riyad Mahrez]] in the 81st minute. ====SC Freiburg (loan)==== On 14 July 2017, Kapustka joined [[Bundesliga]] club [[SC Freiburg]] on loan for 2017–18 season. The [[Breisgau]]-based side secured an option to sign him permanently at the end of the season for a transfer fee of €5 million.{{cite news |title=Kapustka kommt: Freiburg findet Grifo-Ersatz |url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/701526/artikel_kapustka-kommt_freiburg-findet-grifo-ersatz.html |accessdate=14 July 2017 |work=kicker Online |date=14 July 2017 |language=German}} ====OH Leuven (loan)==== On 31 August 2018, Kapustka joined [[Belgian First Division B]] club [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven]] on loan for 2018–19 season.{{cite news |title=OHL leent Kapustka van Leicester City|trans-title=OHL loans Kapustka from Leicester City |url=https://www.ohleuven.com/nieuws/840402/ohl-leent-kapustka-van-leicester-city |accessdate=1 September 2018 |work=ohl.be |date=31 August 2018 |language=Dutch}} ==International career== On 7 September 2015, Kapustka made his debut appearance for the [[Poland National Football Team|Poland national team]] in a match against [[Gibraltar National Football Team|Gibraltar]], substituting [[Jakub Błaszczykowski]]. He scored his first goal for the national team on his debut.{{cite news |last=Koźmiński |first=Piotr |title=Lewandowski's Poland in for 'fierce fight' |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/news/newsid=2279955.html |publisher=UEFA |date=8 September 2015 |accessdate=13 June 2016}} In the buildup to the [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]], Kapustka was involved in a brawl outside a night club, in which he sustained an injury. Following the incident, he made a phone call personally to Polish national team manager [[Adam Nawałka]], to ask for his forgiveness and ask that he not be excluded from the squad for the upcoming tournament.{{cite news |last=Wheatley |first=Chris |title=A new star is born: Poland teenager Kapustka lights up Northern Ireland win |url=http://www.goal.com/euro2016/en/article/a-new-star-is-born-poland-teenager-kaputska-lights-up-northern-ireland-win/kvmpbiz113l618dbfxk3nod8h |publisher=Goal |date=12 June 2016 |accessdate=12 June 2016}} Kapustka was eventually selected for Poland's Euro 2016 campaign, and produced a standout performance in the team's opening match victory over [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]]. ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|23 May 2018}} {{cite web |url=http://www.90minut.pl/kariera.php?id=24420 |title=Bartosz Kapustka |publisher=90minut.pl |accessdate=26 December Leicester City's official 25-man Premier League squad and U21 list|publisher=TalkSport|date=5 September 2014|accessdate=16 January 2015}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|1|23|df=yes}}{{cite web |title=Callum Elder |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/callum-elder-248806/|publisher=11v11 |accessdate=1 December 2015}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], Australia | height = {{height|m=1.80}} | position = [[Left back]] | currentclub = [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]
(on loan from [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]) | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Manly United FC|Manly United]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2013 | youthclubs2 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | years1 = 2013– | clubs1 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2015 | clubs2 = → [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 21 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2015–2016 | clubs3 = → [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] (loan) | caps3 = 18 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2016–2017 | clubs4 = → [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] (loan) | caps4 = 6 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017 | clubs5 = → [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] (loan) | caps5 = 5 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2017–2018 | clubs6 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps6 = 27 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2019– | clubs7 = → [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] (loan) | caps7 = 2 | goals7 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[Australia national under-20 soccer team|Australia U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | pcupdate = 18:27, 19 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Callum Roddie Elder''' (born 27 January 1995) is an Australian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[left back]] for [[Ipswich Town F.C|Ipswich Town]], on loan from [[Leicester City F.C|Leicester City]]. He represented [[Australia national under-20 soccer team|Australia U20]] at international level. ==Club career== ===Leicester City=== A [[left back]], Elder was born in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] and began his youth career with [[Manly United FC|Manly United]], before moving to [[England]] at the age of 16 to begin a scholarship in the [[Leicester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]] at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/ten-facts-on-new-signing-callum-elder-from-leicester-city-3215294.aspx|title=Get to know new signing Callum Elder as he joins from Leicester City|last=Brett|first=Ciaran|access-date=30 July 2016}} After completing his scholarship at the end of the [[2012–13 Leicester City F.C. season|2012–13]] season, he was awarded his first professional contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/150513-academy-pair-pen-deals-822731.aspx|title=Academy Pair Pen Deals|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=15 May 2013|accessdate=4 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911225915/http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/150513-academy-pair-pen-deals-822731.aspx|archivedate=11 September 2013 |deadurl=no}} Graduating to the Foxes' U21 team, he progressed to sign a new two-year deal at the end of the [[2014–15 Leicester City F.C. season|2014–15]] season and a further extension a year later,{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/au/news/leicesters-aussie-young-gun-out-impress|title=Leicester's Aussie young gun out to impress|date=28 July 2015|access-date=30 July 2016}} which will keep him at the [[King Power Stadium]] until June 2019.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/2016-17/elder-signs-new-lcfc-deal-3214794.aspx|title=Elder Signs New LCFC Deal|last=City|first=Leicester|access-date=30 July 2016}} ====Mansfield Town (loan)==== On 8 January 2015, Elder was [[Loan (sports)|loaned out]] to [[Football League Two|League Two]] club [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]] for one month.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30730426|title=Callum Elder: Mansfield Town sign Leicester City defender|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=8 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}} He made his professional debut two days later, starting in a 2–1 away loss against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30663580|title=Burton 2–1 Mansfield|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}} He became a regular starter, which saw his loan extended to the end of the [[2014–15 Mansfield Town F.C. season|2014–15]] season.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/elders-mansfield-loan-extended-2324826.aspx|title=Elder's Mansfield Loan Extended|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=12 March 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504181619/http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/elders-mansfield-loan-extended-2324826.aspx|archivedate=4 May 2015|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/mansfield-extend-elder-stay-2398604.aspx|title=Mansfield Extend Elder Stay|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=14 April 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504181621/http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/mansfield-extend-elder-stay-2398604.aspx|archivedate=4 May 2015|deadurl=no}} Elder made 21 appearances for the Stags and returned to Leicester at the end of the season.{{Soccerbase season|74272|2014|access-date=30 July 2016}} ====Peterborough United (loan)==== On 29 August 2015, Elder joined [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on a one-month loan,{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/elder-heads-to-peterborough-on-loan-2653809.aspx|title=Elder Heads To Peterborough On Loan|last=City|first=Leicester|website=www.lcfc.com|access-date=30 July 2016}} which was later extended until January 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/elder-extends-peterborough-loan-2701254.aspx|title=Elder Extends Peterborough Loan|last=City|first=Leicester|website=www.lcfc.com|access-date=30 July 2016}} He made 21 appearances and scored the first senior goal of his career, which came in a 4–0 thrashing of [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on 24 October 2015.{{Soccerbase season|74272|2015|access-date=30 July 2016}} A foot injury suffered in a match versus [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 19 December led to the early termination of Elder's loan.{{cite web|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/sport/football/posh/posh-latest-blow-for-peterborough-united-as-elder-is-ruled-out-of-festive-football-1-7131375|title=POSH LATEST: Blow for Peterborough United as Elder is ruled out of festive football|website=www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk|access-date=30 July 2016}} ====Brentford (loan)==== On 30 July 2016, Elder joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on loan for the duration of the [[2016–17 Brentford F.C. season|2016–17]] season.{{cite web|title=Callum Elder joins from Leicester City|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/callum-elder-joins-brentford-from-leicester-city-3215237.aspx|website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk|publisher=Brentford F.C.|accessdate=30 July 2016}} He was an ever-present in league matches during the opening month of the season, before suffering a knee injury during a 2–0 win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 10 September 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-boss-gives-update-leicester-11900889|title=Brentford boss gives injury update on Callum Elder|date=18 September 2016|access-date=19 September 2016}} Elder's recovery was delayed by a thigh injury and he returned to the King Power Stadium for treatment in mid-December 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-target-alan-judge-wont-12191470#rlabs=1%20rt$sitewide%20p$6|title=Injury update on Saunders, Bonham, Elder, Macleod, Henry & Judge|last=Moore|first=Tom|date=17 November 2016|newspaper=getwestlondon|access-date=23 November 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/leicester-city-take-brentford-loanee-12329866|title=Leicester City take Brentford loanee back|last=Street|first=Tim|date=16 December 2016|work=|newspaper=getwestlondon|access-date=16 December 2016|via=}} He returned to training with Brentford on 16 January 2017,{{Cite news|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-boss-outlines-plans-left-12468808|title=Brentford boss outlines plans for left back spot|last=Moore|first=Tom|date=17 January 2017|work=|newspaper=getwestlondon|access-date=17 January 2017|via=}} but failed to make an appearance before being recalled by Leicester City two weeks later.{{Cite news|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/brentford-loanee-callum-elder-recalled-by-leicester-city-3546995.aspx|title=Brentford loanee Callum Elder recalled by Leicester City|last=FC|first=Brentford|date=|work=|language=en|access-date=31 January 2017|via=}} ====Barnsley (loan)==== On 31 January 2017, Elder joined Championship club [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on loan until the end of the [[2016–17 Barnsley F.C. season|2016–17]] season.{{Cite news|url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/callum-elder-joins-on-loan-from-leicester-city.-3546168.aspx|title=Callum Elder Joins On Loan From Leicester City.|last=|first=|date=|work=|language=en|access-date=31 January 2017|via=}} ====Wigan Athletic (loan)==== On 31 July 2017, Elder joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a season long loan.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40783353|title=Wolves' Lee Evans and Leicester's Callum Elder join Wigan on season-long loans|last=|first=|date=|work=|language=en|access-date=31 July 2017|via=}} He made his debut on 5 August at [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] but was sent off in the 44th minute. Wigan won the match 1–0.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40760933 |title=MK Dons 0–1 Wigan |publisher=BBC |date=5 August 2017 |accessdate=5 August 2017}} ====Ipswich Town (loan)==== On 2 January 2019, Elder joined [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on loan for the remainder of the 2018–19 Championship season.{{cite web |url=https://www.itfc.co.uk/news/2019/january/callum-elder-joins-ipswich-on-loan/ |title=Callum Elder joins on loan |publisher=Ipswich Town Football Club |date=2 January 2019 |accessdate=2 January 2019}} ==International career== Elder is eligible to play for [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]], [[Scotland]] and [[England national football team|England]] at international level. In October 2013, Elder was called up by [[Australia national under-20 soccer team|Australia U20]] for the [[2014 AFC U-19 Championship qualification|2014 AFC U19 Championship qualifying]] matches and made a single appearance in a 3–0 win over [[Chinese Taipei national football team|Chinese Taipei]] on 5 October.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/051013-international-call-ups-for-five-foxes-1096529.aspx|title=International Call-Ups For Five Foxes|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=5 January 2013|accessdate=4 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007122810/http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/051013-international-call-ups-for-five-foxes-1096529.aspx|archivedate=7 October 2013 |deadurl=no}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-afc.com/afcasfeeds?fixtureid=7600&stageid=293&tMode=C&view=ajax&show=matchsummary|title=AFC U-19 CHAMPIONSHIP 2014|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} He was not named in the squad for the [[2014 AFC U-19 Championship|tournament finals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.footballaustralia.com.au/article/paul-okon-names-young-socceroos-squad-for-afc-u-19-championship/1kod8khddxypy100tmw05v4jlc|title=Paul Okon names Young Socceroos squad for AFC U-19 Championship|access-date=30 July 2016}} ==Style of play== Elder describes himself as "an athletic full back. I like getting up and down the left-hand-side".{{Cite news|url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/elder-i-was-really-eager-to-jump-at-the-chance-to-play-here.-3547069.aspx|title=Elder: "I was really eager to jump at the chance to play here."|last=|first=|date=|work=|language=en|access-date=31 January 2017|via=}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 19 January 2019}} {| style="text-align: center" class="wikitable" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !
